(4)  Any commercial establishment which holds, promotes, sponsors or allows any contest, promotion, special night, event or any other activity where live patrons of the establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct described in subsections (1), (2), and/or (3) herein; 
(5)  Any commercial establishment having a substantial portion of its stock in trade, books, magazines or other periodicals, videotapes or movies or other reproductions, whether for sale or rent which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" as defined herein or "specified anatomical areas" as defined herein or having a segment or section comprising more than 50 square feet of its total floor space, devoted to the sale or display of such material, or which utilizes 25 percent or more of its display area for the display or offer for sale or rental such media or materials, or which derives more than five percent of its net sales from the sale or rental of such material; 
(6)  Any commercial establishment utilizing an enclosed building with a capacity of 50 or more persons used for cinematographic or videographic presentation of material distinguished by or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas", as defined herein, for observation by patrons therein; 
(7)  Any adult motion picture theater, adult motion picture arcade, adult mini-motion picture theater, adult bookstore, adult video store, adult hotel, or adult motel, as defined herein; 
(8)  The definition of "adult entertainment establishment" shall not include traditional or mainstream theater, which means a theater, movie theater, concert hall, museum, educational institution, or similar establishment which regularly features live or other performances or showings which are not distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, display, or description or the featuring of specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities in that the depiction, display, description or featuring is incidental to the primary purpose of any performance. For purposes of this subsection, such performances and showings are regularly featured when they comprise at least 80 percent of all annual performances or showings. 
(9)  Any commercial establishment having a substantial portion of its stock in instruments, devices, paraphernalia, products, article or articles which are designed, sold or viewed for use in connection with "specified sexual activities" as defined herein, or which are sold or marketed primarily for stimulation of human genital organs or having a segment or section comprising more than 50 square feet of its total floor space, devoted to the sale or display of such items, or which utilizes 25 percent or more of its display area for the display or offer for sale or rental such items, or which derives more than five percent of its net sales from the sale or rental of such material. 
Adult hotel or motel means a hotel or motel which: 
(1)  Makes available to patrons any material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, and has a sign visible from any public right-of-way advertising that such material is available; or 
(2)  Regularly offers a room or rooms for rent for any period of time that is less than 12 consecutive hours; or 
(3)  Regularly allows a tenant or occupant of a room or rooms to sub-rent the room or rooms for a period of time that is less than 12 consecutive hours. 
Adult mini-motion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity for fewer than 50 persons used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
Adult motion picture arcade means any place to which the public is permitted to be invited wherein paper currency, coin- or slug-operated or electronically, electrically or mechanically controlled still or motion picture machines, projectors or other image-producing devices are maintained to show images to five or fewer persons per machine at any one time and where the images so displayed are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depicting or describing specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
Adult motion picture theater means an enclosed building with a capacity of 50 or more persons, used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas for observation by patrons therein. 
Adult video store means any establishment having a substantial portion of its stock in trade, video tapes or movies or other reproductions, whether for sale or rent, which are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, or an establishment with a segment or section, comprising more than ten square feet of its total floor space or wall space, or floor and wall space combined, devoted to the sale or display of such material. 
Application fee shall be the fee required to accompany an application for an adult entertainment establishment license under this chapter, and shall not include the annual regulatory fee for such establishments as established by the city's governing body. The application fee shall be a nonrefundable fee in an amount established by the city's governing body. 
Chief of police shall mean and include the duly appointed and serving chief of police for the City of Tifton, Georgia, or his designee, i.e., that person designated by the chief of police to act on his behalf and under his supervision in connection with this chapter. 
Children's day care facility shall be defined as a structure or portion of a structure wherein is provided care and supervision of children away from their place of residence for less than 24 hours per day on a regular basis for compensation. For the purpose of this chapter the term "children's day care facility" shall include but not be limited to the terms "nursery school," "early learning center," "pre- kindergarten," "private kindergarten," "play school," or "pre-school." 
City shall mean the City of Tifton, Georgia. 
City manager shall mean and include the duly appointed and serving city manager for the City of Tifton, Georgia, or his designee, i.e., that person designated by the city manager to act on his behalf and under his supervision in connection with this chapter. 
Convicted shall mean and include an adjudication of guilt or a plea of guilty or an Alford Plea or a plea of nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond when charged with a crime or an ordinance violation in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
Employee or adult entertainment establishment employee shall mean any person who performs any service on the premises of an adult entertainment establishment on a full-time, part-time, or contract basis, whether or not the person is an employee, an independent contractor, or any other kind of agent, and whether or not said person performs such services only for tips or is paid a salary, wage, or any other type of compensation by the adult entertainment establishment. The term "employee" or "adult entertainment establishment employee" shall include, but is not limited to, entertainers, wait staff, parking attendants, security personnel, cooks and dishwashers. The term "employee" or "adult entertainment establishment employee" shall not include a person who is temporarily on the premises for the sole purpose of repair or maintenance of the premises, any building or equipment on the premises, or for the delivery of any goods or merchandise to the premises. 
Governing body shall mean the mayor and city council for the City of Tifton, Georgia. 
License shall mean a license issued by the city under this chapter to a licensee which authorizes the licensee to operate, engage in, or carry on the business of an adult entertainment establishment as defined in this chapter. 
Licensee shall mean the holder of an adult entertainment establishment license issued under this chapter. 
Operator means the manager or other person principally in charge of an adult entertainment establishment. 
Owner means any individual or entity holding more than a 20 percent interest in an adult entertainment establishment. 
Permit shall mean a temporary or annual permit issued by the city which authorizes a person to work or perform services as an employee of an adult entertainment establishment as those terms are defined in this chapter. 
Premises or licensed premises shall mean the property or premises where an adult entertainment establishment licensed under this chapter operates, conducts, or carries on its business, and shall include the entire tract or parcel of land where such business is conducted. 
Regulatory fee shall be the annual regulatory fee to be paid by each adult entertainment establishment when it is issued an adult entertainment establishment license or a renewal of an adult entertainment establishment license by the city. 
Specified sexual activities shall be defined to mean and include any of the following: 
(1)  Actual or simulated sexual intercourse, oral copulation, anal intercourse, oral anal copulation, bestiality, direct physical stimulation of genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship, or the use of excretory functions in the context of a sexual relationship and any of the following sexually oriented acts or conduct: anilingus, buggery, coprophagy, coprophilia, cunnilingus, fellatio, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, piquerism, sapphism, zooerasty; 
(2)  Use of human or animal ejaculation, sodomy, oral copulation, coitus or masturbation; 
(3)  Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttocks or female breast; 
(4)  Masochism, erotic or sexually oriented torture, beating or the infliction of pain; or 
(5)  Erotic or lewd touching, fondling or other sexual contact with an animal by a human being. 
Specified anatomical areas shall include the following: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region, anus, or female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; or 
(2)  Human male genitalia in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012; Ord. No. 2016-11, § I, 6-6-2016 ) 
Sec. 10-33. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, association, partnership, or corporation to operate, engage in, conduct, or carry on, in or upon any premises within the corporate city limits of the City of Tifton, Georgia any adult entertainment establishment as defined in this chapter without first procuring an annual license to do so except as provided in subsection 10-41(b) of this article when the governing body fails to approve or deny an application for an adult entertainment license within the 30-day period provided for therein. In no event shall any license issued to an adult entertainment establishment under this chapter be in force or effect after midnight of December 31 of the year in which it is issued. The issuance of such an annual license shall not be deemed to authorize, condone or make legal any activity thereunder if the same is deemed illegal or unlawful under the laws of the State of Georgia or the United States. 
(b)  There shall be an annual regulatory fee for each adult entertainment establishment licensed within the city in an amount established by the city's governing body. The annual regulatory fee must be paid to the city within ten days after the governing body approves the application for an adult entertainment establishment license or a renewal thereof. No adult entertainment establishment license or renewal thereof shall be issued until the most recent annual regulatory fee has been paid. All licenses granted hereunder shall expire at midnight on December 31 of the year in which they are issued. Licensees who desire to renew their license shall file an application with the city clerk on the form provided for renewal of the license for the ensuing year. Applications for renewal must be filed before November 30 of each year. Any applicant filing a renewal application which is received by the city after November 30 shall pay, in addition to said annual regulatory fee, a late charge of 20 percent, and shall cease conducting business on the premises effective midnight December 31 until a renewal license is duly issued under this chapter. If a license renewal application is received after January 1, such application shall be treated as an initial application and the applicant shall be required to comply with all rules and regulations for the granting of licenses as if no previous license had been held, and the applicant shall cease conducting business on the premises until a renewal license is duly issued under this chapter. If a license application is received after January 1, investigative and administrative costs as set forth in this chapter will be assessed. All licenses granted hereunder shall be for the calendar year and the full annual regulatory fee must be paid for a license renewal application filed prior to July 1 of the license year. One-half of a full annual regulatory fee shall be paid for a license renewal application filed after July 1 of the license year. Any person renewing any license issued hereunder who shall pay the annual regulatory fee, or any portion thereof, after January 1, shall, in addition to said annual regulatory fee and late charges, pay simple interest on the delinquent balance at the annual rate then charged by the Internal Revenue Service of the United States on unpaid federal income taxes. 
(c)  The regulatory fee provided for in subsection (b) of this section shall be fixed by the governing body in an amount that will defray, in part, the costs incurred by the city through the enforcement of this chapter. The regulatory fee shall be exclusive of, and shall not include any costs of, licensing adult entertainment establishments under this chapter. 
(d)  Licenses and permits issued under this chapter shall not be transferable, except for a license or ownership interest under the following circumstances: in case of the death of an owner or a licensee as defined herein, the license pertaining to the owner's or licensee's adult entertainment establishment shall remain in force and effect for a period of up to 30 days in order to allow the beneficiary (or beneficiaries) who will inherit the ownership interest or license an opportunity to apply for and qualify to hold the interest or license under this chapter. In order to qualify to hold said interest or license, the beneficiary (or beneficiaries) shall make application to the city within the 30-day period as if he or she were applying for a new ownership interest or license under this chapter. If a completed application is filed within the 30-day period, then the existing license shall remain in effect for an additional period of up to 30 days following the date of filing in order to allow the governing body to grant or deny the application under this chapter. If the governing body grants the application, or if the application is deemed granted because of a failure to approve or deny the same within the 30-day period provided for in this chapter, then the beneficiary applicant(s) shall become the new owner(s) of the interest or license, which shall be considered transferred without any interruption of ownership interest which may have existed from the original approval of same, said interest or license being thereafter subject to all of the terms and conditions of this chapter. If the beneficiary fails to file a completed application under this subsection within the 30-day period, or if the application is denied (and if appealed, the denial is upheld on appeal), then the ownership interest or license shall terminate at midnight on the 30th day or at midnight on the day that a final judgment upholding the appeal is entered, and the adult entertainment establishment shall close its business on that day; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed to allow or permit any license to remain in force and effect beyond midnight on December 31 of the year in which the death occurs, unless necessary to allow for one or both of the two 30-day periods provided for in this subsection. If an appeal of a denial might remain pending on December 31 of the year in which it is filed, then in such an event, the beneficiary applicant shall file a new application for a license or approval of an ownership interest for the next succeeding calendar year under the terms of this chapter. 
(e)  All other changes in an ownership interest in an adult entertainment establishment or a license issued under this chapter must be reported in writing to the city manager prior to such transfer, and the person who is intended to receive such ownership interest shall be required to make an application for a license as if he or she were applying for a new license hereunder. No licensee may change the location of the licensee's operation; any change in location shall require application for a new license under this chapter, so that such application process is completed before the relocation takes place. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-34. - On-premises operator required. 
An adult entertainment establishment shall have a designated person(s) to serve as an on-premises operator. The operator(s) shall be principally in charge of the establishment and shall be located on the premises during all operating hours. If an adult entertainment establishment is found open for business without the presence of an on-premises operator, the licensee shall be cited for a violation of this chapter, and the business shall be ordered to close until an on-premises operator is present and remains present during all operating hours. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-35. - Application process and qualifications. 
(a)  Process. Any person, association, partnership or corporation desiring to obtain a license to operate, engage in, conduct, or carry on any adult entertainment establishment in the city shall make application for a license under this chapter to the city manager. Such application shall be made on forms furnished by the city, shall be made in the name of the adult entertainment establishment by an applicant who is a natural person and an agent of the adult entertainment establishment and shall include the name(s) of the operator(s) as defined herein and of the owner(s) as defined herein. If the adult entertainment establishment is a corporation, then the agent for purposes of making application for a license hereunder shall be the president or chief executive officer of the corporation. If the adult entertainment establishment is a partnership, the agent for such purposes shall be a general partner. At the time of submitting such application, a nonrefundable application fee payable in cash or by certified check in an amount established by the city's governing body shall be paid to the city to defray, in part, the cost of investigation and report required by this chapter. The city manager shall issue a receipt showing that such application fee has been paid. The application for a license does not authorize the operation of, engaging in, conducting or carrying on of any adult entertainment establishment. 
(b)  Contents. Each application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The full true name and any other names used by the applicant, the operator(s) and owner(s); 
(2)  The present address and telephone number of the applicant, the operator(s) and owner(s); 
(3)  The previous addresses of the applicant, the operator(s) and the owner(s), if any, for a period of five years immediately prior to the date of the application and the dates of residence at each; 
(4)  Acceptable written proof that the applicant, the operator(s) and the owner(s) are at least 18 years of age; 
(5)  The height, weight, color of eyes and hair and date and place of birth of the applicant, the operator(s) and the owner(s); 
(6)  Two photographs of the applicant, the operator(s) and the owner(s) at least two inches by two inches taken within the last six months; (and in addition, the applicant and the operator(s) must agree to be photographed by the city police department prior to issuance of the license applied for); 
(7)  The business, occupation or employment history of the applicant, the operator(s) and owner(s) for the five years immediately preceding the date of application; 
(8)  The business license history of the applicant and whether such applicant, in previous operations in this or any other location under license, has had such license or permit for an adult entertainment business or similar type of business revoked or suspended, the reason therefore, and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of revocation or suspension; 
(9)  If the application is made on behalf of a corporation, the name of the corporation, exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation or charter, together with the place and date of incorporation. If the application is on behalf of a limited partnership, a copy of the certificate of limited partnership shall be provided. If one or more of the partners is a corporation, the provisions of this subsection pertaining to corporations shall apply to each such corporation; 
(10)  The names and addresses of the owner and if applicable, the lessor of the real property upon which the adult entertainment establishment is to be operated, engaged in, conducted or carried on and a copy of the lease or rental agreement, if any; 
(11)  With respect to the applicant, the operator(s) and the owner(s), all convictions, (excluding misdemeanor traffic violations unrelated to driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol) within the past ten years, including a complete description of the crime or violation, the date of the crime or violation, date of conviction (including plea of guilty or nolo contendere or an Alford Plea), jurisdiction and any disposition including any fine or sentence imposed and whether the terms of disposition have been fully completed. Each person required to disclose convictions hereunder shall also provide a signed and notarized consent, on forms prescribed by the Georgia Crime Information Center, authorizing the release of his or her criminal records to the city police department. 
(12)  A complete set of fingerprints of the applicant and the operator(s); 
(13)  If the person or business entity on whose behalf application for a license is made is doing business under a trade name, a copy of the trade name as properly recorded. If the application is made on behalf of a corporation, a copy of its authority to do business in the state should be provided, including articles of incorporation, and a trade name affidavit, if any, and last annual report, if any; 
(14)  The address of the premises where the adult entertainment establishment will be operated, engaged in, conducted, or carried on; 
(15)  A plat prepared by a registered engineer or a registered land surveyor, licensed by the State of Georgia, showing the location of the proposed premises where the adult entertainment establishment will be operated, engaged in, conducted or carried on in relation to the neighborhood, the surrounding zoning, its proximity to any residential area, church, school, public park or children's day care facility, any other adult entertainment establishment, and any establishment licensed by the city to sell alcoholic beverages, beer or wine for consumption on the premises; the survey should depict the location and distance of the property use closest to the proposed premises that would disqualify the property if it were within the prohibited distance; 
(16)  Each application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall be verified and acknowledged under oath to be true and correct by: 
a.  If application is made on behalf of an individual, the individual; 
b.  If application is made on behalf of a partnership, by a general partner; 
c.  If application is made on behalf of a corporation, by the president or chief executive officer of the corporation; 
d.  If application is made on behalf of any other organization or association, by the chief administrative official. 
(17)  Appearance by applicant. The applicant or their attorney shall personally appear before the city manager with payment of the nonrefundable application fee in the amount established by the governing body of the city, and shall present the application containing the aforementioned and described information. 
(c)  Investigation; standards for granting of license. The city shall have 30 days from the date of actual receipt of a fully completed application to investigate the facts provided in the application and the background of the applicant, the operator(s) and owner(s). The city manager shall stamp the date of receipt of each application on the first page thereof and shall provide the applicant a photocopy of the stamped first page signifying the date of receipt of the application. The governing body shall approve or deny the completed application for an adult entertainment establishment license within 30 days of actual receipt of a fully completed application. If any application is received that is not fully complete for any reason, then in such event, the incomplete application shall be returned to the applicant as soon as possible following the discovery of the incompleteness, and the applicant shall be required to submit a newly completed application along with payment of an additional application fee in an amount established by the governing body of the city, and the 30-day time period specified above shall begin over again upon the actual receipt of the fully completed application. 
The application for an adult entertainment establishment license shall be granted if the governing body finds: 
(1)  The required license application fee has been paid; 
(2)  The application contains all of the information provided for in section 10-35(b), subsections (1) through (16) above, and the applicant has made no material misrepresentation of fact in the application; 
(3)  Neither the applicant nor any of the operator(s) or owner(s) has been convicted or pled guilty or entered an Alford Plea or a plea of nolo contendere to any crime involving assault, battery, keeping a place of prostitution, pandering, pimping, public indecency, prostitution, sodomy, solicitation of sodomy, masturbation for hire, sexual battery, rape, child molestation, enticing a child for indecent purposes, or any offense included in the definition of a "criminal offense against a victim who is a minor" as defined in O.C.G.A. § 42-1-12 within a period of ten years next preceding the date of the application. If there has been any such conviction or plea, then the application shall be denied. For purposes of this chapter, a conviction or plea of guilty or nolo contendere or an Alford Plea shall be ignored as to any offense for which the applicant was allowed to avail themselves of the Georgia First Offender Act unless the applicant was or is later adjudicated guilty of having violated the terms of his first offender treatment; 
(4)  Neither the applicant nor any of the operator(s) or owner(s) has had an adult entertainment establishment license or permit revoked for cause by this city or any other municipal corporation or county located in or out of the State of Georgia within the five-year period immediately preceding the date of the application; 
(5)  The building, structure, equipment and location of the premises of the adult entertainment establishment as proposed by the applicant is in compliance with all applicable laws, including but not limited to health, zoning, distance, fire and safety requirements and standards based on information provided by or through other city departments or Tift County; 
(6)  The applicant, operator(s) and owners(s) are all at least 18 years of age; 
(7)  The proposed premises will be located at least the minimum distances set forth in this chapter and as designated within the City of Tifton Development Code from any residential use, church, school, public park or children's day care facility, any other adult entertainment establishment, and any other establishment licensed by the city to sell alcoholic beverages, beer or wine for consumption on the premises; 
(8)  The grant of such license will not cause a violation of any law of the State of Georgia or the United States. 
The governing body shall deny the application for an adult entertainment establishment license if the application fails to meet any requirement contained in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-36. - Regulation of adult entertainment establishments. 
(a)  Location. No adult entertainment establishment shall be located: 
(1)  Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land that is zoned residential under the city's then current zoning ordinance; 
(2)  Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land on which a church, school, college campus, public park or children's day care facility is located; 
(3)  Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land containing another adult entertainment establishment; 
(4)  Within 500 feet of any parcel of land upon which any establishment licensed by the city to sell alcoholic beverages or malt beverages or wine for consumption on the premises is located; 
(5)  In any area of the city that lies outside the areas established for the permissible location of adult entertainment establishments under the city's Land Development Code § 4.03.21 (Appendix A of this Code). 
For purposes of this section, all distances referenced above shall be measured as defined within the city's Land Development Code § 4.03.21 (Appendix A of this Code). 
(b)  Adult entertainment establishment employees. 
(1)  Qualifications. All employees of an adult entertainment establishment shall be not less than 18 years of age. No employee employed in an adult entertainment establishment shall have been convicted of an offense described in section 10-35(c) of this chapter within the five years immediately preceding the proposed employment at or by an adult entertainment establishment. Any adult entertainment establishment employee who is convicted of any such crimes while so employed shall not thereafter work on any licensed premises in the city for a period of five years from the date of such conviction, unless a longer time is ordered by a court of competent jurisdiction. The terms "licensed premises" and "convicted" are defined in section 10-32 of this chapter. 
(2)  Permit for employment. Before any person may work as an employee on a licensed premises, he or she shall file a notice with the city manager of his or her intended employment on forms supplied by the city and shall thereupon receive a temporary permit for such employment from the city manager, which shall expire when the annual permit provided for herein is issued or when the decision of the city manager to deny the permit is finally upheld or overturned. The prospective employee shall supply a signed and notarized consent, on forms prescribed by the Georgia Crime Information Center, authorizing the release of his or her criminal records to the city manager. The prospective employee shall also provide a list of all of his or her convictions of offenses described in subsection 10-35(c) herein (including pleas of nolo contendere and Alford Pleas) within the past five years. The city manager shall approve or deny the permit within 15 days of the application. If the prospective employee is found to meet the requirements of this subsection (b), and upon payment of the permit fee, the city shall issue a permit approving such employment within 48 hours following such approval. 
Upon receipt of a temporary or annual permit under this chapter, the employee may begin or continue working on the licensed premises. If approval of an annual permit is denied, the city manager shall provide the prospective adult entertainment employee the reasons for the denial and the applicant may, within ten (days of said denial, appeal to the governing body who shall uphold or reverse the decision within 30 days of such appeal. The applicant may continue to work under the temporary permit during the pendency of the appeal. If the city manager does not approve or deny an application for an annual permit within 15 days of the date such application was received, then on the expiration of the 15th day: (1) the application shall be approved and the city shall immediately issue the permit for which application was made, and (2) the applicant shall have the right to begin or continue their employment in the manner allowed by the permit for which application was made. 
(3)  Categories of permits. There shall be three employee permit classifications: an operator permit, an adult establishment entertainer permit, and a permit for all other employees of an adult entertainment establishment. 
(4)  Permit fees. The governing body of the city shall establish a separate fee for each classification of permit. Each annual employee permit fee shall be in an amount which is reasonably tied to the costs of investigating the employee's record and background. 
(5)  Permits to be worn by employees. All permits issued under this chapter to employees shall be worn so as to be readily visible at all times during which the employee or permit holder is in or upon the licensed premises, except that when an adult entertainer is actually performing, he or she may place the permit in a place where it is readily obtainable if asked for by any city police officer or other law enforcement officer. 
(6)  Suspension or revocation, of permit; procedure. Violation by an adult entertainment employee of the provisions of this chapter and/or conviction of an offense described in subsection 10-35(c) of this chapter shall subject such adult entertainment employee to suspension or revocation of the permit for employment in the manner provided for herein. Permits for employment shall not be revoked for any other reason. Whenever the city manager finds that reasonable grounds exist to suspend or revoke a permit for employment issued hereunder, the city manager shall schedule a hearing before the governing body to consider such action and shall notify the employee at least 15 days prior to the hearing of the time and place of the hearing and the proposed action and grounds therefore. The employee shall be entitled to present evidence and cross-examine witnesses with or without legal counsel. The employee may continue working for the adult entertainment establishment during the pendency of any appeal under this section, either before the governing body or a reviewing court. The governing body shall make their decision within ten days of the hearing and shall notify the employee promptly in writing of its decision. In the event that a permit for employment is suspended or revoked by the governing body, and if the governing body's decision is upheld by a court of competent jurisdiction in the event of an appeal, then in either such event, an appeal cost in an amount established by the governing body of the city shall be assessed against the appellant, which must be paid before the appellant is allowed to work or perform any services on the premises of any adult entertainment establishment in the city. 
(7)  Independent contractors. For the purpose of this chapter, independent contractors working for an adult entertainment establishment shall be considered as employees and shall be required to satisfy the provisions of this chapter relating to employees of adult entertainment establishments. As used in this chapter, the terms "employee" and "adult entertainment establishment employee" shall include any person who performs any service on the premises of an adult entertainment establishment on a full-time, part-time, or contract basis, whether or not the person is an employee, an independent contractor, or any other kind of agent, and whether or not said person performs such services only for tips or is paid a salary, wage, or any other type of compensation by the adult entertainment establishment. The term "employee" or "adult entertainment establishment employee" shall not include a person on the premises for the sole purpose of repair or maintenance of the premises, or any building or equipment on the premises, or for the delivery of any goods or merchandise to the premises. 
(c)  Amateurs. Any person who wishes to perform as an adult entertainer in any adult entertainment establishment without being compensated or paid, shall first comply with this section by filing the notice and submitting the information provided for therein, and if necessary or applicable, by continuing the application process required to obtain an adult entertainment establishment employee permit. A temporary or annual permit issued to any such amateur performer shall be governed by and subject to this section as if the performer were an employee of the adult entertainment establishment. 
(d)  Hours and days of operation. An adult entertainment establishment may only be open between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m., and shall only be open on those days and hours when businesses selling alcoholic beverages are permitted to be open under the city's ordinances or Georgia state law. 
(e)  Display of licenses. An adult entertainment establishment licensee shall conspicuously display the license required by this chapter. 
(f)  Consent to jurisdiction and service. Any licensee issued a license under this chapter and any employee issued an employee permit under this chapter shall be deemed to have consented to the jurisdiction of the Municipal Court of the City of Tifton, Georgia, the State Court of Tift County, Georgia, and the Superior Court of Tift County, Georgia, for purposes of the enforcement of this chapter, and shall also be deemed to have consented to service of any citation or summons issued under this chapter via the United States mail with sufficient first class postage affixed and properly addressed to the licensee or employee at the address set forth on the application for such license or permit, as the case may be. Nothing herein shall be interpreted to preclude a police officer or deputy sheriff from personally serving a licensee or employee. 
(g)  Performance area. All dancing by adult entertainers at adult entertainment establishments shall occur on a platform intended for that purpose which is raised at least 18 inches from the level of the floor. 
(h)  Lighting. All areas of an adult entertainment establishment licensed hereunder shall be fully lighted at all times patrons are present. Full lighting shall mean illumination equal to 3.5 foot candles per square foot. 
(i)  Covering of windows and doors. All adult entertainment which is licensed and permitted by this chapter shall be carried on inside a closed building with all windows and doors covered so that the activities carried on inside cannot be viewed from the immediate areas surrounding the outside of the building. 
(j)  Retention of records. All adult entertainment establishments shall be required to retain all records pertaining to its employees for a period of ten years, and such records shall be open to inspection by any city police officer for official police business during normal operating hours. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-37. - Conduct or activities prohibited. 
(a)  Advertising without license. No person, partnership, corporation or other entity shall advertise or cause to be advertised an adult entertainment establishment without a valid adult entertainment establishment license issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(b)  Employment of minors or unpermitted persons. No adult entertainment establishment licensee shall employ or contract with a person under the age of 18 years or any person who has not obtained a permit pursuant to this chapter. 
(c)  Contact between patrons, employees. No patron, customer or guest shall be permitted to touch, caress or fondle any specified anatomical area of, or any part of, the body of any adult entertainer while on the premises of the adult entertainment establishment. No adult entertainment licensee, adult entertainment operator or adult entertainment employee shall be permitted to touch, caress or fondle any specified anatomical area of, or any part of, the body of any patron, customer or guest while on the premises of the adult entertainment establishment. 
(d)  Engaging in specified sexual activities prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any specified sexual activity as defined herein on the premises of any adult entertainment establishment. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person, association, partnership, corporation, or licensee under this chapter, to sell, trade, exchange, dispense, give away, consume, or allow the consumption of, any alcoholic beverage of any kind (including but not limited to spirituous liquors, malt beverages and wine) in or upon the premises of any adult entertainment establishment licensed under this chapter. In case of any conflict between this subsection and any other provision in this Code, this subsection shall prevail. 
(f)  In addition to the crime of "public indecency" provided for in O.C.G.A. § 16-6-8, which is applicable throughout the city and the State of Georgia, and in order to provide for more specific and clearer regulations pertaining to nudity in adult entertainment establishments in the city as expressly permitted in O.C.G.A. § 16-6-8(e), it shall be unlawful for any person to appear in any portion of an adult entertainment establishment or any other business open to the public in a state of nudity. The term "nudity" as used herein, shall mean and include the showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, or the anus, with less than a fully opaque covering, the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of the nipple or the areola thereof, or the showing of the covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state. Examples of attire that would comply with this section include but are not limited to those items commonly known as pasties, G-strings, T-backs, dental floss, and thongs. In case of any conflict between this subsection and any other provision in this section, this subsection shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-37.1. - Admission of minors unlawful. 
It is unlawful for an applicant to admit or permit the admission of minors within a regulated premises. 
( Ord. No. 2016-11, § I, 6-6-2016 ) 
Sec. 10-37.2 - Sales or displays in presence of minors unlawful. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter or give, to any minor any service, material, device or thing sold or offered for sale by an adult bookstore, adult motion picture theater, adult massage parlor or adult dancing establishment or other adult entertainment establishment. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any provisions to the contrary, no commercial establishment which does not come within the definition of an adult entertainment establishment shall advertise the sale or display any books, magazines or other periodicals, videotapes or movies or other reproductions, instruments, devices, paraphernalia, products, article or articles which are designed, sold or viewed for use in connection with "specified sexual activities" as defined herein, or which are sold or marketed primarily for stimulation of human genital organs, in a location wherein persons under the age of 18 may be present. 
( Ord. No. 2016-11, § I, 6-6-2016 ; Ord. No. 2017-11 , § I, 4-17-2017) 
Sec. 10-38. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished as provided for in the city Charter and section 1-11 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-39. - Unlawful operation declared nuisance. 
Any adult entertainment establishment operated, conducted or maintained contrary to the provisions of this chapter shall be and the same is hereby declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. The city may, in addition to or in lieu of prosecuting a criminal action hereunder, commence an action or actions, proceeding or proceedings for abatement, removal or enjoinment thereof in the manner provided by law. It may take such other steps and shall apply to such court or courts as may have jurisdiction to grant such relief as will abate or remove such adult entertainment establishment and restrain and enjoin any person from operating, engaging in, conducting or carrying on an adult entertainment establishment contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-40. - Conditions of adult entertainment establishment. 
(a)  Cleaning of licensed premises. All adult entertainment establishments shall be kept in a clean, sanitary condition, and shall be in full compliance with all applicable ordinances and regulations of the city, Tift County, and the State of Georgia. 
(b)  Inspection of licensed premises. The fire marshal and the city building code inspector shall have the authority to regularly inspect adult entertainment establishments, to determine compliance with and enforce all applicable fire, health and other codes of the city and Tift County. 
(c)  Inspection for unsanitary or unsafe conditions. The city police department shall have the authority to inspect any adult entertainment establishment at any time such establishment is occupied by one or more persons, in order to determine compliance with and enforce all provisions of this chapter and other applicable ordinances, regulations and laws. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-41. - Denial, suspension or revocation of license; hearing. 
(a)  Grounds. Any of the following shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of an adult entertainment establishment license, and these constitute the sole permissible reasons for suspension or revocation of an adult entertainment establishment license: 
(1)  The making of any statement on an application for a license issued hereunder which is material and is later found to be false; 
(2)  A violation of any of the following regulations or prohibitions of this chapter by the licensee (individually or through the operation of the licensed premises): sections 10-33, 10-34, 10-36, 10- 37, 10-40, 10-41, or 10-44 of this article, or alternatively a total of at least three or more violations committed by employees of the licensee within any six-month period; 
(3)  With respect to the applicant, operator(s) and owner(s), conviction of or a plea of guilty or nolo contendere or an Alford Plea to any of the crimes which would make such person or adult entertainment establishment ineligible to hold a license under subsection 10-35(c) above. 
(b)  Denial; procedure. Within 30 days of actual receipt of a fully completed application for an adult entertainment establishment license, the governing body shall either approve or deny the application. In no event shall the decision whether to approve or deny the adult entertainment establishment license application be withheld for more than 30 days after actual receipt of a fully completed application. In the event that such an application is held without decision for a period of more than 30 days, however, the license application shall be deemed approved, and expressive conduct may begin immediately thereafter notwithstanding the fact that no license has been issued. The city shall issue an adult entertainment establishment license to an applicant who informs the city, through the city manager, of the fact that an application has been submitted, but no decision has been made thereon for a period of more than 30 days following actual receipt of the fully completed application. Notwithstanding the fact that the license provided by this sentence shall not be a prerequisite to the commencement of business operations contemplated by the application, the city shall issue an adult entertainment establishment license under such circumstances within three business days of actual receipt of written notice by the applicant of such circumstances. In the event that the governing body denies an application for an adult entertainment establishment license, then within five business days following such denial, notice of such denial shall be delivered to the applicant in person or deposited in the United States mail, with sufficient first class postage affixed, properly addressed to the applicant at the address provided for such notices on the application. 
(c)  Suspension or revocation; procedure. Whenever the city manager finds reasonable grounds exist to suspend or revoke a license issued hereunder, the governing body shall schedule a hearing to consider such suspension or revocation and shall, at least 15 days prior to the hearing, notify the licensee of the time and date of the hearing and the proposed action and the grounds therefor. The licensee shall be entitled to present evidence and cross-examine any witnesses at the hearing, with or without legal counsel. The governing body shall make his or her decision within ten days of the hearing and shall notify the licensee in writing within five business days of the decision. 
(d)  Any applicant for an adult license or employee permit, license holder, or permit holder aggrieved by any decision of the governing body, or any decision of the city, or any of its officials, employees or agents pursuant to this chapter, may seek an immediate review of such decision by filing an appropriate pleading in the Superior Court of Tifton County, Georgia initiating a certiorari proceeding within 30 days pursuant to the Official Code of Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-42. - Reserved. 
Sec. 10-43. - Automatic license forfeiture for nonuse. 
Any holder of any license hereunder who shall for a period of 90 consecutive calendar days after the license has been issued cease to operate the business and sale of the product or products authorized shall after the said 90 calendar day period automatically forfeit the license without the necessity of any further action. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-44. - Physical layout of establishment. 
(a)  Layout of adult entertainment establishments providing live entertainment. No adult entertainment establishment as defined in subsections (1), (2), (3), or (4) of the definition of an "adult entertainment establishment" contained in section 10-32 above shall provide any booth, room, cubicle or enclosed space for customers or patrons to go where entertainers or other employees are also permitted to go, excepting only restrooms, and no entertainment shall be conducted or viewed inside any booth, room, cubicle or enclosed space or restroom. All entertainment or other interaction between employees and patrons in such establishments shall only take place in open areas, which are open to view from all other areas of the premises (as defined in section 10-32 above) of such adult entertainment establishments. 
(b)  Layout of other adult entertainment establishments. All adult entertainment establishments other than those defined in subsections (1), (2), (3), and (4) of the definition of "adult entertainment establishment" contained in section 10-32 above, which are permitted to have booths, rooms, cubicles or enclosed spaces shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Access. Each booth, room or cubicle shall be totally accessible to and from aisles and public areas of the establishment, and shall be unobstructed by any curtain, door, lock, or other control-type device or any view-obstructing devices or materials. 
(2)  Construction. Every booth, room or cubicle shall meet the following construction requirements: 
a.  Each booth, room or cubicle shall be separated from adjacent booths, rooms and cubicles and any nonpublic areas by a wall. 
b.  Have at least one side totally open to a public lighted area or aisle so that there is an unobstructed view of anyone occupying the booth from the area in which the cash register for the adult entertainment establishment is located. 
c.  All walls shall be solid and without openings, extended from the floor to a height of not less than six feet and be light colored, nonabsorbent, smooth-textured and easily cleanable. 
d.  The floor must be light colored, nonabsorbent, smooth-textured and easily cleaned. 
e.  The lighting level of each booth, room or cubicle when not in use shall be a minimum of ten foot candles at all times, as measured from the floor. 
(3)  Occupants. Only one individual shall occupy a booth, room or cubicle at any time. No occupant of same shall engage in any type of sexual activity, or cause any bodily discharge while in the booth, room or cubicle. No individual shall damage or deface any portion of the booth, room or cubicle. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-45. - Severability. 
It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and city council of Tifton, Georgia that all sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this chapter are and were, upon their enactment, believed by the mayor and city council of Tifton, Georgia to be fully valid, enforceable and constitutional. It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and city council of Tifton, Georgia that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, that each and every section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter is severable from every other section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase therein. It is hereby further declared to be the intention of the mayor and city council of Tifton, Georgia to the greatest extent allowed by law, that no section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter is mutually dependent upon any other section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter. In the event that any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this chapter shall, for any reason whatsoever, be declared invalid, unconstitutional or otherwise unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, it is the express intent of the mayor and city council of Tifton that such invalidity, unconstitutionality or unenforceability shall, to the greatest extent allowed by law, not render invalid, unconstitutional or otherwise unenforceable any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this chapter, and that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, all remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this chapter shall remain valid, constitutional, enforceable, and of full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 2012-11, § I, 7-2-2012) 
ARTICLE III. - BODY ART ESTABLISHMENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-12, § I, adopted July 2, 2012, deleted the former Art. III, §§ 10-100—10-109, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to tattoo parlors or studios and derived from Ord. No. 2003-021, § I, adopted 10-9-2003. 

Sec. 10-46. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the term: 
Body art. The practice of physical body adornment by permitted establishments and operators utilizing, but not limited to, the following techniques: body piercing, tattooing, and cosmetic tattooing. This definition does not include implants under the skin, tattoo removal, or any other practices that are considered medical procedures by a state medical board. 
Body art establishment. Any place or premise, whether public or private, temporary or permanent in nature or location, where the practices of body art, whether or not for profit are performed. 
Body piercing. Any method of piercing the skin or mucosa, except the entire ear, in order to place any object including, but not limited to, rings, studs, bars, or other forms of jewelry through the skin or mucosa. 
Body piercing establishment. Any place or premise, whether public or private, temporary or permanent in nature or location, where the practices of body piercing, whether or not for profit, are performed.. 
Operator. Any person who controls, operates, manages, conducts, or practices body art activities at a body art establishment and who is responsible for compliance with these regulations, regardless whether actually performing body art procedures or not. The term includes technicians who work under the operator and perform body art procedures. 
Permit. The authorization granted by the county board of health or its duly authorized representative to operate a body art establishment. 
Tattooing. Any method of placing ink or other pigment into or under the skin or mucosa by the aid of needles or any other instruments used to puncture the skin, resulting in permanent coloration of the skin or mucosa. This includes all forms of cosmetic tattooing. It shall be unlawful for any person to tattoo the body of any person within any area within one inch of the nearest part of the eye socket of such person. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-47. - Prohibited practices. 
(a)  No person shall operate a body art establishment or engage in the practice or business of tattooing human skin as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist unless the person has first secured a permit to do so from the county board of health and has complied with all ordinances of the city, including but not limited to its zoning ordinance, and has paid the business occupation tax. 
(b)  No person shall operate a body art establishment or engage in the practice or business of tattooing as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist without following an approved exposure control plans and the rules and regulations promulgated by the department of community health and the county board of health. 
(c)  No tattoo operator or tattoo artist shall tattoo any person while such tattoo operator or tattoo artist is under the influence of alcohol, drugs or other stimulants or depressants, nor shall such tattoo operator or tattoo artist tattoo any person who is a minor (under the age of 18), or who is under the influence of either alcohol, drugs or other stimulants or depressants, or any person of unsound mind. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-48. - Permit from county board of health required; inspection fee; exposure control plan. 
(a)  A condition precedent prior to applying for an occupation tax permit in the city the operator/applicant shall show satisfactory proof that the body art establishment has secured from the county board of health a permit to operate the establishment. 
(b)  The operator/applicant shall be required to submit with his application an annual inspection fee of $75.00, or such fee as shall be set from time to time by the county board of health. Thereafter, such inspection fee shall be due and payable on an annual basis. 
(c)  The operator shall submit and the county board of health shall approve an exposure control plan conforming to the rules and regulations promulgated by the department of community health and the county board of health. 
(d)  The permit shall be valid until suspended or revoked and shall not be transferable with respect to person or location. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-49. - Enforcement; right of entry. 
The county board of health or its designated representative, as well as the city code enforcement officer or his designee, in order to enforce compliance with this article and the rules and regulations adopted hereof (pursuant to this article), may conduct periodic unannounced inspections and shall be able to enter upon and inspect the premises of a body art establishment at any reasonable time and in a reasonable manner. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-50. - Authority of board of health to suspend, revoke or deny permit. 
The county board of health or its designated representative may suspend or revoke permits where the health and safety of the public requires such action. When, in the judgment of such board or its duly authorized agents, it is necessary and proper that such application for a permit be denied or that a permit previously granted be suspended or revoked, the applicant or holder of the permit shall be so notified in writing and shall be afforded an opportunity for hearing pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 31-5-2. In the event that such application is finally denied or such permit finally suspended or revoked, the applicant for or holder of such permit shall be given notice in writing, which notice shall specifically state the reasons why the application or permit has been suspended, revoked or denied. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-51. - Appeal of suspension or revocation of permit. 
Any person substantially affected by any final order of the county board of health denying, suspending, revoking or refusing to renew any permit provided under this article may secure review thereof by appeal to the state department of human resources as provided by O.C.G.A. § 31-5-3. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-52. - Permit issued by the board of health not in lieu of occupation tax permit. 
The permits issued hereunder by the county board of health shall be cumulative and are not in lieu of any license or permit issued by the city to do business in the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-53. - Application for occupation tax permit. 
Any person desiring to operate a body art establishment or desiring to operate as a tattoo operator or tattoo artist shall make application for an occupation tax permit at the tax office of the city. The applicant, in addition to the payment of the business occupation tax as required by this city Code, shall also be charged a background investigation fee of $25.00, or such fee as shall be set from time to time by the city, to defray the cost of application processing. The minimum age of each applicant shall be 18 years of age. Applicants shall furnish two photographs showing a front and side picture of the full face of the applicant, size two inches by two inches. The applicant shall also submit an approved permit as issued by the county board of health pursuant to the provisions of section 10-48 of this article and shall comply with all other requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-54. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in the Charter and the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Sec. 10-55. - Incorporation of state law. 
The provisions of this article are adopted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 31-40-9. All provisions of O.C.G.A., title 31, chapter 40 not inconsistent with the provisions of this article are hereby incorporated by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2012-12, § I, 7-2-2012) 
Secs. 10-56—10-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BILLIARDS AND GAME ROOMS 

Sec. 10-150. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Billiards means any of the several games played on a table surrounded by a ledge of cushions, with balls which are impelled by a cue, and shall include all forms of the game known as carom billiards, pocket billiards, pool, English billiards, and like games. 
Game rooms means commercial establishments offering video games, arcade games, pool, billiards and similar games for pleasure, only, which involve some skill and experience rather than pure chance. 
(Ord. No. 2009-08, § I, 5-4-09) 
Sec. 10-151. - Hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a billiard or game room between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m., or to permit any person to remain in such billiard or game room between such prohibited hours, except regular employees performing necessary labor on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2009-08, § I, 5-4-09) 
Sec. 10-152. - Admission of persons under 18 years of age. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner, operator, or manager of a billiard or game room or any establishment in which billiard tables are located in which beer, wine or alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises to permit any person under the age of 18 years to play billiards in, or for any purpose to enter or remain in such room or establishment past 8:00 p.m. unless the person under 18 is accompanied by a parent or guardian, unless the billiard room or the establishment in which the billiard tables are located derives at least 50 percent of its total gross food and beverage sales from the sale of full course meals prepared, served and consumed upon the premises thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2009-08, § I, 5-4-09) 
Sec. 10-153. - Condition of premises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any billiard or game room to erect or permit any screens, curtains, blinds, partitions or other obstructions to be used to prevent a clear view of the interior at all time from the street adjacent to which it is situated. No partitions forming rooms, stalls or other enclosures shall be permitted. This provision, however, shall not be construed to prohibit the maintenance of washrooms and toilet rooms for proper purposes, or the maintenance of closets for storage purposes exclusively. 
(b)  The premises shall be kept safe, clean, sanitary and well ventilated at all times. 
(Ord. No. 2009-08, § I, 5-4-09) 
Sec. 10-154. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, or for the owner, manager or their agents to suffer or permit any person to engage in any illegal or improper diversion or activity or any use of insulting, profane, indecent, immoral, lewd or obscene language, or any indecent, insulting, tumultuous, lewd or lascivious conduct or behavior, or any gaming or betting or any contest of strength or skill, or any disturbance or breach of the peace, or any fighting or challenging or threatening to fight. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every person owning or managing a billiard or game room in the city, to report to the police of the city each and every person guilty of disorderly conduct in the pool or billiard room immediately after the same comes to the knowledge of such owner or manager. 
(Ord. No. 2009-08, § I, 5-4-09) 
Sec. 10-155. - Gambling. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner, manager or their agent to engage in or permit any person to engage in gambling of any form upon the premises of any billiard or game room. 
(Ord. No. 2009-08, § I, 5-4-09) 
Secs. 10-156—10-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - COIN OPERATED AMUSEMENT MACHINES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2018-08 , adopted April 16, 2018, repealed the former art. V., §§ 10-200—10-213, and enacted a new art. V as set out herein. The former art. V pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2012-14, August 6, 2012. 

Sec. 10-200. - Short title. 
This article shall be known as the "The City of Tifton Coin Operated Amusement Machine Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2018-08 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 10-201. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bona fide coin operated amusement machine shall have the same definition as found in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70. 
Business location means the entire office or area of the business in any one location owned or leased by the same proprietor or proprietors where the lessor or lessors allow the space to be used for business purposes. 
Location owner or location operator means an owner or operator of a business where one or more bona fide coin operated amusement machines are available for commercial use and play by the public, or shall have the same definition as found in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70, should that definition differ. 
Class B machine shall have the same definition as found in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70. 
Operator means any person, individual, firm, company, association, corporation, or other business entity who exhibits, displays, or permits to be exhibited or displayed, in a place of business other than his own, any bona fide coin operated amusement machine in this state, or shall have the same definition as found in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70, should that definition differ. 
Owner means any person, individual, firm, company, association, corporation, or other business entity owning any bona fide coin operated amusement machine in this state or shall have the same definition as found in O.C.G.A. § 50-27-70, should that definition differ. 
(Ord. No. 2018-08 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 10-202. - Prohibition on class B devices. 
Location owners and location operators are prohibited from offering more than nine class B machines at one business location within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2018-08 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 10-203. - Application for occupation tax permit. 
Any person desiring to operate a business which offers to the public any bona fide coin operated amusement machine that rewards the player exclusively as described in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d) shall report in the application for an occupation tax permit that there will be located on the business premises one or more bona fide coin operated amusement machines at the business location and shall provide such further information as required under this article. The minimum age of each applicant shall be 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 2018-08 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 10-204. - License required for operation. 
No person shall be issued a business license from the city until adequate proof has been submitted that the person applying for the occupation business license has obtained from the state revenue commissioner a master license and annual permit fee as required pursuant to the O.C.G.A. § 48-17-2 and O.C.G.A. § 48-17-9. 
(Ord. No. 2018-08 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 10-205. - Designation of agent. 
Each owner or operator of a business location which offers to the public any bona fide coin operated amusement machine that rewards the player exclusively as described in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d) shall name in the application one or more persons as the agent and representative for the corporation or partnership to receive all communications, notices, service of process or other papers or documents on behalf of the corporation or partnership in connection with any matter arising out of or connected with the issuance, holding, suspension, revocation or other action with respect to any such license. The application shall give the mailing address of such person, or persons, with the mailing of any notice to any such person at the address so furnished being sufficient notice to the corporation or partnership. If any such person shall cease to be the agent and representative of such corporation or partnership, another person shall immediately be appointed by the license holder and written notice shall be given the city stating the name and address of such new agent and representative. 
(Ord. No. 2018-08 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 10-206. - Location owner and location operator notice. 
The owner and/or possessor of each bona fide coin operated amusement machine that rewards the player exclusively as described in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d) with a machine located within the jurisdiction of the city is required to inform the location owner and/or location operator of each business location in which one of the machine owner's machines is located of the prohibitions and penalties set out in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f), and (g). 
(Ord. No. 2018-08 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 10-207. - Employee notice. 
The location owner and/or location operator of each business location which offers to the public the use of a bona fide coin operated amusement machines which rewards the player exclusively as described in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d) with a machine located within the jurisdiction of the city is required to inform all employees of that business in which one of the machine is located of the prohibitions and penalties set out in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f), and (g). 
(Ord. No. 2018-08 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 10-208. - License suspension and revocation; penalties. 
(a)  The city may suspend or revoke the license of any location owner or location operator to manufacture, distribute, or sell alcoholic beverages in the city, or any other license granted by the city, as a penalty for the conviction of the location owner or location operator of a violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f), or (g) or for violation of one or more provisions of this article. In addition, any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and may also be punished in accordance with the general penalty section 1-11 of this Code. 
(b)  The city may suspend or revoke the license of any location owner or location operator of any other license granted by the city as a penalty for the conviction of the location owner or location operator of a violation of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(e), (f), or (g). 
(c)  The suspension or revocation of licenses under this section, or other penalties imposed, shall be in accordance with the following guidelines of due process: 
(1)  Upon a preliminary determination by the city manager that a ground or grounds exist for the suspension or revocation of a license pursuant to the provisions of this article, then the city manager shall cause a written citation to be issued to the holder of such license requiring such holder to show cause, if any such holder can, at a hearing before the city council at a time and place specified therein which shall not be less than five days nor more than 30 days from the date of service of the citation, by mail or otherwise, upon such holder as well as written notice of the reasons believed by the city manager to authorize possible suspension or revocation of such license. 
(2)  The hearing provided for in subsection (a) of this section, which need not be a regular meeting of the council, may be continued by announcement at such time and place due to the lack of a quorum of the city council or at the request of the license holder or for good cause shown for a period of not longer than ten days. At such hearing the holder of the license shall have the opportunity to show cause why the license should not be suspended or revoked and shall be entitled to the opportunity to present evidence, to present witnesses, to cross examine witnesses presenting evidence in favor of suspension or revocation, to be represented by an attorney, and to have the proceeding transcribed or recorded at the license holder's expense, all in accordance with such rules and procedures as may be adopted from time to time by the city council relative thereto. 
(3)  Following the conclusion of such hearing the city council shall, at a regular or called meeting thereof within 30 days of the date of such hearing, render its decision regarding whether the license in issue should be suspended or revoked and, if suspended, then the duration of such suspension and the amount of license reinstatement fee which amount shall not be in excess of $250.00, if any, as the city council shall in its sole discretion determine to be appropriate under the circumstances, which license reinstatement fee shall be paid as a condition to reinstatement of the license following suspension. 
(4)  Upon the suspension or revocation of such license then the city manager shall cause the license holder to be notified in writing within ten days of such decision of the nature of such decision and the grounds therefor and thereupon the license shall immediately become suspended or terminated in accordance with such decision and the license holder shall immediately upon receipt of such notice cease and desist from all activity authorized under such license in accordance with such decision and physically surrender such license to the city manager. 
(5)  If the city council determines that grounds do not exist to suspend or terminate such license or decides to not suspend or terminate such license notwithstanding the existence of grounds therefor then the city manager shall promptly notify the license holder thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2018-08 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 10-209. - Grounds for suspension or revocation of license. 
The city council shall be entitled, in its sole discretion, to either suspend or revoke any license upon a finding by the city council, following the hearing prescribed in connection therewith, of the existence of any of the following: 
(1)  Conviction of, or the entering of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere by, the licensee or any of his employees or any person holding an interest in the license for any felony, any law, administrative regulation or ordinance involving alcoholic beverages, gambling or narcotics, or tax laws. 
(2)  Conviction of, or the entering of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere by, the licensee or any of his employees or any person holding an interest in the license for any sex offense when the licensed business is for on-premises consumption. 
(3)  Suspension or revocation of any state license required as a condition for the possession, sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages. 
(4)  Material falsification of any fact given in an application for a license issued under this chapter or bearing upon the licensee's qualification therefor. Any act which may be construed as a subterfuge in an effort to circumvent any of the qualifications for a license under this chapter shall be deemed a violation of the requirement attempted to be circumvented. 
(5)  Failure to meet or maintain any standard prescribed by this article as a condition or qualification for holding a license. 
(6)  Any other factor known to or discovered by the city whereby it is objectively shown the licensee, any of the licensee's employees or any person holding an interest in a license, has engaged in conduct at or involving the licensed business or has permitted conduct on the licensed premises that constitutes a violation of federal or state law, local ordinance or administrative regulations involving alcoholic beverages, gambling or narcotics for all alcohol licensed businesses and including any sex offense under state law or local ordinances with respect to businesses licensed for on-premises consumption. With respect to this section, it shall be rebuttably presumed that the violative act was done with the knowledge or consent of the licensee; provided, however, that such presumption may be rebutted only by evidence which precludes every other reasonable hypothesis save that such licensee did not know, assist or aid in such occurrence, or in the exercise of full diligence that such licensee could not have discovered or prevented such activity. 
(Ord. No. 2018-08 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 10-210. - Posting of signs. 
Any location owner or location operator with a business location within the city which offers to the public one or more bona fide coin operated amusement machines is hereby required to post prominently a notice, in the vicinity of such coin operated amusement machines, including the following or substantially similar language:
