ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1—22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PAWNSHOPS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-31. - Purposes. 
In the interest of public safety and general welfare, there is determined to be a need for an ordinance to reasonably regulate the pawnshop business in an effort to timely recover stolen property and to minimize the wrongful transfer and sale of stolen property. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(a), 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 22-32. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Pawnbroker means any person engaged in whole or in part in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property on the condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed dealers as a part of or in conjunction with the business activities described in this Code. 
Pledged goods means tangible personal property other than chooses in action, securities or printed evidences of indebtedness, which property is purchased by, deposited with, or otherwise actually delivered into the possession of a pawnbroker in the course of his business. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(b), 6-1-1998) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-33. - Duration of pawn transactions. 
All pawn transactions shall be for 30-day periods but may be extended or continued for additional 30-day periods. In no event shall a pawn transaction be for less than 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(c), 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 22-34. - Duration of purchase transactions. 
It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker to resell any item purchased in the pawn business until ten business days have elapsed following the date of purchase. The reason for this mandatory waiting period is to allow the police department opportunity to inspect and recover items presented by sellers as owned but which are in fact stolen. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(c), 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 22-35. - Dealing with minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker and/or any clerk, agent, or employee of such pawnbroker to receive in pawn, trade, or to buy from minors any pledged or purchased goods. The term "minor," for the purpose of this section, means any individual who has not yet reached the age of 18 years. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(c), 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 22-36. - Inspection of inventory. 
In addition to the right of duly authorized law enforcement officers to inspect the permanent record book at times and places as set forth in this article, duly authorized law enforcement officers shall also have the right to inspect the inventory of the pawnbroker's business during the ordinary hours of business or at any reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(c), 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 22-37. - Daily reports to police department. 
In addition to the right of inspection of the permanent record book by authorized law enforcement officers as set forth in this article, each pawnbroker shall also be required to turn in to the police department a legible report typed or written in ink (or in the alternative, a computer disc compatible with the police department's computer system) once per day following every day that the pawnbroker is open for business. Failure to timely report or failure to report legibly will subject the offending pawnbroker to the following range of disciplinary actions: written warning for the first and second offenses; prosecution in the municipal court with a fine not to exceed $500.00 for the third and fourth offenses; recommendation to city council that license to operate business be suspended or revoked for fifth and successive offenses. Each such offense will be removed from the pawnbroker's record of offenses maintained at the police department on the second anniversary of such offense; therefore, disciplinary action will be taken based upon the number of offenses that have occurred within the past two years. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(c), 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 22-38. - Operation with other businesses. 
The business license issued for a specific location where the business of pawnbrokering occurs shall be limited solely to such pawnbroker business. There shall not be issued for the same location a separate and independent business license to conduct any other type of buying, selling or swapping of merchandise. This is made necessary in the best interest of the safety and welfare of the public so as to minimize the possibility of commingling or transferring of stolen property in and through a separate business operation at the same location. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(c), 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 22-39. - Prohibited acts. 
It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker and any clerk, agent or employee of such pawnbroker to: 
(1)  Fail to make an entry of any material matter in his permanent record book. 
(2)  Make any false entry in his permanent record book. 
(3)  Falsify, obliterate, destroy, or remove from his place of business such permanent record book. 
(4)  Refuse to allow any duly authorized law enforcement officer to inspect his permanent record book or any goods in his possession during the ordinary hours of business or any reasonable time. 
(5)  Fail to maintain a record of each pawn or purchase transaction for at least four years. 
(6)  Fail to report to the police department on the daily report any item that is or later proves to be stolen will be charged with theft by receiving stolen property. The license to operate the pawn business of such pawnbroker will be reviewed by city council for possible suspension or revocation. 
(7)  Fail to report to the police department on the daily report any item that is not stolen. The license to operate the pawn business will be reviewed by city council for possible suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(c), 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 22-40. - Exception for motor vehicle titles. 
This section shall likewise apply to transactions involving pawning of motor vehicle titles except for the requirement of daily reporting to the police department. The reason for this exception, in line with the purpose of this section, is that the state issues a certificate of title on each motor vehicle which dramatically reduces the ability to transfer title to stolen vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(c), 6-1-1998) 
Secs. 22-41—22-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMANENT RECORDS 

Sec. 22-56. - Required, content. 
Every pawnbroker shall maintain a permanent record in which shall be entered in legible English at the time of each loan, purchase, or sale: 
(1)  The date of the transaction; 
(2)  The name of the person conducting the transaction; 
(3)  The name, age, and address of the customer; a description of the general appearance of the customer; and, the distinctive number from the customer's driver's license or other similar identification card; 
(4)  An identification and description of the pledged or purchased goods, including, if reasonably available, the serial, model, or other number, and all identifying marks inscribed thereon (without limiting the generality of the provisions of this subsection, with regard to jewelry it shall be the duty of the pawnbroker to identify each jewelry item by brand, type, length, size, or any other identifying phrase appropriate to that item and shall not use in such report the phrase "scrap jewelry"); 
(5)  The number of the receipt or pawn ticket; 
(6)  The price paid or the amount loaned; 
(7)  If payment is made by check, the number of the check issued for the purchase price or loan; 
(8)  The maturity date of the transaction; and 
(9)  The signature of the customer. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(c), 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 22-57. - Format. 
The permanent records required to be kept by each pawnbroker can be typed or handwritten if such is legible or, in the alternative, can be entered on a computer disc compatible with the computer system used by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(c), 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 22-58. - Manner of recording entry; correction; inspection. 
The permanent records required by this division shall be maintained in a permanent record book or in a permanent set of computer discs so long as there is a backup system. Entries shall appear in ink and shall be in chronological order. No blank lines may be left between entries. No obliterations, alternations, or erasures may be made. Corrections shall be made by drawing a line of ink through the entry without destroying its legibility. The permanent record book shall be open to the inspection of any duly authorized law enforcement officer of the city during the ordinary hours of business or at any reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(c), 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 22-59. - Maintenance. 
The record of each pawn or purchase transaction provided for in this section shall be maintained for a period of not less than four years. 
(Ord. No. 98-20, § 16-34(c), 6-1-1998) 
Secs. 22-60—22-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - USED MERCHANDISE 

Sec. 22-81. - Applicability. 
This article shall be applicable to all stores, swap shops, pawn shops, and businesses dealing, buying, selling, swapping, and any form of pawning of used merchandise, furniture, machinery, appliances, utensils or firearms, whether such sales, trades, purchases and swaps are retail, wholesale, or by any pawning. Specifically excluded are businesses dealing in buying or selling new merchandise. Isolated transactions between persons not engaged in business are not covered by the terms of this section. 
(Code 1974, § 16-34(a), (c)) 
Sec. 22-82. - Activity declared in public interest. 
Engaging in the business of buying, selling, swapping, or pawning used merchandise, furniture, machinery, appliances, utensils or firearms within the corporate limits of the city is hereby declared to be affected with the public interest due to the opportunity it affords for the disposal of stolen property. 
(Code 1974, § 16-34(b)) 
Sec. 22-83. - Dealing with minors prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any business to receive in pawn, trade or to buy from minors used merchandise, furniture, machinery, appliances, utensils or firearms. A minor for the purpose of this section is any individual who has not reached the age of 18 years. 
(Code 1974, § 16-34(d)) 
Sec. 22-84. - Reports of purchases. 
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any business covered by this section to buy, receive in pawn or receive in a swap any used merchandise, furniture, machinery, appliances, utensils or firearms without complying with the following regulations: 
(1)  At the time of the sale, pawn or swap there shall be obtained from the seller, on a written form which the seller must sign, the following information: seller's name, residence address, date of birth, place of employment and identification of the item sold which will include the kind, serial number and manufacturer of the item. 
(2)  The information set out in subsection (1) of this section shall be placed upon a written form which the seller shall sign, and this shall be made in duplicate. On this form and below the signature of the seller the name of the business and the location shall be shown along with the date and hour of the transaction and following this, the manager or person in charge of the business shall sign his name. 
(3)  The forms set forth in subsection (2) of this section shall be provided by the police department of the city to the business. The original signed form showing the information called for shall be delivered by the business to the police department on the following day after the transaction is completed, such delivery to be made by hand or by placing the original in the United States mail addressed to the police department with adequate postage thereon. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person, business, association, partnership or corporation, pawn shop or firm required by subsection (1) of this section to fail to obtain the information required in subsection (1) or fail to provide such information to the police department as required by subsection (3) of this section. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person selling, pawning or swapping as set forth in subsection (1) of this section to give false information to the seller or to answer falsely any of the information required in subsection (1). 
(Code 1974, § 16-34(e)) 
Sec. 22-85. - Penalties. 
Any violation of this section shall be construed as an offense against the city and shall be punished as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. Any business who shall be convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be subject to having its business license suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1974, § 16-34(f)) 
Secs. 22-86—22-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BUYERS OF PRECIOUS METALS 

Sec. 22-141. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Gold or silver buyer means any person engaged in the business of purchasing or otherwise dealing in gold or silver or other precious metals of any kind or description, from members of the general public within the corporate limits of the city. Included in this definition are buyers of secondhand jewelry and gems. Isolated transactions between persons not engaged in the business are not covered by the terms of this article. 
Fixed place of business means an office or other fixed facility, that is, a place, site, structure, or other similar facility, used exclusively for business, including, but not limited to administrative or management activities, on a regular and continuing basis through which an individual or business entity engages in a trade or business for which an occupational license is currently issued. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-142. - Legislative findings. 
Engaging in the business of buying gold, silver, other precious metals; precious gems; or jewelry within the corporate limits of the city is hereby declared to be affected with the public interest because of the opportunity it affords for the disposal of stolen property. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-143. - Compliance with article required. 
It is hereby declared to be unlawful, and an offense punishable as provided in section 1-11 of this Code, to engage in the business of buying precious metals, precious gems or jewelry from members of the general public within the corporate limits of the city without first complying with the registration and other provisions of this article and obtaining a license as herein provided. Each day such offense occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-144. - Advertising. 
No person, partnership, corporation or other entity covered by this article shall advertise, either in the news media, or portable signs, or in any other manner, the buying, selling or trading of, or otherwise dealing in, precious metals, precious gems or jewelry until they have complied with the provisions of this article. The violation of this section shall be unlawful and an offense punishable as provided in section 1-11 of this Code, and each day such violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-145. - Registration. 
(a)  Required. All persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities engaging in the business of buying precious metals, precious gems or jewelry shall register with the chief of police on a form to be provided by the chief of police. 
(b)  Information. All applicants for registration under the provisions of this article shall furnish, in addition to such other information as the chief of police shall require, the following information: 
(1)  Name of the applicant. 
(2)  Permanent address and local address of the applicant. 
(3)  If the applicant is a partnership, the name and address of each member of the partnership. 
(4)  If the applicant is a corporation, the name and address of each stockholder, each officer and each director of the corporation. 
(5)  The name and address of each employee of the applicant who is actively engaged in the performance of such services. 
(6)  If a resident, the length of time the applicant has been a resident of the state and the city. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-146. - Effect of criminal conviction. 
No person shall engage in the business or activity for which the license is required under this article, or shall be a member of a partnership, or an officer, stockholder or director in a corporation engaged in such business who shall have been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-147. - Bond required. 
Every person, partnership, corporation or other entity engaging in the business of buying precious metals, precious gems or jewelry shall file with the chief of police for the city a surety bond executed by such applicant secured by a corporate surety company, authorized to do business in the state, in an amount not less than $10,000.00 conditioned upon compliance with the provisions of this article, and upon the prompt report of all suspicious persons dealing with the obligor, and of stolen property or property suspected of being stolen, and for the returning to the chief of police or to the true and lawful owner of any such property or making payment therefor. The bond shall be taken in the name of the city, and the city or any person injured by the breach of said bond may bring an action on said bond in its or his own name to recover damages therefor. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-148. - Investigation of applicant. 
Within five days after receipt of an application as provided for herein, the chief of police shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant and his proposed operation. If upon investigation the chief of police shall find that the applicant has never been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, and has met all of the requirements of this article, he shall approve the issuance of a license to the applicant. The license shall be issued by the city, and the occupation tax provided by the occupation tax ordinance shall be paid. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-149. - Notice to law enforcement officials. 
If the license required by the provisions of this article is approved, the applicant shall file a notice with all law enforcement agencies of the county and city within 15 days after approval. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-150. - Register. 
Every licensee under this article shall keep a register upon which the licensee shall record the name, address, Social Security number or drivers license number, a brief description of the person, and other identification, of every person from whom the licensee purchases any precious metals, precious gems or jewelry, together with the date and time of day of said purchase; a description of each article purchased, including the name, make and serial or other identifying number or mark; and the amount paid therefor. Such entry shall be made at the time the transaction occurs. Before buying any precious metals, precious gems or jewelry, the licensee shall require positive identification from the seller, either from a driver's license or other document. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-151. - Reports to police. 
Each licensee under this article shall file daily written reports with the chief of police, showing the name and description of the persons from whom precious metals, precious gems or jewelry were purchased by the licensee during the preceding 24 hours, and a description in detail of the nature, type and quantity of the precious metals, precious gems or jewelry. It is hereby made the duty of the chief of police to obtain such reports promptly each day. It shall be unlawful and an offense punishable as provided in section 1-11 of this Code of the city for any licensee to fail or refuse to make such daily report in the manner described by this section, and such failure shall be a ground for the revocation of the license. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-152. - Elapsed time before disposal. 
No articles of personal property made of gold, silver or other precious metals or precious gems or jewelry shall be sold, melted, altered or otherwise disposed of by any secondhand dealer until ten days have elapsed from the time the chief of police has been given a copy or transcript of the register in which such articles of personal property made of gold, silver, platinum or other precious metals or gems or jewelry are entered, and said articles shall not be transferred from within the city limits during said ten-day period of time. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-153. - Licenses nontransferable. 
Licenses issued under this article shall not be transferred. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-154. - Disposition of stolen items. 
In the event it is determined that any item covered by this article is the subject of any theft, embezzlement or other crime, the licensee shall surrender same upon demand to the owner or the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-155. - Purchasing from minors prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful and punishable as provided in section 1-11 of this Code for any person, partnership, corporation or other entity engaged in the business of buying precious metals, precious gems or jewelry to purchase any of said items from a person less than 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-156. - Revocation of license. 
Licenses issued pursuant to this article shall be subject to revocation or suspension by the city manager upon recommendation of the chief of police for the violation of or the failure to comply with any provision of this article or for the violation of any provision of law, after reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard has been given the licensee. The city manager shall immediately notify any licensee of such suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-157. - Location restrictions. 
Every gold or silver buyer shall have at least one fixed place of business within the corporate limits of the city and all items stored pursuant to section 22-152 shall be stored at said fixed place of business. A gold or silver buyer may temporarily operate at a location other than their fixed place of business so long as the temporary location is properly zoned and the owner, occupier, or other person or entity entitled to the use of the location and the gold or silver buyer are licensed pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
Sec. 22-158. - Accurate weight scales. 
Every gold or silver buyer that purchases by weight shall utilize for such purchases a weight scale certified as accurate by the weights and measures section of the office of the commissioner of the state department of agriculture or other appropriate governmental entity. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § I, 7-12-2010) 
ARTICLE V. - PEDDLERS AND TRANSIENT MERCHANTS 

Sec. 22-160. - Findings and intent. 
The intent of the city council in enacting this article is to regulate the sale of goods and services by soliciting at residences in the city, to the end that criminal activity in the city and abusive techniques utilized by any such solicitors which adversely affect the public health, safety and welfare in the city will be curtailed. This article is not intended as a de facto prohibition of door-to-door solicitation, nor is it an attempt to adversely affect interstate commerce. Instead, this article is intended to balance competing interest, reduce criminal activity and protect city residents from abusive sales techniques versus the conduct of proper commercial sales activity. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-161. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Canvasser, peddler, or solicitor means any person who sells or solicits for sale in the city any new or used goods, wares, merchandise, services or other things of value and goes about from place to place within the city selling or offering for sale any of such things to either merchants or customers shall be deemed a peddler or solicitor. Excluded from this definition are persons who sell or solicit for sale goods, wares or merchandise, or other things of value from house to house for charitable organizations or purposes or on behalf of religious organizations, political organizations and political candidates. 
Charitable organization means any benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary (of, relating to, or supported by charity or alms) corporation, partnership, limited liability company, association, joint-stock company, trust, governmental agency or entity, unincorporated organization or individual who solicits or obtains contributions solicited from, or conducts the sale of merchandise to, the general public, which contributions are used for charitable purposes or governmental purposes. 
Charitable purpose means any charitable, benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary purpose for religion, health, education, social welfare, arts and humanities, environment, civic or public interest. 
Door-to-door salesperson means any person who shall solicit orders on behalf of a firm, corporation, company, association, partnership or individual of any goods, wares or merchandise, or other things of value from house to house shall be deemed a door-to-door salesperson. Any person who obtains orders for merchandise or other things of value shall be deemed a door-to-door salesperson. Excluded from this definition are persons who solicit orders for goods, wares or merchandise, or other things of value from house to house for charitable organizations or purposes or on behalf of religious organizations, political organizations and political candidates. 
Transient merchant means any person, firm, or corporation, as principal or agent, or both, which is not a regular retail or wholesale merchant with a permanent place of business in Tift County, Georgia, but rather one who displays samples, model goods, wares, or merchandise in any lot, building, room, or structure of any kind, whether fixed or mobile, for the purpose of securing orders for the retail sale of such items or items of like kind or quality for immediate or future delivery. The term "transient merchant" shall not include any person, firm, or corporation which: 
(1)  Sells agriculture or forestry products; 
(2)  Makes house-to-house or personal calls for the purpose of displaying samples or taking orders for shipment directly from a manufacturer; 
(3)  Conducts business at any industry or association trade show; or 
(4)  Sells items at a rummage, garage, antique, or similar sale when such person, firm, or corporation is a resident of this state or has a permanent place of business within this state and such sale is not part of the regular business activity of such person, firm, or corporation or when the net proceeds of such sale are to be used for charitable purposes. 
Vehicle means motorized conveyance fully functioning and moving under its own power. A vehicle shall include a trailer or anything pulled by the vehicle. Vehicles shall not be in excess of 20 feet in length, ten feet in width, and eight feet in height. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-162. - License required; application. 
(a)  All persons, firms, companies, corporations or other entities engaging or offering to engage in business as a canvasser, solicitor, peddler or transient merchant shall file an application in the required form, and obtain a solicitor's license for such activity from the city clerk. 
(b)  The application shall include, but not be limited to, the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number; 
(2)  Date of birth; 
(3)  Social Security number; 
(4)  Copy of photo identification; 
(5)  Name, address and telephone number of the applicant's employer; 
(6)  Name, address and telephone number of the applicant's supervisor; 
(7)  Brief description of products or services to be sold; 
(8)  Location(s) where the goods, merchandise or other property will be offered for sale; 
(9)  Description of motor vehicles to be used by the applicant in conducting the solicitation; and 
(10)  Criminal history. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-163. - Investigation. 
(a)  A review of criminal history records is required prior to the issuance of a solicitor's license. In addition to a review of criminal history, the applicant must provide the following items: 
(1)  Two forms of positive identification (only official United States Government issued pictured identification accepted; e.g., a valid driver's license, military ID card or valid state ID car). 
(2)  Fingerprints may be required on occasion for positive identification. 
(b)  The city shall make an investigation, including, but not limited to, an investigation of the police record and moral character of the applicant. The city clerk shall furnish the application to the police chief. The police chief shall furnish a report to the city clerk of the criminal history record, if any, of the applicant. 
(c)  The criminal history record shall be used for investigative purposes only, and shall give rise to no presumption or inference of guilt. Due to the inclusion of criminal history records, these applications shall be regarded as confidential and shall not be produced for public inspection without a court order. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-164. - Disqualification. 
(a)  No solicitor's license shall be issued to any applicant who provides any false or misleading information in connection with the application for the license required by this article. 
(b)  No solicitor's license shall be granted to any person under the age of 18 or who has been convicted, pled guilty or entered a plea of nolo contendere under any federal, state or local law of any crime involving moral turpitude, illegal gambling, any felony, criminal trespass, public indecency, misdemeanor involving any type of sexual related crime, any theft or violence against person or property, any crime of possession or sale, or distribution of illegal drugs, distribution of material depicting nudity or sexual conduct as defined under state law, criminal solicitation to commit any of these listed offenses, or attempts to commit any of these listed offenses, for a period of ten years prior to the date of application for such license and has been released from parole or probation. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-165. - Denial. 
(a)  If, as a result of the investigation authorized by this article, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the police chief shall endorse on such application his disapproval and the reasons for such disapproval, and return the application to the city clerk who will notify the applicant that the application is disapproved and that no license will be issued. 
(b)  No application for a solicitor's license shall be received or acted upon if the applicant has submitted the same or similar application for a solicitor's license within the preceding 12 months which was denied. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-166. - Approval; issuance. 
If, as a result of the investigation authorized by this article, the applicant's character and business responsibility are found to be satisfactory, the police chief shall endorse on such application his approval and reasons for such approval, and return the application to the city clerk, who shall, upon payment of regulatory fees as established by resolution of the city council, issue a solicitor's license. A solicitor's license shall contain the name, address, physical description and organizational affiliation of the licensee; a description of the solicitation activity to be engaged in; an expiration date; and the signature and seal of the city clerk. The city clerk shall keep a record of all solicitors' licenses issued. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-167. - Duration; required fees prescribed. 
A solicitor's license shall be issued for up to one month in duration upon payment of the following fees: each registrant shall pay to the city clerk an administration fee of $75.00 together with a registration fee as follows: 
(1)  One-day license ..... $11.00 
(2)  One-week license ..... $22.00 
(3)  One-month license ..... $55.00 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-168. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The license issued to any solicitor charged with any felony, criminal trespass, public indecency, misdemeanor involving any type of sex crime, theft or violence against person or property, criminal solicitation to commit any of these offenses, or violation of this or any other city ordinance shall be deemed suspended and subject to seizure from the time of lawful arrest by the police department. Such suspension shall remain in effect until the solicitor is convicted or acquitted, or until the charge is dismissed, "dead-docketed," "nolle prossed," or "no-billed." It shall be the responsibility of the solicitor to present the city clerk with proof that the arrest which lead to the suspension was dismissed, "dead-docketed," "nolle prossed," or "no-billed." Upon representation of proof of such dispositions, the solicitor's license will be reinstated and will be valid until the date of the original expiration. 
(b)  The license of any solicitor who is convicted, has entered a plea of guilty, or has received a nolo contendere to a felony, criminal trespass, public indecency, misdemeanor involving any type of sex crime, theft or violence against person or property, or criminal solicitation to commit any of these offenses, shall be deemed revoked and subject to seizure by the chief of police or his designee from the time of such conviction, guilty or nolo contendere sentencing. 
(c)  The license of any solicitor who is convicted, has entered a plea of guilty or received a nolo contendere sentencing for any violation of this article shall be deemed revoked and subject to seizure by the chief of police or his designee from the time of such conviction, guilty or nolo contendere sentencing. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-169. - Applicability of provisions; exceptions. 
Except for the regulations set forth in section 22-171, nothing in this article shall apply to the following: 
(1)  Officers or employees in the city, county, state or federal governments or the school system, or any subdivisions thereof, when on official business; 
(2)  Any local non-profit organization such as boy scouts, civic clubs, religious, charitable, political, or educational organizations and the like, when the membership of such club or organization does the soliciting itself; but it shall apply when the soliciting is done by a paid solicitor or by a solicitor on contract with an individual with only a percentage or portion of any sales or collections to go to the benefit of such non-profit club or organization. 
(3)  Any person selling only agricultural or forestry products or selling food for immediate consumption; 
(4)  Any person who conducts business at any industry or association trade show; 
(5)  Any person selling items at a rummage, garage, antique or similar sale when such person, firm, corporation or other legal entity is a resident of this state or has a permanent place of business within this state and such sale is not part of the regular business activity of such person, firm, corporation or legal entity or when the net proceeds of such sale are to be used for charitable purposes; 
(6)  Any person selling such items at a city-sponsored festival or event, provided that such person has obtained the necessary approvals from the city and other regulatory agencies to operate at said festival or event. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-170. - Regulations for solicitors and peddlers; operating on public lands or from vehicle. 
(a)  No person shall stand on or adjacent to a street, road, or highway or on rights-of-way within the city limits for the purpose of soliciting employment, business or contributions from the occupant of any vehicle. 
(b)  No person shall locate and/or conduct a business from a mobile vehicle or upon the public sidewalks, streets, alleys, walkways, parks, parking lots, rights-of-way, or other public lands of the city or upon state rights-of-way within the city limits. 
(c)  The provisions of the city's land development code, pertaining to outside displays, shall be applicable to any solicitor, or peddler. 
(d)  No solicitor, peddler, or door-to-door salesperson shall: 
(1)  Call at residences, offices or businesses clearly displaying a sign stating "No Solicitors Or Peddlers Invited," "No Solicitation," or using similar language; 
(2)  Engage in door-to-door soliciting at residences on Sundays or between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m.; 
(3)  Enter any private dwelling without the consent of the owner or occupant, or to remain there after being requested or directed to leave; 
(4)  Fail to register and carry or produce for inspection a permit when required under this chapter; 
(5)  Make any false or deceptive statement on any registration hereunder. 
(e)  A person who is soliciting or selling on behalf of a non-profit organization shall be required to verify the nonprofit status of such organization. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-171. - Exemption of disabled or indigent veterans of armed forces. 
(a)  Scope of exemption. It shall be lawful for any disabled or indigent veteran of the armed forces, such veteran is defined in O.C.G.A. § 43-12-1, to peddle without obtaining a permit for the privilege of so doing, and a certificate from the probate court of the county stating the fact of his being such disabled or indigent veteran shall be sufficient proof thereof; provided, that this section shall not authorize peddling ardent spirits. The privileges hereby granted shall not be transferred to or used by any other person. 
(b)  Effect of exemption. All such persons are authorized to peddle in the city without first obtaining a license therefore from the city and without being subject to any tax therefore. 
(c)  Affidavit required. Before any such person shall avail himself of the privilege conferred by this section, he shall go before the judge of the probate court of the county and make oath in writing that he served as a soldier and that the business which he proposes to carry on (stating what he proposes to peddle) is his own, and that he will not sell or offer to sell any article for another, directly or indirectly. 
(d)  Issuance of certificate. Upon making and filing the affidavit provided for in subsection (a), the judge of the probate court shall issue a certificate stating that such person has taken the oath prescribed, which certificate shall authorize such person making such affidavit and holding such certificate to peddle in the city without procuring a license or being subject to any tax therefore. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-172. - Obstruction of street, highway or sidewalk prohibited. 
No canvasser, solicitor, peddler or transient merchant authorized to engage in any business in the city shall, in carrying on such business, obstruct the whole or any part of any sidewalk, street or highway of the city, and any such person peddling in the city or using the streets or sidewalks in the city for the purpose of selling or offering for sale any goods, wares, medicines or merchandise of any kind, shall continually move from place to place in the city, and shall not in the conduct or carrying on of such business obstruct the whole or any part of any sidewalk, street, or highway in the city. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-173. - Unlawful or prohibited activities. 
The following are prohibited practices for solicitors and any violation shall constitute grounds for suspension, revocation or denial of renewal of license, and/or arrest: 
(1)  Solicit on Sunday, or between the hours 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. Monday through Saturday. 
(2)  Solicit at any location where a sign is posted at or near the main entrance or driveway to the residence or business prohibiting such activity. 
(3)  Using any entrance, or part of the building, other than the main entrance to the residence or business. 
(4)  Entering a residence except at the express invitation of the occupant. 
(5)  Failure of the solicitor to inform the occupant in plain terms of the solicitor's identity and the purpose of the call. 
(6)  Making more than one solicitation call at the same location within any consecutive 14-day period, unless invited back by the occupant. 
(7)  The solicitor to represent that they are participating in any contest, game or other competitive endeavor, or that they are offering the occupant an opportunity to participate in any such contest, game or endeavor. 
(8)  The solicitor to use vulgar, insulting or threatening language in the course of any solicitation. 
(9)  The solicitor to remain upon the property of the residence or business after the occupant has verbally indicated that they do not wish to make a purchase. For the purpose of this article, a solicitation shall be deemed to continue until the solicitor has left the property of the residence or business. 
(10)  Soliciting anyone under the age of 18 years. 
(11)  Failure of solicitor to have a valid license or refuse any person's request to examine same. 
(12)  For more than two solicitors to engage in solicitation upon any residence or business at the same time for the same goods or services. 
(13)  Solicitor to violate any of the provisions of this article, or to violate any other city ordinance while engaging in any solicitation activity. 
(14)  Solicitor to lend, rent or sell their license to another, or to solicit using the license of another. 
(15)  Solicitor to alter or deface their license or the license of another. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Sec. 22-174. - Violations; enforcement. 
Any violations of the provisions in this chapter shall subject the license or permit to revocation. In addition, any person violating this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. The provisions of this chapter may be enforced by the city police department or the city code enforcement staff. 
( Ord. No. 2014-20, § I , 9-8-2014) 
Secs. 22-175—22-180. - Reserved. 
Chapter 26 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 
State Law reference— Georgia Cemetery and Funeral Services Act of 2000, O.C.G.A. § 10-14-1 et seq.; disposition of unclaimed dead bodies, O.C.G.A. § 31-21-21 et seq.; abandoned cemeteries and burial grounds, O.C.G.A. § 36-72-1 et seq.; criminal trespass and damage to property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-20. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 26-1—26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OAKRIDGE CEMETERY 

Sec. 26-31. - Purpose, applicability. 
For the mutual protection of every lot purchaser in the Oakridge Cemetery, this article is hereby adopted as the rules and regulations of the Oakridge Cemetery, and all property owners and visitors within the cemetery and all lots hereafter to be sold in the cemetery, shall be subject to the rules and regulations formulated and adopted by the city manager and council and set forth in this article; and subject, further, to such other additional rules and regulations, amendments or alterations as shall be adopted by the city for Oakridge Cemetery, being a public cemetery, owned and operated by the city; and reference to such rules and regulations in instruments and deeds conveying the ownership of lots and the right of interment, shall have the same force and effect as if the rules and regulations in such instruments and deeds were set forth therein. 
(Code 1974, § 6-16) 
Sec. 26-32. - Plat of lots. 
The location of any lots in the cemetery may be found by reference to a plat on file in the office of the city manager. 
(Code 1974, § 6-17) 
Sec. 26-33. - Sale of lots. 
Upon the sale of a lot, before the lot is used, it must first be offered to the city; if the city refuses such lot, it may be sold to an individual. 
(Code 1974, § 6-18) 
Sec. 26-34. - Price of lots. 
The price of cemetery lots in Oakridge Cemetery which shall be sold by the city shall be as set forth in the schedule of rates and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the city shall donate a cemetery lot in which to bury any stillborn child or infant child whenever the mortician certifies to the city that his services have also been donated free of charge. 
(Code 1974, § 6-18.1) 
Sec. 26-35. - City not responsible for damages. 
The city shall not be liable and distinctly disclaims all responsibility for the loss or damage to property or rights of lot owners arising from causes beyond its control, and especially from damages caused by the elements, acts of God, common enemies, thieves, vandals, malicious mischiefmakers, explosions, unavoidable accidents, invasions, insurrections, riots or order of any military or civil authority, whether the damage is direct or collateral. 
(Code 1974, § 6-19) 
Sec. 26-36. - Damage to raised structures and fixtures. 
While the city will exercise all possible care to protect raised lettering, carving or ornaments on any memorial or other structure on any lot, it disclaims any responsibility and shall not be liable for any damage or injury thereto. 
(Code 1974, § 6-20) 
Sec. 26-37. - Order or request prerequisite to grave opening. 
An order or request, in writing, is required of the lot owner or authorized funeral director before a grave is to be opened, giving the name, age, sex, date of death and location of grave in reference to the lot. 
(Code 1974, § 6-21) 
Sec. 26-38. - Who may do maintenance and improvement. 
All grading, landscape work and improvements of any kind, and care of the lots, and all trees and shrubs moved and herbage of any kind, with the exception of planting grass, shall be planted, trimmed, cut or removed, only by the city. The planting of grasses on the lot shall be left to the lot owner as to the type of grass to be planted, the grass shall be planted at cost to the lot owner. Permanent planting of shrubs, flowers, etc., shall be made by the city and further planting may be permitted only at the discretion of the city. The whole cemetery is to be landscaped, and to keep it uniform it is necessary that all plantings shall be under the control of the city, including the following additional care: 
(1)  Removal of rubbish when necessary, raking and cutting of grass, trimming of trees and shrubbery and other care that the city may deem necessary. 
(2)  The ownership of rights of interment in lots does not convey any right to do planting or other improving without the express approval of the proper officials of the city. 
(3)  The city retains control and supervision of all lots that are sold and the city retains the right to enter upon any lot and prohibit, modify or remove any structure, object or improvement on such lot, which has been placed thereon, subsequent to the adoption of these rules and regulations and which may be considered objectionable or injurious to the lot, adjoining lots or the cemetery in general. 
(Code 1974, § 6-22) 
Sec. 26-39. - Right to regulate sprinkling and drainage. 
The right to lay, maintain, operate or alter, or change pipelines and gutters for sprinkling systems, drainage, etc., is also expressly reserved to the city, as well as its right to use such land for cemetery purposes. 
(Code 1974, § 6-23) 
Sec. 26-40. - Removal of cut flowers, potted plants. 
The city reserves the right to remove all cut flowers and potted plants that may be dead or otherwise objectionable. 
(Code 1974, § 6-24) 
Sec. 26-41. - Gathering plants, disturbing wildlife. 
All persons are prohibited from gathering flowers, either wild or cultivated, or breaking trees, shrubbery or plants or disturbing birds or other wildlife in the cemetery. 
(Code 1974, § 6-25) 
Sec. 26-42. - Signs, notices, advertisements. 
No signs, notices or advertisements of any kind shall be allowed in the cemetery unless placed by the city. 
(Code 1974, § 6-26) 
Cross reference— Sign regulations, app. A, § 10-1 et seq. 
Sec. 26-43. - Markers. 
No memorial, such as family marker, grave marker, slab or corner post, shall be placed in the cemetery, either on the grave or lot, unless the memorial or marker is made of marble, granite or bronze. Corner posts or nameplates shall be placed flush with the finished grade of the surrounding ground. 
(Code 1974, § 6-27) 
Sec. 26-44. - Depth of vaults and containers. 
The top of any vault or container holding a body shall be placed at least 12 inches below the finished grade of the surrounding ground. 
(Code 1974, § 6-28) 
Sec. 26-45. - Lot enclosures. 
(a)  No coping, curbing, fencing, hedging, grave mounds, borders or enclosures of any kind shall be allowed around any lot except in accordance with all of the following rules: 
(1)  Coping must be a minimum four inches wide and six inches high; 
(2)  Soil must be treated with weed sterilant; 
(3)  Coping joints must be flush; 
(4)  When butting up to existing coping, joints will be ground to make joints flush; 
(5)  Coping will be anchored at least every five feet, not to exceed natural ground; 
(6)  Inside coping will be a minimum of two inches concrete and a minimum of two inches loose gravel; 
(7)  Disturbed area around outside of coping will be dressed out with top soil; 
(8)  All work and material shall be at the expense of the lot owner; and 
(9)  Notification shall be required to the city park and cemetery department prior to proceeding. 
(b)  No loose gravel shall be allowed on any lot. The city reserves the right to remove such gravel if so placed, other than gravel placed inside coped areas. 
(c)  All gravesites must be marked within 90 days of burial with markers made of either bronze, granite or marble. 
(Code 1974, § 6-29; Ord. No. 99-26, § I, 9-13-1999) 
Sec. 26-46. - Prior approval required to be in cemetery during certain hours; penalty. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be in Oakridge Cemetery one hour after sunset until one hour before sunrise without prior approval of the caretaker or chief of police. 
(Code 1974, § 6-30) 
Chapter 30 - COURT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 46; public safety, ch. 58; traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 78. 
State Law reference— Establishment of municipal courts authorized and jurisdiction thereof, Ga. Const. art. VI, § I, ¶ I; municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq. 

Sec. 30-1. - Arrest of offenders; release on bond. 
It shall be the duty of the police of the city, for any violation of any ordinance of the city, to arrest the person so offending and hold him in custody until a trial is had in the manner prescribed for the trial of offenders; provided, any such person may be discharged from arrest upon giving to the chief of police a bond with good security for his appearance before the municipal court, to abide the action of the court in the premises, in such sum as will likely compel the appearance of the accused. 
(Code 1974, § 21-1) 
Sec. 30-2. - Incarceration if bond not posted. 
If any party, whether defendant or witness, fails to give the bond and security, or bond, as required of him, such person may be confined in the city jail so as to be present to abide the trial or to testify. 
(Code 1974, § 21-2) 
Sec. 30-3. - Forfeiture of bond; issuance of rule to show cause. 
Upon failure of any principal in any bond or recognizance given by a person charged with a violation of any ordinance of the city to appear, or by a witness to appear and testify, the municipal judge shall forfeit such bond or recognizance in the manner practiced in the superior courts of this state, and shall pass a rule requiring the principal and securities on such bond to show cause, on any day therein named, not to be less than 20 days from the passage of such rule, why they should not pay the amount of such bond. 
(Code 1974, § 21-3) 
Sec. 30-4. - Service of rule to show cause on forfeiture. 
A copy of the rule provided for in section 30-3 shall be served upon the principal and security or securities, if found to be in the city, by any officer or member of the police force, at least 20 days before the time set therein for the hearing of the rule. 
(Code 1974, § 21-4) 
Sec. 30-5. - Judgment of forfeiture; satisfaction thereof. 
If no sufficient cause is shown, the municipal judge shall proceed to enter judgment against the principal and securities for the amount of the bond, and the clerk shall issue an execution for the amount of such judgment and place the execution of judgment in the hands of the chief of police, who shall proceed to collect the judgment by levy and sale as in the case of tax execution. The hearing may be continued to perfect service or for any other good cause. If either of the parties liable on such bond is not found to be in the city and an entry is made to that effect on the rule, judgment may be entered against those served. 
(Code 1974, § 21-5) 
Sec. 30-6. - Surrender of principal by surety. 
Any surety on a bail bond of any person charged with the violation of a city ordinance may surrender his principal at any time to the chief of police or officer on duty at the station or jail, who shall confine such principal until discharged by order of the court or by giving other or good security. The delivery of the principal shall discharge the securities or security of all further liability upon such bond; provided, such delivery shall be made before any judgment of forfeiture upon such bond shall have been entered; and, provided, all costs, which may have accrued in any proceeding to forfeit such bond, are paid. 
(Code 1974, § 21-6) 
Sec. 30-7. - Procedures in court generally. 
Upon the appearance of the accused, the municipal judge shall try the case under the same rules of practice and evidence as govern the superior courts of the state, and after an impartial hearing, shall make such order or disposition of the case as the law and facts may justify. Continuance shall not be granted, either to the prosecution or the defense, unless for reasonable grounds. Any part defendant may file a plea of guilty, and if such party cannot attend the trial, the court may pass sentence in his absence, if such defendant consents thereto. 
(Code 1974, § 21-7) 
Sec. 30-8. - Right to process for witnesses; speedy trial required. 
Any person charged with a violation of the city ordinances shall have compulsory process for obtaining witnesses and a speedy trial. 
(Code 1974, § 21-8) 
Sec. 30-9. - Issuance, service of witness subpoenas. 
The municipal judge shall issue subpoenas for all witnesses necessary, either for the prosecution or defense, before the municipal court, and also in cases appealed to the superior court. All subpoenas in behalf of the city shall be served by the chief of police or a police officer. Those in behalf of a defendant may be served by any person who may be authorized to perform such service. 
(Code 1974, § 21-9) 
Sec. 30-10. - Absent witnesses may be cited for contempt; procedure penalty. 
Should any witness, subpoenaed for either the city or defendant, fail to appear at the trial, the court may instruct a rule to be issued directing such witness to appear at such time and place as may be therein set forth, to show cause why he should not be adjudged in contempt. Such rule shall be served by the chief of police, or any of the police officers, at least one day before the hearing. At the hearing the court, if no good excuse shall be shown, may, in its discretion, punish the offender by fine or imprisonment. Should the witness fail to appear in response to the rule, the court shall pass an order directing the witness to be arrested and brought before the court to answer the charge. 
(Code 1974, § 21-10) 
Sec. 30-11. - Issuance, satisfaction of executions for fines and costs. 
Executions shall issue instanter for any fines and costs imposed by the municipal court, which shall be signed by the municipal judge and may be levied on any property of the person fined. 
(Code 1974, § 21-11) 
Chapter 34 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses and business regulations, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— Restrictions on operation, installation, maintenance, etc. of electronic security systems by local governments, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-12; Georgia Emergency Telephone Number 911 Service Act of 1977, O.C.G.A. § 46-5-120 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Use of automatic dialing devices regulated. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person, partnership, corporation or association of persons to have in their possession any device or combination of devices which will automatically dial any telephone number of the police department of the city or any telephone number of the fire department or any telephone number of the city hall. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person, partnership, corporation or association of persons to use, key or activate any device or combination of devices which will automatically dial or deliver a recorded message to any telephone number of the police department of the city or any telephone number of the fire department or any telephone number of the city hall. 
(c)  All automatic dialers shall be keyed to a private service that can then notify the appropriate agency. 
(Code 1974, § 16-33) 
Secs. 34-2—34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ALARM SERVICE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Operation of electronic alarm systems by county or municipality, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-12; license required to engage in low voltage alarm system contracting, O.C.G.A. § 43-14-8.1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 34-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alarm administrator means a person or designee designated by the chief of police to administer, control and review false alarm reduction efforts. 
Alarm registration means the notification by an alarm company or an alarm user to the alarm administrator that an alarm system has been installed and is in use. 
Alarm system means a device or series of devices, including, but not limited to, systems interconnected with a radio frequency method such as cellular or private radio signals, which emit or transmit a remote or local audible, visual or electronic signal indicating an alarm condition and intended to summon the police department, fire department or county emergency medical services, including local alarm system. The term "alarm system" does not include an alarm installed on a vehicle or person unless the vehicle or personal alarm is permanently located at a site. 
False alarm means the activation of a fire, burglary and/or robbery or personal alarm by other than a medical emergency, fire, unintentional smoke, forced entry or attempted forced entry to the premises and at a time when no fire has occurred, no emergency medical treatment is needed or no burglary, theft, robbery or forcible entry is being committed or attempted on the premises. False alarms shall include negligently activated alarms, alarms which are the result of equipment which has been improperly installed or maintained, and alarms which are purposefully activated to summon the police, firemen or emergency medical technicians in nonemergency situations, but does not include an alarm caused by violent weather conditions, acts of God or other causes which are beyond the user's control. 
Multiple alarm sites means more than one alarm system on the premises. 
Panic or personal alarm means an alarm system signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a life threatening or emergency situation requiring emergency medical service, fire or law enforcement response. 
(Ord. No. 2001-027, § 21.5-201, 10-9-2001) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-32. - Responsibility of alarm user. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to activate any alarm system, otherwise cause an alarm system to be activated, or operate or maintain an alarm system which is activated at a time when no fire, burglary, or robbery is in progress at a premises that causes a public safety officer to be dispatched and is later determined to be false. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to activate, otherwise cause to be activated, or operate or maintain any alarm system which automatically sends a prerecorded message or coded signal indicating the activation of an alarm system to any public safety agency. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly and intentionally to activate any alarm system as set forth in subsection (a) or (b) of this section with the full knowledge that no fire, burglary or robbery is in progress at a premises. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to obey a cease and desist order issued pursuant to this section. 
(e)  All alarm users shall be required to respond to the location where the alarm is activated or when requested by the police department, fire department or alarm administrator. The key holder will be given 30 minutes from the time the officer or foremen arrive at the premises to respond to the alarm, unless other arrangements are made through the alarm administrator. Upon activation, the alarm shall not sound any longer than 15 minutes. 
(Ord. No. 2001-027, § 21.5-203, 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 34-33. - Responsibility of alarm administrator. 
(a)  The police department, the monitoring agency for this article, will make notification to any owner or occupier of the premises who have violated this article. 
(b)  The alarm administrator will issue a written notice of all false alarms to alarm users. This notice is in addition to the notice issued to the key holder answering the false alarm. 
(Ord. No. 2001-027, § 21.5-204, 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 34-33.1 - Responsibilities of alarm company. 
Each alarm company, for each alarm system that it sells, installs and monitors, shall be responsible for the following: 
(1)  Ensure that all alarm users are provided with adequate training in false alarm prevention. 
(2)  Review with all their installation customers and provide the alarm administrator with a false alarm prevention checklist. 
(3)  Provide the alarm administrator or designee with completed permit registration forms and permit fees for all installations, transfers, or conversions. 
(4)  Verify alarm calls and attempt to cancel dispatch when verification of a false alarm is received. 
(5)  Provide the alarm administrator with updated/current contact information regarding each alarm. 
(Ord. No. 2008-05, § A, 3-3-2008; Ord. No. 2008-09, § A, 5-5-2008) 
Sec. 34-34. - Exemptions. 
(a)  There shall be a 30-day grace period following the installation of any new alarm system during which period false alarms shall not be counted. This grace period is provided to allow the installing company or other installer and the user to take necessary corrective action with regard to the operation of the alarm system. A responsible person at such premises must maintain written proof, in the form of an invoice, of the date of installation of an alarm system for exemption under this section. 
(b)  An alarm activated during an alarm system testing procedure shall not be considered a false alarm if the alarm user first notifies and receives permission from the user's alarm company, or designee, or the police department to test the system. 
(c)  The police chief shall issue a cease and desist order to any person violating subsection 34-32(c). Such order shall direct that the alarm system in question be permanently disconnected immediately upon receipt of such order. 
(d)  The police chief shall also issue a cease and desist order to any person who has violated subsection 34-32(a) and/or subsection 34-32(b) six times within any calendar month or three times within any 24-hour period. Such order shall direct that the alarm system in question be disconnected and shall not be reconnected until it has been inspected and serviced by a properly trained and licensed technician. Such order shall be rescinded upon receipt by the chief of police of written proof that such inspection and service has been performed and any malfunction or maladjustment corrected. 
(Ord. No. 2001-027, § 21.5-205, 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 34-35. - Offenses. 
(a)  Upon the police, fire or emergency medical service responding to the fifth false alarm within a 12-month period, the owner or occupier of the premises where such alarm or burglary system is maintained shall be given a written notice that five responses to false alarms have occurred within a 12-month period. Any additional false alarms would result in the alarms administrator assessing a service fee due and payable within 30 days following notice thereof, and treated as any other municipal liability, such as taxes, and issue a fi. fa. and an execution for the owner of the premises for violation of this article. In cases where the fee is to be assessed to the alarm company, payment of the fee is required as a condition for doing business, or continuing to do business, in the city. The violation would result in fees as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Upon the police or fire department responding to each false alarm, the responding key holder will be advised of the false alarm. If the key holder fails to respond to any false alarm, the responding officer or firemen will notify the alarm administrator who will assess a fee to the owner or occupier for violation of this article. If the key holder fails to respond to any false alarm after the fifth false alarm, the alarm administrator will issue a double assessment. One assessment will be for the owner or occupier for violation of this subsection, and one assessment will be issued for the owner or occupier for violation of subsection (a) of this section. The violation of this subsection would result in an assessment of $25.00. 
(c)  If an alarm company fails to register an alarm system as required, the alarm administrator will assess a fee to the alarm company for violation of this article. The violation of this subsection would result in an assessment of $75.00. 
(d)  If an owner or occupier is a corporation or government entity, the summons will be addressed to the corporation or government entity and made attention to a designated individual. It will be the responsibility of the corporation or governmental entity to provide the police department with the name of the designated individual. 
(Ord. No. 2001-027, § 21.5-206, 10-9-2001; Ord. No. 2008-05, §§ B, C, 3-3-2008; Ord. No. 2008-09, §§ B, C, 5-5-2008) 
Sec. 34-36. - Appeals. 
If a location is assessed a false alarm fee, and the owner, business or legal entity does not agree that the alarm activation should be classified as a false alarm, the owner, business or legal entity may choose to appeal the ruling through the proper process as follows: 
(1)  The proper representative of the owner, business, legal entity, or alarm company having or maintaining the alarm system may contact the chief of the agency that responded to the alarm (fire, police or emergency medical service) and appeal the ruling. The alarm administrator will present any documentation on behalf of the city. 
(2)  If the owner, business, legal entity, or alarm company (proper representative) and the chief of police, fire chief or director of emergency medical services are not able to resolve and agree on the alarm classification, the proper representative may request a meeting with the city manager to appeal the ruling. The alarm administrator will present any documentation on behalf of the city. 
(3)  The ruling of the city manager will be final. 
(Ord. No. 2001-027, § 21.5-207, 10-9-2001; Ord. No. 2008-05, § D, 3-3-2008; Ord. No. 2008-09, § D, 5-5-2008) 
Secs. 34-37—34-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION 

Sec. 34-56. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain within the city an alarm system on commercial or residential premises unless the alarm company has registered such alarm with the police department or designee on such valid alarm registration form supplied by the alarm administrator or designee. A separate registration is required for each alarm site (multiple alarm sites). Fire alarms, burglary or robbery alarms, or panic alarms (any combination) on one site will be considered as one registration. 
(Ord. No. 2001-027, § 21.5-202(a), 10-9-2001; Ord. No. 2008-05, § E, 3-3-2008; Ord. No. 2008-09,:s; E, 5-5-2008) 
Sec. 34-57. - Application. 
Each alarm registration application shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name, complete address, and telephone numbers of the person who will be the registration holder and be responsible for the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees assessed under this article; 
(2)  The classification of the alarm site as either residential, commercial, government entity or apartment; 
(3)  For each alarm system located at the alarm site, the classification of the alarm system, i.e., fire, burglary, holdup, panic or other, for each purpose, whether audible or silent; 
(4)  Mailing address if different from the alarm site; 
(5)  Any dangerous or special conditions present, i.e., attack dog at the alarm site; 
(6)  Name and telephone numbers of at least two individuals who are able and have agreed to receive notification of an alarm activation at any time; respond to the alarm site within 30 minutes; and will deactivate the alarm system if such becomes necessary; 
(7)  Type of business conducted at the alarm site; and 
(8)  That law enforcement, fire or emergency medical service response may be based on factors such as: availability of police units, fire or emergency medical technicians, priority of calls, weather conditions, traffic conditions, emergency conditions, staffing levels, etc. 
(Ord. No. 2001-027, § 21.5-202(c), 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 34-58. - Issuance; conditions. 
Upon receipt of a completed application form for registration under this division, the alarm administrator shall register the applicant and assign an alarm index number unless the applicant has failed to pay a prior fi. fa. assessment or had an alarm registration for the alarm site suspended or revoked, and the violation causing the suspension or revocation has not been corrected. 
(Ord. No. 2001-027, § 21.5-202(b), 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 34-59. - False application. 
Any false statement of a material fact made by an applicant for the purpose of obtaining an alarm registration under this division shall be sufficient cause for refusal to issue a registration or to revoke a registration upon the discovery of a false statement of a material fact. 
(Ord. No. 2001-027, § 21.5-202(e), 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 34-60. - Transferability. 
An alarm registration under this division may not be transferred to another person or alarm site. An alarm user shall inform the alarm administrator of any change that alters any information listed on the registration application within five business days. 
Sec. 34-61. - Fee. 
A fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk shall accompany each application for registration under this division, except that governments shall be exempt from paying such registration fee. 
(Ord. No. 2001-027, § 21.5-202(f), 10-9-2001) 
Sec. 34-62. - Duration. 
Each registration completed under this division shall be valid for one year from the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 2001-027, § 21.5-202(g), 10-9-2001) 
Chapter 38 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Animals, ch. 14; rabies control, § 14-151 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; moving buildings, § 18-91 et seq.; demolition, § 18-141 et seq.; floods, ch. 42; parks and recreation, ch. 50; planning and zoning, ch. 54; historic preservation, § 54-131 et seq.; sewers, ch. 62; solid waste, ch. 66. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 38-1—38-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NOISE REGULATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2016-19, § I, adopted Dec. 15, 2016 , repealed former Art. II, §§ 38-31—38-40, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2014-11, § I, adopted June 2, 2014 . 
Cross reference— Traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 78. 

Sec. 38-31. - Purpose and standards. 
(a)  Purpose. This section is enacted to protect, preserve and promote the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City of Tifton through the control of noise. It is the intent of this section to establish standards that will reduce excessive community noises, which are harmful and otherwise detrimental to individuals and to the community in the enjoyment of life and property and in the conduct of business. 
(b)  Sound measurement standards for law enforcement and code enforcement personnel. For the purposes of this article, "plainly audible" shall mean any sound emanating from the specific sound-producing sources set forth below which can be heard from the distances set forth below, using the following sound measurement standards: Measurement shall be by the auditory senses of a person standing at a distance no less than the required minimum distance from the source of the sound. For music and other noise, words and phrases need not be discernable. For music and other noise, bass reverberations are included. 
( Ord. No. 2016-19, § I, 12-15-2016 ) 
Sec. 38-32. - Prohibited conduct. 
(a)  Restrictions of 300 feet for 7:00 a.m. through 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and 7:00 a.m. through 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
(1)  Mechanical sound-making devices. It is unlawful for any person or persons to play, use, operate, or permit to be played, used, or operated any radio receiving device, television, stereo, musical instrument, phonograph sound amplifier or other machines or devices for the producing, reproducing or amplifying of sound and/or noise at such a volume and in such a manner so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible more than 300 feet beyond the property boundary of the property from which the noises and/or sounds emanate between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
(2)  Human-produced sounds. It is unlawful for any person or persons to yell, shout, hoot, holler, whistle or sing on the public streets, sidewalks or on private property so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible more than 300 feet beyond the property boundary of the property from which the noises and/or sounds emanate between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. on Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
(3)  Commercial advertising. It is unlawful for any person or persons to use, operate, or permit to be used or operated any radio receiving device, musical instrument, phonograph, loud speaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the production or reproduction of sound which is cast upon the public streets or other public property for the purpose of commercial advertising or which serves to attract the attention of the public to any building, structure or vehicle in such a manner so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible at a distance of 300 feet or more from the source of the sound cast upon the public streets or other public property, or more than 300 feet beyond the property boundary of the property from which the noises and/or sounds emanate between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. on Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12 midnight on Friday and Saturday. 
(4)  Party noise. It is unlawful for any person or persons in charge of a party or other social event that occurs on any private property to allow that party or social event to produce noise in such a manner that such noise is plainly audible at a distance of 300 feet or more from the property boundary on which the party or social event is located, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. on Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday. For the purposes of this subsection, a "person in charge of a party or other social event" shall mean any person who resides in or on the premises involved in such party or social event and is present at such party or social event. For the purposes of this subsection, "noise" shall mean the same sounds, or any combination thereof, as described in paragraphs (1) or (2) above. 
(b)  Restrictions of 100 feet for 11:00 p.m. through 7 a.m. Sunday through Thursday and 12:00 midnight through 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
(1)  Mechanical sound-making devices. It is unlawful for any person or persons to play, use, operate, or permit to be played, used, or operated any radio receiving device, television, stereo, musical instrument, phonograph sound amplifier or other machines or devices for the producing, reproducing or amplifying of sound and/or noise at such a volume and in such a manner so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible more than 100 feet beyond the property boundary of the property from which the noises and/or sounds emanate between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
(2)  Human-produced sound. It is unlawful for any person or persons to yell, shout, hoot, holler, whistle or sing on the public streets or sidewalks or on private property so as to create, or cause to be created, any noises or sounds which are plainly audible more than 100 feet beyond the property boundary of the property from which the noises and/or sounds emanate between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on Sunday through Thursday and between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
(3)  Commercial advertising.
