(2)  The applicant is not, nor has ever been, affiliated with or a member of any organization or group having communistic beliefs; and 
(3)  A payment of a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1974, § 16-22) 
Sec. 46-5. - Public drunkenness; consumption of alcoholic beverages on municipal property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person while intoxicated or drunk to appear in any public place while one or more persons are present or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own where one or more persons are present and manifest a drunken condition by boisterous or indecent conduct or loud or profane language or both. 
(b)  No person shall be intoxicated to such an extent as to be boisterous or noisy, or who shall commit any other act of disorder amounting to a breach of the peace. 
(c)  Consumption or possession of open alcoholic beverages of any kind is prohibited on any municipal property located within the limits of the city, to include but not be limited to all streets, sidewalks and thoroughfares, all municipal parking lots, all municipal buildings, and all public parks and recreational facilities. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drink alcoholic beverages in or at any restaurant, cafe, eating place, hotel, drugstores, or other place of business in the city unless such person first secures the express consent of the proprietor or manager then in charge of such place. It shall be unlawful for any person to be in or at any restaurant, cafe, eating place, hotel, drugstore, or other place of business in the city, in an intoxicated condition. 
(e)  No person shall maintain any place in the city at which he permits other persons to assemble and violate any provisions of this section. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be intoxicated on the streets. 
(Code 1974, § 16-23) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6. 
Sec. 46-6. - Skating on streets. 
It shall be unlawful to skate on roller skates on any street in the city paved with asphalt or asphaltic concrete. 
(Code 1974, § 16-24) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 
Sec. 46-7. - Solicitation for funds by nonresident organizations. 
(a)  All solicitations for funds by nonresident religious or charitable organizations in the city are hereby prohibited and declared to be unlawful unless prior thereto a permit is obtained from the manager of the city and the chief of police of the city in the manner set out in this section. 
(b)  Any nonresident religious or charitable organization desiring to solicit funds in the city shall prior thereto make a written application to the manager and the chief of police which shall set forth the following: name and address of organization; period of time solicitations will be conducted; number and names of individuals who will solicit funds; time each day that solicitations will be made; and purpose of solicitations. 
(c)  The written applications shall be presented to either the manager of the city or the chief of police at least 48 hours prior to the proposed solicitation period, and following this the manager and chief of police within the 48-hour period shall either grant the permit or refuse the permit. The general welfare of the citizens of the city will be the primary factor considered by the manager and the chief of police in either granting or refusing such permit. 
(d)  Should the manager and the chief of police refuse to grant the permit for the solicitation of funds and the solicitations be carried on without such permit, any person or persons participating in soliciting funds shall be considered to be engaged in an unlawful activity and upon conviction thereof be punished as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. 
(Code 1974, § 16-30) 
Sec. 46-8. - Sale of literature advocating abuse of controlled substances. 
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person to sell, offer for sale, distribute, display or promote to any minor or to any other person any item, object, printed matter, or any other material related to illegal drugs covered by the state controlled substances act (O.C.G.A. title 16, ch. 13) which reasonably leads to any of the following: 
(1)  Intolerable invasion of privacy. 
(2)  Disruptions of the classroom. 
(3)  Incitement to imminent lawless activity. 
(4)  Solicitation of illegal activity. 
(Code 1974, § 16-31) 
Sec. 46-9. - Curfew for minors during school hours. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the term: 
(1)  Minor means persons that are at least six years old but not yet 17 years old; and 
(2)  Public place means any street, highway, alley or right-of-way, including sidewalks; any park, playground, shopping center or other place or building open to the public; any cemetery, schoolyard, body of water or watercourse; any privately-owned or publicly-owned place of amusement, entertainment or public accommodation, including, parking lots and other areas adjacent thereto; and any vacant lot or land, whether publicly-owned or privately-owned. 
(b)  Between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. on any school day, it shall be unlawful for any minor to loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, places, buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any place unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places; provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply when the minor: 
(1)  Is accompanied by his parent, guardian or other adult person 21 years of age or older having the legal care or custody of the minor; 
(2)  Is upon an emergency errand directed by the minor's parent, guardian or other adult person having the legal care or custody of the minor; 
(3)  Is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the places referenced in subsection (b) of this section during the prescribed period of time; 
(4)  Is in a motor vehicle with parental consent for normal interstate and intrastate travel through the city; 
(5)  Is enrolled in a valid home study program as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 20-2-690; 
(6)  Has completed all course study requirements for high school graduation; 
(7)  Is married in accordance with applicable law; 
(8)  Has written proof from school authorities that the minor is excused from school attendance at that particular time; 
(9)  Is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of First Amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly or free exercise of religion; or 
(10)  Serves as a page of the general assembly as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 20-2-692. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having legal custody or control of any minor to allow such minor to be in or upon any public place within the city between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. on any school day, except in the circumstances set out in subsections (b)(1)—(9) of this section. An adult person who is in violation of this subsection shall be subject to such punishment as the city municipal court may impose, subject to all limitations contained in the city charter and O.C.G.A. § 20-2-690.1, and in case of conflict, the latter shall control. Each violation of this subsection shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)  It shall be an affirmative defense if the parent or legal guardian of the minor has invoked the jurisdiction of the juvenile court against the minor prior to the time that the minor was found in violation of subsection (b) of this section. Any minor who violates subsection (b) of this section is subject to the jurisdiction of the juvenile court. 
(e)  Any police officer who takes into custody a minor in violation of subsection (b) of this section shall comply with the requirements of O.C.G.A. §§ 20-2-699 and 20-2-700. 
(f)  If a minor is suspended or expelled from school, for the duration of the suspension or expulsion, such minor's parent or legal guardian shall: 
(1)  Personally supervise the minor or arrange for a responsible adult 21 years of age or older to supervise the minor at the times that the minor would have been required to be in attendance at school if the minor had not been expelled or suspended; and 
(2)  Prohibit the minor from being in any public place at the times that the minor would have been required to be in attendance at school if the minor had not been suspended or expelled, unless the minor is: 
a.  Accompanied by his parent or legal guardian or a responsible adult 21 years of age or older selected by the parent or legal guardian to supervise the minor; or 
b.  Employed pursuant to an age or schooling certificate during the actual working hours, or traveling directly to or from the job site. 
(g)  A person who is in violation of subsection (f) of this section shall be subject to such punishment as the city municipal court shall impose, subject to all limitations contained in the city charter and O.C.G.A. § 20-2-690.1, and in case of conflict, the latter shall control. Each violation of this subsection shall constitute a separate offense. 
(h)  Any minor who violates subsection (b) of this section, while under suspension or expulsion from school, shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the juvenile court. 
(i)  It shall be an affirmative defense if the parent or legal guardian has invoked the jurisdiction of the juvenile court against the minor prior to the time that the minor violated subsection (f) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2009-12, § I, 6-1-2009) 
Sec. 46-10. - Curfew for minors during evening hours. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the term: 
(1)  Minor means persons that are not yet 17 years old; and 
(2)  Public place means any street, highway, alley or right-of-way, including sidewalks; any park, playground, shopping center or other place or building open to the public; any cemetery, schoolyard, body of water or watercourse; any privately-owned or publicly-owned place of amusement, entertainment or public accommodation, including, parking lots and other areas adjacent thereto; any vacant lot or land, whether publicly-owned or privately-owned; and any private property over which the public has either been granted or has taken the right of vehicular and/or pedestrian travel. 
(b)  Between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. it shall be unlawful for any minor to loiter, wander, stroll or play in or upon any public place as defined hereinabove unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places; provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply when the minor: 
(1)  Is accompanied by his parent, guardian or other adult person 21 years of age or older having the legal care or custody of the minor; 
(2)  Is upon an emergency errand directed by the minor's parent, guardian or other adult person having the legal care or custody of the minor; 
(3)  Is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in the places referenced in this section during the prescribed period of time; 
(4)  Is in a motor vehicle with parental consent for normal interstate and intrastate travel through the city; 
(5)  Is attending an event sponsored by such minor's school including, but not limited to, sporting events and dances; or 
(6)  Is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of First Amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly or free exercise of religion. 
(c)  Any minor found by any police officer to be in violation of this section for the first time shall be taken to the city police department whereupon such minor's responsible adult parent or legal guardian shall be called to come pick up the child. A warning citation shall then be given to both the minor and to the responsible parent or legal guardian. 
(d)  Any police officer who takes into custody a minor in violation of subsection (b) of this section that has already received a warning citation shall then notify juvenile court authorities for processing consistent with the requirements of O.C.G.A. tit. 15, ch. 11. 
(e)  Any adult person who is in violation of this section after having first received a warning citation shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. 
(f)  It shall be an affirmative defense if the parent or legal guardian of the minor has invoked the jurisdiction of the juvenile court against the minor prior to the time that the minor was found in violation of subsection (b) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2011-06, § I, 5-2-2011) 
Sec. 46-11. - Indecent, evocative or provocative bodily exposure and dress in public. 
(a)  Title. The title of this section shall be "An ordinance prohibiting indecent, evocative or provocative bodily exposure or dress in public." 
(b)  Definitions. 
The term evocative as used in this section shall mean any display of any portion of the body which is normally covered by undergarments or clothing designed and intended to be worn as undergarments which convey an image that is lewd, indecent or sexually titillating to a person of ordinary and reasonable sensibilities. 
The term hips as used in this section shall be defined as the crest of the ilium of the wearer. 
The term pants as used in this section shall mean a usually loose-fitting outer garment for the lower part of the body, having individual leg portions that reach typically to the ankle but sometimes to any of various other points from the upper leg down. 
The term provocative as used in this section shall mean any display of any portion of the body which is normally covered by undergarments or clothing designed and intended to be worn as undergarments which conveys an image that is lewd, indecent to a person of ordinary and reasonable sensibilities or is intended to convey membership in identifiable gangs which have been previously associated with unlawful acts. 
The term public place as used in this section shall mean any street, alley, park, public building, any place of business or assembly open to or frequented by the public, and any other place which is open to the public view, or to which the public has access. 
The term undergarment as used in this section shall mean clothing worn at or below the waist, usually next to the skin, that are designed, intended or worn under the clothes to cover a person's intimate parts. 
(c)  Indecent, evocative or provocative acts prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to appear in a public place or on public property wearing pants more than three inches below the top of the hips (crest of the ilium) exposing the skin or undergarments. 
(d)  Penalties. 
(1)  A citation shall be issued to the offender and the person shall be subject to a penalty of not less than $25.00 on the first offense and not more than $200.00 for each subsequent offense. In addition to or in lieu of a fine, the court may order such person to participate in up to 40 hours of court approved community service activities. 
(2)  Any violation of this section shall be cited by the law enforcement officer by issuance of a citation and summons to appear before the municipal court of the city, or in the case of a juvenile, the juvenile court of the county. 
(3)  This section shall not, in and of itself, be grounds for an arrest or for search of the person cited. However, the municipal court or juvenile court shall have the same authority as the superior court to enforce obedience to its orders, judgments and sentences. 
(Ord. No. 2011-14, § I, 11-7-2011) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-14, § I, adopted Nov. 7, 2011, enacted provisions intended for codification as § 46-10. To preserve the style of this Code, and to facilitate indexing, said provisions have been redesignated as § 46-11. 
Secs. 46-12—46-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 

Sec. 46-31. - Advertising—Posting on utility poles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to tack, post or nail any paper, metal, wood, or other signs or advertising matter of any character, on any telegraph, telephone or electric light pole on any street or alley within the city. 
(Code 1974, § 16-1) 
Sec. 46-32. - Same—Posting on private property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to post, or cause to be posted, any bill or bills on any building within the corporate limits of the city without the consent of the owner of the building. 
(Code 1974, § 16-2) 
Sec. 46-33. - Damaging city trees or property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cut down or injure, in any way, any tree on the sidewalks or on the public streets, or to injure or deface any property of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 16-7) 
Sec. 46-34. - Unlawful possession of property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be found in possession of property which the person does not own and which he has not obtained possession of with the consent of the owner of such property. 
(Code 1974, § 16-32) 
Sec. 46-35. - Unwanted presence on premises of another. 
(a)  The unwanted presence of a person on the premises of another person is hereby declared to be dangerous to the welfare and safety of the residents of the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, who is on the premises of another, to fail and refuse to leave such premises when requested to do so by the owner of such premises, or by any person in charge of such premises or the agent or employee of such owner or such person in charge of such premises. 
(Code 1974, § 16-27) 
Secs. 46-36—46-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 46-61. - Disorderly conduct. 
Any person shall be guilty of disorderly conduct if he: 
(1)  Acts in violent or tumultuous manner toward another. 
(2)  Acts in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another, whereby public property or property of any other person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damaged. 
(3)  Endangers lawful pursuits of another by acts of violence, angry threats, and abusive conduct. 
(4)  Causes, provokes or engages in any filth, brawl, or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health, or property of another or public property. 
(5)  Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose of causing, provoking, encouraging, or engaging in any fight or brawl. 
(6)  Jostles or roughly crowds or pushes any person in any public place. 
(7)  Collects in bodies or in crowds for unlawful purposes. 
(8)  Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose of or with the intent to engage in gaming. 
(9)  Frequents any public place with intent to obtain money from another by any illegal and fraudulent scheme, trick, artifice or device. 
(10)  Assembles with another or others for the purpose of engaging in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain any valuable thing in any place or from any person in the city or aids or abets therein. 
(11)  Utters, while in a state of anger, in the presence of another, any lewd or obscene words or epithets. 
(12)  Frequents any place where gaming or the illegal sale or possession of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or dangerous drugs is practiced, allowed or tolerated. 
(13)  Assembles or congregates with another or others for the purpose of doing bodily harm to another. 
(14)  No person shall attempt to force his person or company upon any other person against such person's will. 
(Code 1974, § 16-9) 
Sec. 46-62. - Aggressive begging. 
(a)  Prohibited. No person shall engage in aggressive begging in any public place in the city. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended: 
Aggressive begging means begging with the intent to intimidate another person into giving money or goods. 
Begging means asking for money or goods as a gift, whether by words, bodily gestures, signs, or other means. 
Intimidate means coercing or frightening into submission or obedience. 
Public place means any road, alley, lane, parking area, sidewalk or any place, private or otherwise, adopted or fitted for vehicular or pedestrian travel, that is in common use by the public with the consent, expressed or implied, of the owner or owners, and further, any public playground, school grounds, recreation grounds, parks, parkways, park drives, park paths and wharves, station grounds, and rights-of-way open to the use of the public. 
(Code 1974, § 16-10) 
Sec. 46-63. - Loitering or prowling. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of loitering or prowling when he is in a place at a time or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. 
(b)  Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself, or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impractical, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise explain his presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with the foregoing procedure or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, loaf, wander, stand, or remain idle either along and/or in consort with others in a public place in such manner so as to: 
(1)  Obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building by hindering or impeding or tending to hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles, traffic, or pedestrians. 
(2)  Commit in or upon any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building any act or thing which is an obstruction or interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or facing or fronting on any such public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building all of which prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress, regress therein, thereof and thereto. 
(d)  When any person causes or commits any of the conditions enumerated in subsection (c) of this section, a police officer or any law enforcement officer shall order that person to stop causing or committing such conditions and to move on or disperse. Any person who fails or refuses to obey such orders shall be guilty of a violation of the section. 
(Code 1974, § 16-13) 
Sec. 46-64. - Unlawful assemblies; dispersing. 
If any persons are unlawfully, riotously or tumultuously assembled within the city, any police officer or member of the police department of the city, whether such member is a regular or special police officer appointed for temporary service, when, in the opinion of the police officer or member of the police department, the assembly of such persons shall tend to create a disturbance or incite a riot or disorderly conduct, such officers shall command all of the persons, as assembled, immediately and peaceably to disperse, and if such persons so commanded do not thereupon immediately and peaceably disperse, such persons shall be deemed guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1974, § 16-26) 
Sec. 46-65. - Congregating on streets, sidewalks. 
The congregating of persons on the sidewalks and streets of the city so as to obstruct the sidewalks and streets is hereby declared to be dangerous to the welfare and safety of the residents of the city. It shall be unlawful for any person or number of persons to congregate in such numbers on the sidewalks and streets of the city so as to obstruct the sidewalks and streets. 
(Code 1974, § 16-6) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 
Sec. 46-66. - Disorderly house. 
(a)  The following terms shall have the following definitions as applied to this Code section: 
(1)  Disorderly house means any place within or without any building or structure where persons assemble for the purpose of illegally dispensing or indulging in alcoholic beverages; gaming; prostitution; or the manufacturing, distribution or use of controlled substances. 
(2)  Person means owner, lessee or lessor of property, their guests and invitees, or officer of or agent for any corporation, association, club, lodge or other organization. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain or operate either by himself or by others, a common, ill-governed and disorderly house, to the encouragement of gaming, prostitution, illegally dispensing or indulging in alcoholic beverages, manufacturing, distribution or use of controlled substances, or other misbehavior, to the common disturbance, injury or endangerment to the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of the neighborhood or orderly citizens. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee, lessor, or other person, partnership or corporation having control over any house, building, structure, apartment, tent, vehicle, mobile home, or recreational vehicle to knowingly lease, sublease or otherwise permit the use of same for the purpose of keeping therein any disorderly house, and knowing or ascertaining that such house, building, structure, tent, vehicle, mobile home, or recreational vehicle is so occupied as a disorderly house, no persons, partnership or corporation shall continue to grant permission to so use such premises as a disorderly house; provided, however, before any person is charged under this subsection, written notice shall be given to the owner of the property and the person in possession thereof by the chief of police stating the general, customary and common habits of the house, giving fair notice of this subsection and the conduct prescribed thereby. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any boisterous, noisy, drunken or riotous person to assemble or remain in their house, apartment or upon their property, after receiving oral notice from a police officer that boisterous, noisy, drunken or carousing activities have caused complaint and annoyance to the common disturbance of the neighborhood or orderly citizens; provided, however, no person shall be charged under this subsection unless the owner or person in possession of the premises has been afforded an opportunity to disburse the assembly or offending person from the premises. This subsection shall not preclude a police officer from arresting any individual for criminal trespass where such individual knowingly and without authority remains on private property after being notified by the owner or lawful occupant to depart. 
(Ord. No. 2009-03, § I, 4-6-09) 
Sec. 46-67. - Gambling; possession of gaming equipment. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to assemble with another or others for the purpose of playing or betting for money or other thing of value, at any game played with cards, dice, or balls, or to play and bet money or other thing of value, at any table or whatever name, kind or description, for gaming, or to bet at any game of ninepins, or any other number of pins, or at any billiard or pool table. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain gaming devises in his or another's place of business for use or operation of any kind, at any time or under any circumstance. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate or own or possess for the purpose of maintaining or operating any pinball or similar machine operated by depositing a coin therein for the playing of a game of engaging in any contest of chance or skill, including vending machines where the amount of merchandise to which the customer or person playing the machine is entitled is uncertain, or in some instances may be a larger amount than in other instance. 
(Ord. No. 2010-19, § I, 12-6-2010) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-19, § I, adopted Dec. 6, 2010, enacted provisions intended for codification as § 46-47. To preserve the style of this Code, and to facilitate indexing, said provisions have been redesignated as § 46-67. 
Secs. 46-68—46-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WEAPONS 

Sec. 46-81. - Archery—Prohibited except at ranges. 
All archery activity of any nature or kind is hereby prohibited within the city, except such activity done at an established and marked archery range. 
(Code 1974, § 16-3) 
Sec. 46-82. - Same—Adult supervision. 
There shall be no shooting of arrows at a marked and established archery range unless an adult person is present and actively supervising all activity at the range during the shooting of arrows. 
(Code 1974, § 16-4) 
Sec. 46-83. - Same—Sale, use of hunting arrows. 
The sale of hunting arrows to a minor is hereby prohibited; no hunting arrows may be used or shot on a marked and established archery range. 
(Code 1974, § 16-5) 
Sec. 46-84. - Discharging firearms. 
(a)  Except upon property located in the suburban-agriculture zoning district (S-A), it shall be unlawful for any person to discharge a gun, pistol or other firearm within the city except in defense of person or property. Within the suburban-agriculture zoning district it shall be unlawful to discharge a gun, pistol or other firearm within 1,000 feet of any structure. Despite the provisions hereof, no person shall be relieved of civil or criminal liability with respect to any such discharge. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the employees and other personnel of the police department, under the express authority and supervision of the department, may discharge firearms as required by the department on and upon the city police department pistol range located on Ferry Lake Road. 
(Code 1974, § 16-8; Ord. of 2000-001, § 16-8, 1-3-2000; Ord. No. 2001-31, § I(16-8), 11-12-2001) 
Sec. 46-85. - Slingshots prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use a slingshot within the city. 
(Code 1974, § 16-25) 
Sec. 46-86. - Sale of certain weapons prohibited, regulated; reports of sales. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person to sell or barter to anyone, to exchange or keep for the purpose of sale, any of the following weapons: a shotgun or rifle with barrel length of less than 18 inches; knucks; dirk; sword-cane; blackjack; springback knife; switchblade knife; or any knife which has a blade which exceeds four inches in length, excluding hunting knives or butcher knives, or case knives customarily used for domestic or industrial use. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person, partnership, corporation, pawn shop or firm to sell or barter to any purchaser a rifle, shotgun or pistol without complying with the following regulations: 
(1)  At the time of the sale or barter, there shall be obtained from the purchaser in writing the following information: buyer's name, height, weight, race, residence address, date of birth, place of birth, and answers by the buyer to the following questions: 
a.  Have you been convicted in any court of a crime punishable by imprisonment for a term exceeding one year? (Note: The actual sentence given by the judge does not matter; a yes answer is necessary if the judge could have given a sentence of more than one year). 
b.  Are you under indictment or information in any court for a crime punishable by imprisonment for a term exceeding one year? 
c.  Have you been discharged from the armed forces under dishonorable conditions? 
d.  Are you a user of, or addicted to marihuana, or a depressant, stimulant, or narcotic drug? 
e.  Are you a fugitive from justice? 
f.  Have you ever been adjudicated mentally defective or have you ever been committed to a mental institution? 
g.  Are you an alien illegally in the United States? 
h.  Are you a person who, having been a citizen of the United States, has renounced his citizenship? 
This information will be obtained from the purchaser on a written form, which the purchaser must sign and date. 
(2)  Any person, partnership, corporation, pawn shop or firm selling or bartering a firearm as provided in this section shall provide to the police department the following information in writing: the manner in which the buyer of the firearm has identified himself to the seller; the type, model, caliber or gauge, serial number and manufacturer of the firearm. 
(3)  The information set out in subsections (b)(1) and (2) of this section shall be placed upon a printed form provided by the police department, and shall be made by the seller in duplicate. The original of such form showing such information shall be delivered by the seller to the police department on the same day that the firearm is sold or bartered, such delivery to be made by hand or by placing the original in the United States mail addressed to the police department. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person, partnership, corporation, pawn shop or firm required by subsection (b) of this section to obtain the information set out in subsection (b)(1) of this section to either fail to obtain such information or fail to provide such information to the police department, as required by subsection (b)(3) of this section. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person buying or bartering for a firearm, as set out in subsection (b) of this section, to give false information to the seller or to answer falsely any questions set out in subsection (b)(1) of this section. 
(Code 1974, § 16-29) 
Secs. 46-87—46-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC PANHANDLING, BEGGING, CHARITABLE AND POLITICAL SOLICITATION REGULATED 

Sec. 46-90. - Purpose and findings. 
The city council does hereby find that: 
(1)  It is the intent of council in enacting this article to recognize free speech rights for all citizens while at the same time protecting the coexistent rights for all citizens to enjoy safe and convenient travel in public spaces free from intimidating conduct, threats, and harassment that stem from certain types of abusive solicitation, or that may give rise to interference with other's activities if they occur in particular settings and contexts; and 
(2)  Council finds that there are numerous forms of solicitation that are not in and of themselves inherently threatening or aggressive, including vocal requests for a donation; carrying or displaying a sign requesting donations; shaking or jingling a cup of change; and ringing a bell in compliance with any applicable noise ordinance; and 
(3)  However, council finds that there has been an increase in aggressive solicitation in the city, which threatens the security, privacy, and freedom of movement of both residents and visitors; and 
(4)  Council also finds that the presence of solicitors in certain specific areas (such as near to or adjacent to automatic teller machines, adjacent to sidewalk cafes, at public bus stops, and in public garages in the nighttime) create reasonable concerns by citizens objectively worried about their privacy, freedom of movement, and personal security; and 
(5)  Council further finds that certain forms of solicitation impede the orderly flow of pedestrian and vehicular traffic and leads to concerns regarding traffic and public safety, particularly in congested roadways and sidewalks to include highly traveled areas, building entrances, narrow sidewalks, traffic medians of high-speed or high-volume streets and highways; and 
(6)  Both aggressive and passive begging, panhandling, charitable or political solicitation within streets and highway rights of way, or on traffic medians, give rise to an increased risk of injury to solicitors on medians, traffic congestion, and traffic accidents that may affect drivers or solicitors. This article provides ample alternative sites for passive begging, panhandling, charitable and political solicitation in areas that do not give rise to enhanced public safety concerns or personal privacy and security concerns. 
(7)  This article is not intended impermissibly to limit an individual's right to exercise free speech associated with solicitation; rather it aims to impose specific time, place, and manner restrictions on solicitation and associated conduct in certain limited circumstances; namely, limiting aggressive panhandling, panhandling at locations or times deemed particularly threatening and dangerous, and panhandling in places where people wish to avoid or reduce a threat of inescapable confrontations; and 
(8)  In promulgating this article, council seeks to impose regulations that are narrowly tailored to serve the aforementioned significant governmental interests. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 46-91. - Definitions. 
(a)  Aggressive begging, panhandling, or solicitation includes the following forms of conduct: 
(1)  Confronting someone in a way that would cause a reasonable person to fear bodily harm; 
(2)  Accosting an individual by approaching or speaking to the individual or individuals in such a manner as would cause a reasonable person to fear imminent bodily harm or the commission of a criminal act upon his or her person, or upon property in his or her immediate possession; 
(3)  Touching someone without his or her consent; 
(4)  Using obscene or abusive language toward someone while attempting to panhandle or solicit him or her; 
(5)  Forcing oneself upon the company of another by engaging in any of the following conduct: 
a.  Continuing to solicit in close proximity to the individual addressed after the person to whom the solicitation is directed has made a negative response, either verbally, by physical sign, by attempting to leave the presence of the person soliciting, or by other negative indication; 
b.  Blocking the passage of the individual solicited; or 
c.  Otherwise engaging in conduct that could reasonably be construed as intending to compel or force a person to accede to a solicitation. 
(6)  Acting with the intent to intimidate someone into giving money, or 
(7)  Other conduct that a reasonable person being solicited would regard as threatening or intimidating in order to solicit a contribution or donation. 
(b)  Areas with heightened personal security concerns include the following locations: 
(1)  Public parking garage or lot, between dusk and dawn; 
(2)  Building entrances, public events venues, public accommodations or commercial businesses due to congestion and close proximity to others; 
(3)  Other areas in which congestion could give a reasonable person a reasonable, justified concern for his or her personal security due to congestion and close proximity to others. 
(c)  Areas with heightened personal privacy concerns include the following: 
(1)  Automated teller machine, or financial institution in which an automated teller machine is located. "Financial institution" means any bank, industrial bank, credit union, or savings and loan. 
(2)  Sidewalk café during operating hours unless the solicitor's presence is authorized by the proprietor . , 
(3)  Other locations in which a reasonable person would have a reasonable and justified concern about whether congestion and close proximity to others could compromise his or her interests in privacy. 
(d)  Areas with heightened public safety concerns include the following: 
(1)  Streets or highways; 
(2)  Sidewalks and corners at intersecting streets, highways and alleys; 
(3)  Traffic medians of whatever size within designated high traffic or high-speed roadways. 
(e)  Begging, panhandling and charitable or political solicitation includes the following activities: actions that are conducted in the furtherance of the purpose of immediately collecting contributions for the use of one's self or others. As used in this article, the word, "solicit," and its forms, includes requests for funding arising from begging, panhandling, charitable, or political fundraising initiatives. "Begging, panhandling and charitable or political solicitation" includes both "aggressive" and "passive" forms of begging, panhandling and charitable or political solicitation, but these forms are regulated separately under this article. 
(f)  Passive panhandling, begging, charitable or political solicitation includes conduct that falls within the definition in part (e) of this section, but only such conduct that involves requests for contributions presented in writing without speaking, oral requests for contributions that do not constitute "aggressive panhandling, begging, charitable or political solicitation," or other activities that do not fall within the definition of "aggressive begging, panhandling or solicitation" as defined in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 46-92. - Passive begging, panhandling, charitable and political solicitation: when regulated. 
Passive panhandling, begging, charitable or political solicitation are permitted except where expressly prohibited. 
The city council finds that "passive panhandling, begging, charitable or political solicitation," as defined in this article should be treated as speech protected under the first amendment unless other well- grounded governmental concerns are implicated. Accordingly, passive panhandling, begging, charitable or political solicitation is permitted throughout the jurisdiction except as prohibited in sections 46-94 and 46-95 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 46-93. - Aggressive panhandling, begging, charitable and political solicitation prohibited. 
Aggressive panhandling, begging, charitable and political solicitation prohibited. No person shall engage in aggressive panhandling, begging, charitable or political solicitation as defined in this article at anytime, anywhere in this jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 46-94. - Regulation of panhandling, begging, charitable and political solicitation in areas with specific personal safety and privacy concerns. 
Passive begging, panhandling, charitable and political solicitation are prohibited in the following areas that give rise to specific personal safety and privacy concerns: 
(1)  Locations within eight feet from the entrance of any building entrances, public events venues, public accommodations or commercial businesses; 
(2)  Locations within eight feet of an automated teller machine, or financial institution in which an automated teller machine is located. "Financial institution" means any bank, industrial bank, credit union, or savings and loan; 
(3)  Public parking garage or lot, between dusk and dawn 
(4)  Locations within ten feet of a sidewalk café during operating hours unless the solicitor's presence is authorized by the proprietor. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 46-95. - Panhandling, begging, charitable protection of public access and vehicular safety in public streets and highways and on traffic medians and on high volume and high-speed highways. 
Passive begging, panhandling, charitable and political solicitation are prohibited in the following areas that give rise to concerns of public access, vehicular safety in public streets and highways: 
(1)  Upon any street, highway or alley; 
(2)  Within eight feet from the corner of a intersecting street, highway or alley; 
(3)  Within or upon any median on a state highway. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Sec. 46-96. - Penalties. 
Any person who is convicted of violating this article shall, upon conviction, be penalized as provided in chapter 1, section 1-11 of the Code of Ordinances for the city. 
(Ord. No. 2018-07 , § I, 4-16-2018) 
Chapter 50 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]

State Law reference— Authority to construct and operate parks, swimming pools, golf courses, recreation grounds and buildings used for sports, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; authority to provide parks, recreation areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(5). 

Sec. 50-1. - Statutes adopted. 
O.C.G.A. chs. 36—64 is hereby adopted as an ordinance of the city, and full effect shall be given to the provisions of such chapter. 
(Code 1974, § 17-1) 
Sec. 50-2. - Statutory powers, duties vested in commission. 
The powers and duties enumerated in O.C.G.A. chs. 36—64 for the governing body of the supervised park systems shall be vested in the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1974, § 17-2) 
Sec. 50-3. - Facilities dedicated to park and recreational use. 
Such parks and playgrounds as may be acquired by the city are hereby dedicated to the uses contemplated and described under O.C.G.A. chs. 36—64. 
(Code 1974, § 17-3) 
Sec. 50-4. - Fulwood Park declared recreational area. 
Fulwood Park, located and bounded by East 12th Street on the north, Prince Avenue on the east, East 8th Street on the south and Tift Avenue on the west, is hereby declared to be a recreational area owned and maintained by the city for the enjoyment of the citizens of the city and their families. 
(Code 1974, § 17-4) 
Sec. 50-5. - Coordination of recreational activities. 
Any agency, organization or group desiring to use the city recreational facilities shall consult with the park superintendent prior to the use of such facilities and all recreational activities shall be cleared through the park superintendent in order that the recreational activities of the city will be coordinated. 
(Code 1974, § 17-5) 
Sec. 50-6. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession beer or any beverage containing any alcoholic content whatsoever, or to drink beer or any beverage containing any alcoholic content whatsoever, in any park. 
(Code 1974, § 17-7) 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6. 
Sec. 50-7. - Presence in park at night. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be in or occupy any park from 10:00 p.m. each day until 7:00 a.m. the following day; provided, however, any person or group of persons may secure the prior approval of the caretaker of the park to remain in such park during such hours and upon being given approval, may do so without being in violation of this section. 
(Code 1974, § 17-8) 
Sec. 50-8. - Damaging property. 
It shall be unlawful to destroy, deface or damage any park equipment or furnishing or playground equipment. 
(Code 1974, § 17-9) 
Sec. 50-9. - Moving park equipment. 
It shall be unlawful to move or remove any park benches, furniture or other equipment. 
(Code 1974, § 17-10) 
Sec. 50-10. - Damaging vegetation generally. 
It shall be unlawful to break, cut or otherwise damage any shrubbery, flowers or trees in any city park. 
(Code 1974, § 17-11) 
Cross reference— Vegetation, ch. 86. 
Sec. 50-11. - Reckless driving destroying vegetation in parks. 
It shall be unlawful to drive so recklessly within any city park as to destroy any shrubs or hedges. 
(Code 1974, § 17-12) 
Cross reference— Traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 78; vegetation, ch. 86. 
Sec. 50-12. - Vehicles to be on roadways. 
It shall be unlawful to drive or operate any vehicle in a city park, other than upon roadways furnished for that purpose. 
(Code 1974, § 17-13) 
Sec. 50-13. - Speed of vehicles in parks. 
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle, motor-driven or not, within any city park at a rate of speed greater than ten miles per hour. 
(Code 1974, § 17-14) 
Cross reference— Traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 78. 
Sec. 50-14. - Littering. 
It shall be unlawful to throw or deposit any paper, trash or refuse in or about any city park, other than in receptacles provided for that purpose. 
(Code 1974, § 17-15) 
Cross reference— Solid waste, ch. 66. 
Sec. 50-15. - Advertising. 
It shall be unlawful to place any sign in any park, or to distribute any circulars or other advertising matter therein. 
(Code 1974, § 17-16) 
Cross reference— Sign regulations, app. A, § 10-1 et seq. 
Sec. 50-16. - Camping; building fires. 
It shall be unlawful to camp in any park; and it shall be unlawful to build any fire therein, except in areas and facilities specifically set aside for such purpose. 
(Code 1974, § 17-17) 
Chapter 54 - PLANNING AND ZONING[1]
