The assignment by the applicant of any money due under the provisions of this refund policy without the written consent of the governing authority is prohibited. 
(h)  In the event that a water or wastewater main is extended, either inside or outside the corporate limits, the costs of which is paid in part or in full by the governing authority, applicants who wish to connect to the main shall be required to pay a connection charge in addition to the meter installation fee as referenced in section 62-413. The connection charge shall be applicant's proportionate share, on a footage basis, of the governing authority's share of the cost of the extension. If the water or wastewater main installed is larger than eight-inch, the applicant shall be required to pay only its proportionate share of the cost of an eight-inch main. 
(I)  All water and wastewater mains extended under the provisions of these regulations shall become the sole property of the governing authority upon the connection with the city-county water system and shall thenceforth be maintained by the city-county governing authority. 
(j)  Anything in these regulations to the contrary notwithstanding, the governing authority in its sole discretion, shall have the right to disapprove any application for water service when it determines that it is not in its best interest to do so based on monetary or manpower constraints or on other considerations such as the unavailability of water or wastewater supply. Furthermore, the governing authority reserves the right to extend its water system on a planned basis in the best interest of orderly community-wide growth. 
(Ord. No. 2006-13, § I, 2-13-2006; Ord. No. 2007-32, § I, 10-15-07) 
Secs. 62-402—62-410. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COLLECTIONS 

Sec. 62-411. - Turn-off/turn-on policy. 
All of the provisions set forth in this article shall apply to the user of the water and/or wastewater service and to the owner of the property being served. The term "customer" shall mean the name on the account to which the service is charged and the user of the service at the physical location. Termination of service shall follow these procedures: 
(1)  Service will be terminated to the delinquent customer consistent with the collections policies of the governing authority. 
(2)  Service turned off for non-payment of a water or wastewater bill will be turned on only after payment of the delinquent bill plus a fee to be set by resolution of the governing authority to cover the cost of the additional trips to the service location by utilities department personnel. 
(Ord. No. 2006-13, § I, 2-13-2006) 
Sec. 62-412. - Deposits. 
Applicants for water or wastewater services shall be required, at the time of application for service, to make a deposit consistent with customer service policies. 
(Ord. No. 2006-13, § I, 2-13-2006) 
Sec. 62-413. - Meter installation fees. 
At the time of application for water or wastewater service, the applicant shall also pay a meter installation fee in accordance with the rates adopted by the governing authority. 
(Ord. No. 2006-13, § I, 2-13-2006) 
Chapter 66 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2014-25 , adopted Dec. 1, 2014, repealed the former Ch. 66, §§ 66-1—66-29, 66-61—66-72, 66-91—66-96, and enacted a new chapter as set out herein. The former Ch. 66 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2001-021, §§ 10-1—10-29, 10-42—10-52, 10-54, adopted July 26, 2001; Ord. No. 2002-013, §§ IA—IF, adopted Dec. 19, 2002; Ord. No. 2004-005, § I, adopted Feb. 9, 2004; Ord. No. 2006-26, § I, adopted Dec. 4, 2006; Ord. No. 2008-03, § I, adopted Jan. 23, 2008; and Ord. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Intent and purpose. 
The City Council of City of Tifton hereby declares the intent and purpose of this chapter to be such that a uniform and consistent procedure for regulating the storage, collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste in the incorporated areas of the city is established so as to: 
(1)  Protect the public health, safety and welfare by preventing the dissemination of and providing for the removal of inorganic refuse materials laden with bacterial elements and contaminants detrimental to the general wellbeing of the citizens, their property, and the environment; 
(2)  Protect the public health, safety and welfare and enhance the quality of the water, air and overall environment of this city by providing for uniform rules and procedures for storage, collection, transportation and disposal of residential solid waste from residential premises and commercial properties within the incorporated areas of the city; 
(3)  Protect the public health, safety and welfare and enhance the quality of the water, air and overall environment of this city by prohibiting and restricting the operation of any business, enterprise or commercial activity within the incorporated areas of the city engaged in or carrying out services or operations for the storage, collections, transportation or disposal of solid waste except pursuant to a franchise license issued by the city, and providing for assessment of a franchise fee payable by such franchise license holder for the costs to the city of overseeing and regulating the activities permitted by such franchise license; and 
(4)  Protect the public health, safety and welfare and enhance the quality of the water, air and overall environment of this city by providing for certain additional rules and regulations applicable to the storage, collection, transportation and disposal of nonresidential solid waste in the incorporated areas of City of Tifton. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-2. - Enactment authority. 
The city council, under the authority of article 9, section 2, paragraphs I and III of the Constitution of the State of Georgia (1983), and O.C.G.A. tit. 12, ch. 8, art. 2 and O.C.G.A. tit. 16, ch. 7, hereby ordains and enacts into law this chapter. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-3. - Title. 
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as "The Solid Waste Ordinance of City of Tifton, Georgia." 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-4. - Applicability. 
This chapter shall apply to the storage, collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste in the incorporated areas of City of Tifton as presently or hereafter established. The provisions contained herein: (i) prescribe and provide certain uniform rules and procedures for the storage, collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste at and from residential premises and commercial enterprises within the incorporated areas of the city by residents commercial enterprises of such incorporated areas and by each and every business, enterprise or commercial activity engaged in providing such services and operations; (ii) provide for the franchising and licensing of such businesses, enterprises and commercial activities; (iii) prohibit businesses, enterprises or commercial activities from engaging in such services and operations except pursuant to and in accordance with such franchise license; and (iv) prescribe and provide certain additional rules and regulations for the storage, collection, transportation and disposal of nonresidential solid waste within and through the incorporated areas of the city. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-5. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meaning ascribed to them below in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. All terms used in this chapter, and not otherwise defined below in this section, shall have the definitions ascribed to them in O.C.G.A. § 12-8-22, as the same may be from time to time amended, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Except as specifically defined herein or in O.C.G.A. § 12-8-22, all words used in this chapter shall have their ordinary everyday meaning. Words used in the singular shall include the plural and words used in the plural shall include the singular. Words used in the present tense shall include the future tense. Unless otherwise specifically indicated in this chapter, references in this chapter to articles, sections, subsections, paragraphs, and the like, and to exhibits, attachments, schedules, and the like, are in each case to those of this chapter. 
Acceptable solid waste means residential, commercial and industrial waste as defined herein and which the landfill is authorized to accept for disposal pursuant to its permits and licenses and are not materials prohibited from disposal in the landfill pursuant to the Rules of Georgia Department of Natural Resources Environmental Protection Division Chapter 391-3-4. 
Approved containers shall mean: 
(1)  Ninety- to 100-gallon carts utilized for the collection of solid waste and recyclable materials from residential premises, multiple residential units and light commercial units; 
(2)  Four-, six-, and eight-yard dumpsters; and twenty-, thirty-, and forty-yard roll offs utilized by multiple residential units and commercial units. 
Asbestos means any naturally occurring hydrated mineral silicates separable into commercially used fibers, specifically the asbestiform varieties of serpentine, chrysatile, cummingtomite-grunerite, amosite, rieheckite, crocidolite, anthophyllite, tremolite, and actinolite. 
Biomedical waste means and includes the following: 
(1)  Pathological waste, which means all recognizable human tissues and body parts which are removed during surgery, obstetrical procedures, autopsy, and laboratory procedures. 
(2)  Biological waste, which means bulk blood and blood products, exudates, secretions, suctionings, and other bulk body fluids which cannot or are not directly discarded into a municipal sewer system. 
(3)  Cultures and stocks of infectious agents and associated biologicals including cultures from medical and pathological laboratories, cultures and stocks of infectious agents from research and industrial laboratories, wastes from the production of biologicals, discarded live and attenuated vaccines, and culture dishes and devices used to transfer, inoculate, and mix cultures. 
(4)  Contaminated animal carcasses, body parts, their bedding, and other wastes from such animals which have been exposed to infectious agents, capable of causing disease in man, during research, production of biologicals, or testing of pharmaceuticals. 
(5)  Sharps, which means any discarded article that may cause punctures or cuts. Such waste includes, but is not limited to, items such as needles, IV tubing and syringes with needles attached, and scalpel blades. 
(6)  Chemotherapy waste, which means any disposable material which has come in contact with cytotoxic/antineoplastic agents (agents toxic to cells) and/or antineoplastic agents (agents that inhibit or prevent the growth and spread of tumors or malignant cells) during the preparation, handling, and administration of such agents. Such waste includes, but is not limited to, masks, gloves, gowns, empty IV tubing bags and vials, and other contaminated materials. Such waste must first be classified as empty which means such quantity that it is not subject to other federal or state waste management regulations prior to being handled as biomedical waste. 
(7)  Discarded medical equipment and parts, not included expendable supplies and materials which have not been decontaminated, that were in contact with infectious agents. 
Building materials means any material such as lumber, brick, plaster, gutters, roofing materials, or other substances accumulated as a result of repairs or additions to existing buildings, construction of new buildings, or demolition of existing structures. 
Bulk container means a metal container of not less than four cubic yards nor larger than eight cubic yards, made of watertight construction with doors opening on top and constructed so that it can be emptied mechanically by a specially equipped truck. Containers shall be kept covered at all times. All new bulk containers shall meet these specifications. 
Bulky waste shall mean white goods, appliances, furniture and other materials with weights or volumes greater than those capable of being placed in approved containers, not to include construction or demolition waste. 
Cart (recyclable) or recyclable cart shall mean a roll-out container of adequate strength for the purposes intended with a capacity of approximately 90 to 100 gallons constructed of plastic, having handles of adequate strength for lifting, sturdy wheels for easy movement, and having a tightfitting lid capable of preventing entrance into the container by vectors, to be used by residential and light commercial users for the storage of acceptable recyclable material. 
Cart (solid waste) or solid waste cart shall mean a roll-out container of adequate strength for the purposes intended with an approximate capacity of not less than 90 gallons nor more than 100 gallons constructed of plastic, having handles of adequate strength for lifting, sturdy wheels for easy movement, and having a tight-fitting lid capable of preventing entrance into the container by vectors, to be used by subscribers for the storage of acceptable residential solid waste material. 
City shall mean City of Tifton, a political subdivision of the State of Georgia. 
City council, council shall mean the City Council of City of Tifton, Georgia. 
City manager shall mean the City Manager of City of Tifton. 
Commercial unit or commercial establishment means a business unit within the service area that uses four-, six- and eight-yard dumpsters; and twenty-, thirty-, and forty-yard roll offs. 
Commercial waste means food waste including accumulations of animal or vegetable matter used or intended for use as food, or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables produced by any commercial unit, any accumulation of dust, paper, glass, cans, wood, crockery, metals, dunnage, dust, sweepings, rags, cardboard or other accumulations, which are usually attendant to the operation of stores, offices and similar businesses. 
Construction/demolition waste means the waste building materials and rubble resulting from construction, remodeling, repair, and demolition operations on pavements, houses, buildings and other structures. Such wastes include, but are not limited to, wood, bricks, metal, concrete, wall board, paper or cardboard. 
Disposal site means the location authorized pursuant to this chapter where the final disposition of solid waste occurs. 
Dunnage means loose materials utilized as packing to prevent damage to cargo or contents from breakage or damage during shipping. 
Garbage means food waste including waste accumulations of animal or vegetable matter used or intended for use as food, or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables. 
EPD means the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources. 
Franchise fee shall mean a fee to be paid by a franchisee to the city for the regulation in City of Tifton of residential solid waste and the administration enforcement of the solid waste ordinance. The franchise issued to such franchisee and the rights, terms and conditions granted thereunder. 
Garbage means food waste including waste accumulations of animal or vegetable matter used or intended for use as food, or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables. 
Handling means the storage, collection, transportation, treatment, utilization, processing, or disposal of solid wastes, or any combination thereof. 
Handling facility means any location where any storage, collection, transportation, treatment, utilization, processing, or disposal of solid waste, or any combination thereof, occurs. 
Hazardous waste means any solid waste which has been defined as a hazardous waste in rules or regulations promulgated by the state department of natural resources and/or EPD and also specifically includes explosives, offal, fecal matter, acids, chemicals, caustics, asbestos, poisons, paint products, tires and petroleum products. This definition includes wastes that are ignitable, corrosive, reactive or extraction procedure toxic. 
Incineration means a controlled process by which solid, liquid and gaseous combustible wastes are burned and changed into gases and a residue produced which is relatively free of combustible materials. 
Industrial waste means all waste, including solids, semisolids, sludges, and liquids, created by factories, processing plants or other manufacturing enterprises. 
Inert landfill means a disposal site accepting only wastes that will not or are not likely to cause production of leachate of environmental concern. Such wastes are limited to dirt and dirt-like products, concrete, rocks, bricks, yard trimmings, stumps, limbs and leaves. This definition excludes industrial and demolition waste. 
Landfill shall mean the Tifton/Tift County Landfill and the Tifton/Tift County Inert Landfill. 
Light commercial unit means a business within the service area which uses an approved 90- to 100-gallon cart. 
Liquid waste means any waste material that is determined to contain free liquids as defined by method 9095 (paints filter liquids test), as described in Test Methods of Evaluation of Solid Wastes, Physical/Chemical Methods (EPA Pub. No. SW-846). 
Litter means garbage, refuse, waste materials or any other discarded, used or unconsumed substance which is not handled as specified in this chapter. 
Loading and unloading area means space or area used by any moving vehicle for the purpose of receiving, shipping, and transporting goods, wares, commodities and persons. 
Multiple residential unit means any apartment, group of apartments, condominium or similar multiple-family unit used for dwelling places having more than five units, mobile homes, or dwellings, designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes. 
Municipal solid waste (MSW) means any solid waste resulting from the operation of residential, commercial, governmental, or institutional establishments except such solid waste materials prohibited from disposal in the landfill pursuant to the Rules of Georgia Department of Natural Resources Environmental Protection Division Chapter 391-3-4. 
Person shall mean an individual, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, association, trust, incorporated organization or other entity, or federal, state or local governmental body, unit, authority or agency. 
Public waste receptacle shall mean containers provided by the city or commercial enterprise for the disposal of solid waste and litter from the public streets, alleys, parking lots, etc. 
Putrescible wastes means wastes that are capable of being quickly decomposed by micro-organisms. Examples of putrescible wastes include, but are not necessarily limited to, kitchen wastes, animal manure, offal, hatchery and poultry processing plant wastes, and garbage. 
Recyclable materials means those materials which have known use, reuse or recycling potential; can be feasibly used, reused or recycled; and have been diverted or removed from the solid waste stream for sale, use, reuse or recycling, whether or not requiring subsequent separation and processing. 
Recycling means any process by which reclaimed materials or other materials which would otherwise become solid waste are collected, separated or processed and reused or returned to use in the form of raw materials or products. 
Residential premises shall mean any dwelling, house, residence, building or other structure, including single family homes, duplexes, triplexes, quadraplexes, mobile homes, but excluding multi-family housing such as condominiums, mobile home parks, and apartments having more than five residential units, mobile homes, or dwellings, designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant. 
Residential solid waste means garbage and trash as ordinarily generated at a residence or light commercial unit. By way of example, such waste includes, but is not limited to, waste accumulated from the preparation, processing, consumption, handling, packing, canning, storage and decay of food products, food containers and other consumer goods containers, waste wood, paper, plant, crockery, cloth, glass, small appliances, such as, fans, toasters, lamps, small chairs, packing materials, floor sweepings, and deceased animal matter of less than ten pounds. 
Residential unit means any dwelling occupied by a person or group of persons. Each unit of an apartment, condominium dwelling or multi-family dwelling of any kind, whether of single or multi-level construction, shall be treated as a residential unit. 
Scavenge shall mean the picking from solid waste containers and/or public or private disposal facilities. 
Service area shall mean the incorporated areas of the City of Tifton. 
Solid waste means putrescible and nonputrescible wastes (except water-carried body waste) and shall include garbage, rubbish (paper, cartons, boxes, wood, tree and shrubbery trimmings, yard waste, furniture and appliances, metal, tin cans, glass, crockery, or dunnage), ashes, street refuse, dead animals, sewage sludges, animal manures, industrial wastes (waste materials generated in industrial operations), residue from incineration, food processing wastes, demolition wastes, vehicle waste, dredging wastes, construction wastes, and any other waste material in a solid or semisolid state not otherwise defined in these definitions. 
Solid waste collection service , or substantially similar terms, shall mean the collection, transportation and/or disposal of solid waste from residential premises, light commercial units, multiple residential units and commercial units located in the incorporated area of City of Tifton. 
Solid waste collection franchise or franchise , or substantially similar terms, shall mean the franchise, license and privilege granted and issued by the city to a franchisee to engage in the business, enterprise and commercial activity by such franchisee of offering and providing solid waste collection services to subscribers in the incorporated areas of the city. 
Solid waste collection franchisee or franchisee shall mean a person(s) to whom the city has granted and issued a franchise to engage in the business and operation of providing solid waste collection services in the incorporated areas of City of Tifton. 
Solid waste ordinance or ordinance shall mean this chapter, being the City of Tifton Solid Waste Ordinance, as amended. 
Subscriber shall mean the owner or occupant of a residential premises, commercial units or commercial enterprises in the incorporated areas of the city, who is subscribing to and receiving solid waste collection services from a solid waste collection franchisee. 
Unacceptable solid waste means any and all solid waste which the landfill is not authorized to accept for disposal pursuant to its permits and licenses, including, without limitation, highly flammable substances, hazardous materials (i.e paint, paint products or byproducts, acid of any type, rat or other animal poison, paint thinner, motor oil, insecticides, hazardous waste, and any item containing any type of liquid petroleum product), hazardous waste, certain pathological and biological wastes, explosives, radioactive materials, recycled waste and materials prohibited from disposal in the landfill pursuant to the Rules of Georgia Department of Natural Resources Environmental Protection Division Chapter 391-3-4. 
Yard waste means vegetative matter resulting from landscaping maintenance and land clearing operations other than mining, agricultural and silvicultural operations. This includes lawn, grass or shrubbery clippings, leaves, straw, tree branches, limbs and trunks. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-6. - Responsibility of owners and agents. 
The owners or agents, tenants or lessees of all residential units and commercial establishments shall be responsible for compliance with this chapter. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-7. - Authority, duty of city manager. 
The collection, transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste shall be under the supervision and control of the city manager or his designee. The city manager shall have the authority to establish routes and days of collection, types and locations of municipal solid waste carts and such other matters pertaining to the collection, transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste as he may find necessary, and to change and modify these requirements. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-8. - City collection/franchisee. 
(a)  Residential solid waste, yard waste, bulky waste and commercial and industrial waste which has been handled and segregated pursuant to requirements of this chapter and other applicable law, rules and regulations shall be collected, handled, transported and disposed of by the city or its franchisee, subject to exceptions provided for in this chapter, provided that such solid waste does not contain unacceptable solid waste. 
(b)  The city or its franchisee shall allow each residential unit and light commercial unit up to two solid waste carts; provided, however, upon determination by the city manager, or his designee, that the volume of residential solid waste generated upon such premises cannot be adequately serviced by solid waste carts, then he shall be entitled to require that such premises be serviced by bulk containers rather than solid waste carts. Commercial units and multiple residential units shall be provided bulk containers upon request and upon such terms and conditions that the volume of solid waste generated upon such premises requires. 
(c)  Residential solid waste which has been placed in solid waste carts and placed at designated locations, shall be collected by the city, or its franchisee, on a weekly basis pursuant to this chapter and upon such schedule as shall from time to time be determined or approved by the city manager or his designee. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (c) of this section, the city, or its franchisee, shall provide for the collection of residential solid waste as well as recyclable materials which has been placed in solid waste carts or recyclable carts and which has been generated by the elderly or handicapped persons from a residential unit at locations other than curbside, alleyside or other designated collection site pursuant to policies and procedures promulgated by the city manager from time to time relative to determination and verification of elderly and/or handicap status which renders difficult or impossible for the ability of the occupants of the premises to physically move solid waste or recyclable carts to curbside, alleyside or other designated collection site. 
(e)  In addition to solid waste contained in solid waste carts, the city, or its franchisee, may also collect recyclable materials which has been both: (1) placed curbside, alleyside or other designated collection sites in recyclable carts; and (2) otherwise handled in accordance with all requirements relative thereto. The city may provide for the collection of recyclables at designated collection sites as an alternative to curbside collection. 
(f)  At any time the city, or its franchisee, is engaged in the collection of recyclable materials it shall, from time to time, establish the list of specific items of recyclable materials to be collected. 
(g)  All residential solid waste in excess of that which cannot properly be placed in solid waste carts or recyclable carts (if the city is then engaged in a recyclable solid waste collection service) shall be promptly disposed of by the generators thereof and the owners and occupants of the premises upon which it is generated by: 
(1)  The deposit thereof into a bulk container that is located upon such premises; 
(2)  Delivery thereof to an appropriate designated handling facility of the city; 
(3)  Delivery thereof to a commercial collector authorized to handle, transport and provide for disposal thereof; or 
(4)  Delivery thereof to an authorized handling or disposal site. 
(h)  Notwithstanding the other provisions of this chapter, the city, or its franchisee, shall have the exclusive and sole right to collect any and all municipal solid waste generated within the commercial downtown zoning district of the city. Upon determination by the city manager, that the volume of municipal solid waste generated in the commercial downtown zoning district cannot be adequately or safely serviced by solid waste carts, then he shall be entitled to require that as many solid waste customers as appropriate located within the same city block be serviced by common bulk containers rather than solid waste carts. Such bulk containers shall be placed within city alleys. Residential units shall pay collection fees consistent with published residential rates. Collection fees for commercial and multiple residential units shall be consistent with published commercial rates and shall be based upon usage as determined by the city manager or his designee. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-9. - Private collection prohibited; exception. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to collect and transport municipal solid waste except for: 
(1)  Employees of the city; 
(2)  Persons or entities holding a franchise for the collection and disposal of solid waste within the city or persons authorized to collect solid waste as may from time to time be authorized by the city; 
(3)  Persons transporting municipal solid waste from their own residence, business or industrial property; and 
(4)  Collection and disposal of recyclable materials generated from light commercial units, multiple residential units utilizing bulk containers and commercial units. However, nothing contained herein shall prohibit the collection and disposal of recyclable materials generated from a residential unit by the occupants of the residential unit. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-10. - Required receptacles, containers. 
(a)  It shall be required of every person in possession, charge or control of any place in or from which building materials, solid waste, or industrial waste is accumulated or produced to provide and at all times to keep in a suitable place readily accessible for collection, adequate and suitable receptacles and containers capable of holding all such waste materials which would ordinarily accumulate between the times of successive collections. The city manager, or one designated by him, shall determine the quantity and location of such receptacles, and shall determine whether such receptacles and containers are serviceable. 
(b)  Solid waste carts shall be provided by the city, or its franchisee, for each residential unit which utilizes solid waste carts. If a solid waste cart is damaged due to excessive abuse, gross neglect, intentional damage, or due to fire, the city, or its franchisee, shall have the right to charge for the cost of repair or replacement of the garbage receptacle. The city, or its franchisee, shall make available bulk containers by commercial units and multiple residential units. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-11. - Receptacles and containers to be safe. 
All solid waste and recyclable carts and bulk containers required under this chapter shall be of safe construction and design and shall be maintained in good and serviceable condition at all times. Any carts or containers which do not conform to the provisions of this article, or which have ragged or sharp edges or any other defects likely to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents thereof or the public generally, shall be promptly replaced upon notice. If such container, after proper notice, has not been replaced, the city manager or one designated by him shall have the authority to remove such container as refuse. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-12. - Pre-collection practices. 
(a)  Municipal solid waste (MSW). When practical, all municipal solid waste shall be placed and maintained in carts and containers as specified in this chapter. All carts and containers shall be kept covered at all times. All MSW shall be drained of liquids prior to its placement in the carts. MSW shall be combined with garbage when possible. 
(b)  Garbage. All garbage being placed in carts or containers for collection shall have drained from it all free liquid, and should be wrapped, bagged, or enclosed in paper or plastic material. 
(c)  Injurious trash items. All waste material of an injurious nature, such as broken glass, light bulbs, sharp pieces of metal, fluorescent tubes, and television tubes, shall be securely wrapped to prevent injury to the collection crews. 
(d)  Hazardous waste, hazardous refuse and building materials. No hazardous waste, hazardous refuse or hazardous building materials shall be placed in any cart used for collection of waste, nor shall the hazardous waste, hazardous refuse or hazardous building materials be collected by the city or its franchisee. 
(e)  Yard waste. Yard waste shall be stacked or bundled. Trees and stumps shall not exceed six inches in diameter, and cannot exceed six feet in length. Yard waste material shall not exceed five cubic yards per collection. Tree and shrubbery limbs shall have protruding branches trimmed and must be neatly stacked and placed in an orderly manner at curbside, alley or other designated collection location. 
(f)  Trimmings cut by contractors, etc. Tree and shrubbery branches, yard waste, limbs and trimmings cut by tree service contractors, or resulting from land clearing operations, shall not be collected by the city or its franchisee, but shall be collected and removed by the business or person being paid by the resident for the service. 
(g)  Bulky waste. Bulky waste shall be collected by the city or its franchisee on a regular schedule provided that such items are placed at curbside, alley or other designated location. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-13. - Commercial establishments. 
All commercial establishments shall store their municipal solid waste in containers as specified in this chapter so as to eliminate wind-driven debris and unsightly litter in and about their establishments. Approved methods of containerization include solid waste carts, bulk containers and detachable roll-off containers. Spillage and overflow shall be immediately cleaned up by such establishment when and as it occurs. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-14. - Loading and unloading areas. 
All loading and unloading areas shall be provided with refuse receptacles for loose debris, paper, packaging materials and other trash. The number of containers necessary for each area shall be as required to maintain clean, neat and sanitary premises, as directed by the city manager. The owner of the premises and the occupant thereof shall jointly and severally maintain surveillance to ensure that all litter is placed in the proper container and the area is kept clean. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-15. - Receptacles in parking areas. 
(a)  Obligation to furnish receptacles. All parking lots and establishments with parking lots shall provide municipal solid waste receptacles distributed within the parking area. The city manager shall have the authority to determine the number and types of receptacles necessary to provide containerization. Such receptacles shall be weighted or attached to the ground as necessary to prevent spillage. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or the manager of the parking lot to collect the municipal solid waste and trash deposited in such containers and store this material in an approved location. 
(b)  Obligation to use receptacles. It shall be the obligation of all persons using the parking areas to use such municipal solid waste receptacles or containers as provided in subsection (a) of this section for the purpose intended, and it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to dump, scatter, or throw upon any such parking lot, any municipal solid waste, garbage, or trash of any kind. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-16. - Collection and placement of containers. 
(a)  Roll-off/bulk containers. 
(1)  Placing/pickup. 
a.  Roll-off containers will be placed and collected between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
b.  Collection of commercial units and multiple residential units utilizing bulk containers shall not be collected prior to 7:00 a.m. in residential and residential/professional zoning districts. 
c.  Containers shall be placed in a clear zone as not to block visibility or normal vehicle and/or pedestrian traffic. 
d.  Collection of bulk containers and roll-off containers shall be collected at such intervals as requested by the customer. 
e.  Should the applicant/customer misrepresent what material is to be put in the roll-off container, the unit will be removed and any fees or deposits paid will not be refunded. 
(2)  Liability. 
a.  The city assumes no liability for damage to customer property due to any inferred negligence on the part of the city. 
b.  The customer assumes liability for damages to city equipment caused by overload, misuse or negligence on the part of the customer. 
(b)  Residential waste and recyclable carts/placement for collection. 
(1)  All residential units utilizing solid waste and recyclable carts and light commercial units shall place the carts either at the curbside on a street adjacent to their property, or on their property immediately adjacent to an alley, or other designated collection site, on the days designated by the city manager or the franchisee for pickup. Carts should have at least four feet of clearance on each side from any object including mailboxes, other solid waste and recyclable carts and other garbage receptacles and containers. 
(2)  Residential solid waste shall be collected every week from a 90-gallon cart supplied by the city or its franchisee. Solid waste carts shall be collected from all residential units utilizing solid waste carts and light commercial units one time per week. Only residential solid waste shall be placed in a solid waste cart. 
(3)  Residential recyclable carts shall be collected from all residential units utilizing solid waste carts every other week. Only approved recyclable materials shall be placed in a recyclable cart. Recyclable carts shall be stored near the residence and recyclable carts shall be stored in such a way as to keep the recyclable materials dry. 
(4)  Carts shall be placed by the resident at the designated collection site by 7:00 a.m. on the day of collection. Each resident shall remove his cart from the curbside by 11:00 p.m. on the resident's collection day. If the city or its franchise fails to collect the items from a resident's cart on the regularly scheduled day of collection, the time limits in the immediately preceding sentence shall not apply for that regularly scheduled day of collection. However, in no event shall the cart(s) be left at street side later than 11:00 p.m. on the third day after the regularly scheduled day of collection which was missed. This requirement may be waived for any person physically unable to place the cart(s) at the collection site. Residents must provide proof of the condition in the form of a letter from a medical doctor. Any cart placed on the curb or other designated collection site after the departure of the collection crew shall be at the peril of the owner. Containers and carts not collected as a result of not being at the designated collection site by 7:00 a.m. shall be collected the following regularly scheduled collection day. 
(c)  Collection of bulky waste. Bulky items shall be collected every other week by the city or its franchisee either at the curbside on a street adjacent to their property, or on their property immediately adjacent to an alley, or other designated collection site, on the days designated by the city manager or the franchisee for pickup. Items shall be placed at said locations by 7:00 a.m. on the designated collection day. 
(d)  Collection of yard waste. 
(1)  Yard waste shall be collected by the city or its franchisee on an every other week basis and shall be placed at curbside, in an alley or other designated location four feet from any obstruction for timely collection. Yard waste material shall be placed at said locations by 7:00 a.m. on the designated collection day and shall not be placed in 90- to 100-gallon carts. It shall be unlawful to place or mix yard trimmings with residential solid waste within incorporated City of Tifton. 
(2)  Yard trimmings, if not collected by a franchisee hereunder, shall be disposed of in the following manners: 
a.  Sorted and stockpiled; 
b.  Chipped; 
c.  Composted; 
d.  Used as mulch; 
e.  By otherwise beneficially reusing or recycling it to the maximum extent feasible; or 
f.  At certain types of landfills that are permitted to accept yard trimmings under O.C.G.A. § 12-8-40.2. 
(3)  Each subscriber shall ensure that his yard is free of non-inert material such as paper, metal, plastics and glass. 
(e)  Hazardous waste. No hazardous waste shall be placed in any receptacle used for collection of municipal solid waste by the city or its franchisee or upon, in or across city curbside, alleys or rights-of-way. 
(f)  Dead animals. Owners of small or large dead animals shall be responsible for their removal and disposal. 
(g)  Building materials. Unless placed in a roll-off container, the city or franchisee shall not be responsible for the collecting or hauling of building material originating from private property preliminary to, during or subsequent to the construction of new buildings, alterations or additions to existing buildings of whatever type or from demolition of existing structures. Such material shall be removed by the owner of the property or by the contractor. 
(h)  Hazardous or liquid wastes. Hazardous or liquid waste, or highly combustible industrial waste, shall not be disposed of in the landfill unless permitted under the rules and regulations of the EPD. 
(i)  Accumulations of municipal solid waste and trash. All accumulations of municipal solid waste and trash shall be stored or placed for collection in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Public streets and private property. No person shall place any accumulations of municipal solid waste and trash in any street, median strip, alley or other public place of travel, or upon any private property except as stated in this chapter. 
(2)  Blockage of storm drains. No person shall place any municipal solid waste, trash, yard waste, carts or containers on, upon or over any storm drain, or so close thereto as to be drawn by the elements into such storm drain. 
(3)  Unauthorized accumulations. Any accumulation of municipal solid waste or trash items on any lot, property, premises, public street, alley or other public or private place not permitted by this article, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and is prohibited. Failure of owner or occupant to remove and correct any such accumulation of municipal solid waste shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(4)  Junk. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or leave outside any building or dwelling, except as specified in subsection 66-12(g), any dilapidated furniture, appliance, machinery, equipment, building material, junked motor vehicle, or other item which is either in a wholly or partially rusted, wrecked, junked, dismantled or inoperative condition, and which is not completely enclosed within a building or dwelling. Any such item or items which remain on the property of the occupant for a period of ten days after notice of violation of this section shall be presumed to be abandoned and subject to being removed from the property by the city without further notice. This shall not apply to authorized junk dealers or currently licensed establishments engaged in the repair, rebuilding, reconditioning, or salvaging of equipment or furniture. 
(j)  Holidays. Collections shall not be made on the Thanksgiving or Christmas holidays unless otherwise specified by the city manager. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-17. - Special refuse disposal. 
(a)  Contagious disease refuse. The removal of clothing, bedding or other refuse from homes or other places where highly infectious diseases have prevailed shall be performed under the supervision and direction of the county health department. Such refuse shall not be placed in containers for city collection. 
(b)  Hypodermic instruments. No person shall dispose of or discard any hypodermic syringe, hypodermic needle, or any instrument or device for making hypodermic injections before first breaking, disassembling, destroying or otherwise rendering inoperable and incapable of reuse, such hypodermic syringe, needle, instrument or device, and without safeguarding the disposal thereof by wrapping or securing such material in a suitable manner (such as a sharps container) so as to avoid the possibility of causing injury to the collection personnel. Commercial establishments shall not dispose of hypodermic instruments in solid waste carts or bulk containers. 
(c)  Cardboard boxes and cartons. Prior to depositing refuse for collection in authorized carts or bulk containers, the person disposing of any such boxes or cartons, or the person in charge of the premises, shall collapse all cardboard boxes and cartons. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-18. - Collection charges. 
The city, or its franchisee, shall have exclusive and sole right to collect any and all solid waste generated within the city limits by any residential unit, light commercial unit or commercial unit except as may be otherwise provided in this chapter. All residential units or light commercial units utilizing solid waste carts shall be assessed and must pay a monthly sanitation assessment to the city or franchisee. The monthly sanitation assessment shall include the collection of residential solid waste, recyclable materials, bulky waste and yard waste. Commercial units and multiple residential units utilizing bulk containers shall be charged according to the city's or franchisee's bulk container rate service fee. Residential and light commercial unit cart fees are per cart, per residence (or business), per month. Charges shall be paid to the city or its franchisee for the collection of solid waste, recyclables, yard waste and bulky waste and such charges shall be approved by resolution of the city council. The city may enter into a franchise or inter-local governmental contracts for sanitation collection services. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-19. - Determination of violations; complaints. 
(a)  Code enforcement officials, the city manager or his designee shall be responsible for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and shall substantiate complaints of violations of any provisions of this chapter. Code enforcement officials, the city manager or his designee shall determine if there has been a violation and shall initiate requests for compliance with this chapter from the person alleged to be in violation of this chapter. 
(b)  Code enforcement officials, the city manager or his designee shall be authorized to issue a citation against a violator of this chapter. The alleged violator shall be prosecuted in the municipal court. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-20. - Violations; penalties. 
Any person violating or failing, refusing or neglecting to comply with any provision, requirement, or section of this chapter, after conviction in the municipal court, may be punished as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Secs. 66-21—66-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DISPOSAL SITES 

Sec. 66-61. - Use authorized; regulation. 
All acceptable solid waste shall be delivered and deposited in the Tifton/Tift County Landfill or at authorized disposal sites in accordance with the directions and orders of the city manager, or his representative in charge of operations, and in accordance with the requirements of this chapter; except, however, privately operated sites may be used for the sanitary disposal of industrial wastes or other specified waste upon the approval of the city manager, and upon the issuance of appropriate disposal permits, as required by the regulations of the Rules of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division Chapter 391-3-4.02 and other applicable state or federal agencies. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-62. - Disposal sites—Designation. 
(a)  Disposal sites approved for the disposal of municipal solid waste shall be designated by appropriate signs posted near the roadside at the location of the sanitary landfill. 
(b)  Disposal sites shall be maintained in use until permanently closed, at which time additional authorized sites shall be opened and publicized by posting and through the press. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-63. - Operating hours. 
Authorized disposal sites shall be operated Monday through Friday of each week, with the exception of the Thanksgiving and Christmas (or such other holidays that may from time to time be designated by the city manager), from 7:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Saturdays 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 noon, and from 7:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. on the following holidays: 
New Year's Day 
Martin Luther King's Birthday (third Monday in January) 
Good Friday 
Memorial Day 
Independence Day 
Labor Day (first Monday in September) 
Christmas Eve 
During such hours, acceptable solid waste generated in the city shall be received for disposal from any resident of the city. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-64. - When use authorized; ownership of waste. 
No person shall enter a disposal site except when an attendant is present and during the hours and days prescribed in section 66-63. All materials delivered and deposited for disposal on the grounds or disposal sites shall be the property of the city. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-65. - Scavenging prohibited. 
No person shall be permitted to scavenge or reclaim any refuse that has been deposited in a solid waste or recyclable cart, bulk container or public waste receptacle, including the landfill or service centers. Notwithstanding the foregoing, employees operating the landfill may reclaim recyclables delivered to the landfill. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-66. - Prohibited types or categories of solid waste. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, no unacceptable solid waste as defined herein shall be deposited upon or disposed of in the landfill or disposal site owned or operated by the city, either individually, or jointly with any other governmental entity. The city manager shall have authority to refuse any waste considered unsuitable for disposal in the city's disposal site, or place restrictions on disposal time, volume disposed, advanced notification, delivery methods, testing, certification, separation according to type, etc., to facilitate safer or more efficient disposal. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-67. - Private disposal sites—Permit, acceptance required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or permit to be deposited on land under his ownership and control any solid waste without first having obtained a disposal area permit as required by the regulations of the Rules of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources, Environmental Protection Division Chapter 391-3-4 and other applicable state or federal agencies. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-68. - General maintenance. 
It shall be the duty and responsibility of the owner of any private disposal site to keep the site in an orderly condition and maintained so as not to be a public nuisance or a menace to public health. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-69. - Right to enter to inspect. 
The city manager, his designated representative, or authorized representative of the department of public health, shall be permitted to enter any private disposal site at any time during normal business hours for free and unhindered inspections to determine compliance with this chapter and all other pertinent laws and regulations. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-70. - Burning. 
The city shall have authority to utilize an air curtain destructor at its disposal sites in accordance with EPD regulations and guidelines. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-71. - Fees; landfills and disposal sites. 
The charges to be made and collected for all deposits and disposals made at or upon all landfills and solid waste disposal sites owned or operated by the city either individually or jointly with any other governmental entity for acceptable solid waste and which are not prohibited for deposit or disposal at such landfills or disposal sites shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-72. - Waste, trash coming from outside county restricted. 
It is prohibited for any waste or trash coming from outside the county to be carried and dumped at the landfill unless such waste or trash from outside the county is covered by; 
(1)  An inter-local government agreement between the city and the applicable local governing body with original jurisdiction over such waste or trash; 
(2)  Contract with any private hauler; or 
(3)  Approval by the city manager. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-73. - Failure of individual or legal entity not holding permit to deliver solid waste to landfill; civil fines. 
Any individual or entity not holding a permit but disposing of solid waste generated within the geographical limits of the city who fails to deliver such solid waste to the landfill shall be subject to civil fines not to exceed $1,000.00 per offense. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-74—66-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TIFTON-TIFT COUNTY LANDFILL 

Sec. 66-91. - Delivery of municipal solid waste to landfill required. 
All acceptable solid waste generated within geographical limits of the city must be delivered to the Tifton-Tift County landfill for disposal. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-92. - Uniform tipping fee. 
All acceptable solid waste generated within Tift County and disposed of at the landfill shall be subject to a uniform tipping fee, as set from time to time consistent with applicable law, regardless of whether such solid waste is delivered by: 
(1)  A public or private hauler; or 
(2)  An individual or entity who/that generates such solid waste and presents it for disposal at the landfill. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-93—66-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PERMITTING/FRANCHISE COLLECTION 

Sec. 66-100. - Collection and disposal services—Generally. 
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, no person shall engage in the business, enterprise or commercial activity of providing all or any part of solid waste collection services within the incorporated areas of the city except pursuant to a solid waste collection franchise issued under section 66-101 or a temporary permit issued under section 66-103. Any person who so engages in the business, enterprise or commercial activity of providing any solid waste collection services within the incorporated areas of the city except pursuant to a solid waste collection franchise shall be in direct violation of this chapter and subject to penalties as specified in sections 66-112 or 66-73. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-101. - Solid waste collection franchise. 
In order to protect the health, safety and welfare of persons, property and the environment in the incorporated areas of the city, and to provide for and regulate uniform collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste in the incorporated areas of the city, the city may issue either an exclusive franchise to a single person or a non-exclusive franchise to multiple persons for the conduct by a business, enterprise or commercial activity of solid waste collection services in the incorporated areas of the city. Each such franchise shall contain such terms and conditions, not inconsistent with this chapter, as the city may deem appropriate. Any franchise issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to all terms and conditions imposed by this chapter, other applicable ordinances and resolutions of the city, together with all other applicable federal, state or local laws, statutes, rules and regulations. Prior to issuance of a franchise, the applicant shall provide to the city (i) evidence as required by O.C.G.A. § 36-60-6 that the franchisee is authorized to use the federal work authorization program (or evidence that it is not required by O.C.G.A. § 36-60-6 to provide such evidence) and (ii) evidence pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 50-36-1 that the applicant is lawfully present in the United States. The franchisee shall utilize the federal work authorization program as required by O.C.G.A. § 36-60-6. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-102. - Franchise fee. 
Each person issued and holding a valid franchise pursuant to this chapter shall pay such franchise fee as the city council shall from time to time determine. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-103. - Temporary permit. 
For good cause shown and upon such terms and conditions as the city may reasonably require, a "temporary permit" for engaging in the business of solid waste collection services may be issued by the city manager or his designee for a period not to exceed 30 calendar days from the issuance date thereof. At the conclusion of such initial 30 days term of a temporary permit, up to two additional 15-day extensions may be granted if justification for such extension is presented to and accepted by the city manager or his or her designee. The temporary permit issued pursuant to this section (or a legible copy) must be posted and visible at all times on any vehicle used by the temporary permit holder in its solid waste collection activities. As a condition to the issuance of a temporary permit pursuant to this section, the permit holder shall maintain such insurance, agree to indemnification of the city, and post a performance bond in favor of the city, in each case on such terms and conditions as the city manager may require. Prior to issuance of a temporary permit, the applicant shall provide to the city (i) evidence as required by O.C.G.A. § 36-60-6 that the temporary permit holder is authorized to use the federal work authorization program (or evidence that it is not required by O.C.G.A. § 36-60-6 to provide such evidence) and (ii) evidence pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 50-36-1 that the applicant is lawfully present in the United States. The temporary permit holder shall utilize the federal work authorization program as required by O.C.G.A. § 36-60-6. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-104. - Use of city streets, roads and alleys. 
In furtherance of the city's protection of the health, safety and welfare of persons, property and the environment in the incorporated areas of the city by providing uniform collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste in such incorporated areas, and as an exercise of the city's police powers, a franchisee or holder of a temporary permit shall be permitted and authorized to use and travel upon the public roads and rights of way, together with private streets, roadways and alleys that are customarily and generally utilized by the traveling public located in private developments and subdivisions. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-105. - Exclusive service by franchisees; fees. 
Person(s) holding a franchise (or a temporary permit) shall exclusively provide solid waste collection service in the incorporated areas of the city, and each franchisee shall offer its services to each and every residential premises or commercial enterprise within the entire incorporated areas of the city. A franchisee shall charge its subscribers the same uniform fees for such franchisee's various solid waste collection services, and further shall not charge fees for its solid waste collection services in excess of those fees as are set forth in its franchise. In addition to the specific solid waste collection services and the fees therefore as set forth in the franchise granted by the city, a franchisee may offer to its subscribers such related special services and charge reasonable and uniform fees therefor, in each case as approved in advance in writing by the city manager; provided, however, that no subscriber shall be required to utilize such special services and may contract with third parties for provision thereof. A "special service" is a service that is not required to be provided by the franchisee under the terms of the franchise. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-106. - Residential collection service rules. 
(a)  Collection of residential solid waste. 
(1)  The franchisee shall collect residential solid waste from all residential units utilizing solid waste carts and light commercial units in accordance with section 66-16(b). The franchisee shall provide a 90- to 100-gallon cart to each subscriber. Carts shall remain the property of the franchisee. It shall be the responsibility of the subscriber to properly use and safeguard the carts. Franchisee shall maintain carts in a reasonably good condition. Franchisee shall have the right to charge subscribers for the cost of repair or replacement of carts, if such repair or replacement is required as a result of subscriber's excessive abuse, gross neglect or intentional damage, or due to fire. Franchisee shall replace carts at no additional charge due to theft. The color shall be selected or agreed upon by the city. 
(2)  Subscribers may request one additional cart for the approved contract price between the city and the franchisee for an additional volume of residential solid waste. 
(3)  Franchisee shall not be responsible for the collection of residential solid waste not placed in a cart, from any cart not in the proper location described in the franchise, or waste other than residential solid waste, unless otherwise provided for in the franchise. 
(4)  The franchisee shall dispose of all residential solid waste at the landfill and shall be responsible for the payment of all fees associated with disposal. The franchisee shall be acting under contract with and on behalf of the city and franchisee shall pay the uniform tipping fee. 
(b)  Collection of bulky waste. The franchisee shall collect residential solid waste from all residential premises in accordance with section 66-16(b). Franchisee shall be responsible for the proper disposal of all bulky items. 
(c)  Collection of recyclables. 
(1)  The franchisee shall collect recyclable materials from all residential units, light commercial units and multiple residential units utilizing solid waste carts in accordance with section 66-16(c). Residential recycling shall be collected from a 90- to 100-gallon recyclable cart container supplied by franchisee. Recyclable carts shall remain the property of the franchisee. It shall be the responsibility of the subscriber to properly use and safeguard the recyclable cart(s) provided to him. A franchisee shall maintain its recyclable carts in a reasonably good condition. Franchisee shall have the right to charge subscribers for the cost of repair or replacement of carts, if such repair or replacement is required as a result of subscriber's excessive abuse, gross neglect or intentional damage, or due to fire. Franchisee shall replace carts at no additional charge due to theft. The color shall be selected or agreed upon by the city. 
(2)  Franchisee shall be responsible for the disposal of recyclable waste through agreements negotiated between third party recycling agents. Contractor shall provide the city with a monthly report which calculates the total amount of recyclables delivered to each third party vendor. 
(3)  Subscribers may request one additional recyclable cart for the approved contract price between the city and franchisee for an additional volume of recycling service. 
(d)  Collection of yard waste. 
(1)  The franchisee shall collect yard waste from all residential premises in accordance with section 66-17(d). The franchisee shall be responsible for the proper disposal of all yard waste material at the Tifton/Tift County Inert Landfill. 
(2)  Yard trimmings shall not be disposed of at any solid waste disposal site with liners or leachate collection systems or any solid waste landfills which have received a vertical expansion under O.C.G.A. § 12-8-40.2. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-107. - Collection of light commercial, commercial/industrial waste. 
Franchisee will provide collection of all incorporated commercial customers currently serviced by the city. Franchisee shall collect commercial/industrial waste from apartments, schools, institutional organizations, small businesses, manufacturing concerns, etc. This aspect of the work will be driven by customer demand, but generally may provide for the use of 90- to 100-gallon cans; four-, six- and eight-yard dumpsters; and twenty-, thirty-, and forty-yard roll offs. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-108. - Hours of collection. 
(a)  Collection of residential solid waste and recyclable materials shall not start before 7:00 a.m., shall conclude collection by sunset as recorded by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and shall be conducted on weekdays only; except in the event of holidays or unavoidable equipment issues which prevent compliance with this provision on a short term basis and except to perform emergency work or service required to safeguard the immediate health, safety and welfare of the public. In performing its solid waste collection services, any person providing solid waste collection services (whether or not residential) shall not create undue disturbance or noise in residential areas in performing its collection activities. 
(b)  Collection of commercial units and multiple residential units utilizing bulk containers shall not be collected prior to 7:00 a.m. in residential and residential/professional zoning districts. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-109. - Disposal of solid waste and yard waste. 
Delivery of acceptable solid waste to the landfill: Franchisee shall deliver acceptable solid waste collected in its hauling business to the landfill. Franchisee shall not deliver any unacceptable solid waste to the landfill. Franchisee shall deliver yard waste collected in its hauling business to the Tifton/Tift County Inert Landfill. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-110. - Waste delivery vehicles. 
Franchisee shall deliver acceptable solid waste to the landfill at its expense, in enclosed container vehicles or enclosed compactor vehicles with leak resistant bodies complying in all material respects with all applicable regulations or procedures which are required by any governmental entity, including, but not limited to, any local rules and the permits pertaining to the landfill. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-111. - Excluded services. 
In providing its solid waste collection services hereunder, a franchisee shall not be required to collect, handle, remove or transport materials which exhibit any of the following characteristics: toxic, ignitable, reactive, corrosive or any other item or material of a clearly hazardous, or of a dangerous nature. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Sec. 66-112. - Failure of permitted individual or legal entity to deliver solid waste to landfill; sanctions. 
Any individual or legal entity required to be permitted under the provisions of sections 66-101 and/or 66-103 for collection of municipal solid waste generated within the geographical limits of the city who/which then fails to deliver such solid waste for disposal at the Tifton-Tift County landfill shall be subject to the following sanctions: 
(1)  Revocation of collection permit; and/or 
(2)  Civil fines in the amount of $1,000.00 per offense. Each bulk container or solid waste cart of municipal solid waste generated within the geographical limits of the city and collected but not delivered to the Tifton-Tift County landfill for disposal shall constitute a separate offense. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Secs. 66-113—66-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OTHER 

Sec. 66-120. - Severability of provisions. 
If any article, section, part, subpart, subsection, paragraph, item, sentence, clause, phrase or word of this chapter is declared or adjudged to be invalid or unconstitutional, such declaration or adjudication shall not affect the remaining provisions or portion of this chapter, which shall remain of full force and effect as if such portions so declared or adjudged invalid or unconstitutional were not originally a part of this chapter. The city council declares that it would have enacted the remaining provisions or parts of this chapter had it known that such portion hereof would be declared and adjudged invalid or unconstitutional. 
( Ord. No. 2014-25 , 12-1-2014) 
Chapter 70 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(6); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-6(9); any ordinance establishing or prescribing street grades in the city saved from repeal, § 1-6(15); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; moving buildings, § 18-91 et seq.; cemeteries, ch. 26; floods, ch. 42; skating on streets, § 46-6; congregating on streets, sidewalks, § 46-65; parks and recreation, ch. 50; planning and zoning, ch. 54; public safety, ch. 58; sewers, ch. 62; maintenance of property; sweeping litter into streets, § 66-7; traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 78; bicycles prohibited on sidewalks, § 78-12; driving on play streets, § 78-34; stopping, standing and parking, § 78-76 et seq.; utilities, ch. 82; vegetation, ch. 86; location of street trees, § 86-3; street trees and public utilities, § 86-4; vehicles for hire, ch. 90; zoning, app. A; subdivisions, app. B; street paving in subdivisions, app. B, § 6-7.

IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; state, county and municipal road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Obstructions on sidewalks and streets. 
It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to obstruct any sidewalk, street, alley or public road in the city by placing, maintaining or keeping anything in or on any sidewalk, street, alley or public road in the city. In construing this section, where a building abuts a sidewalk it will be presumed that the sidewalk encompasses the land up to the edge of the building. 
(Code 1974, § 23-2) 
Sec. 70-2. - Dangerous conditions to be marked at night. 
All parties making or causing to be made any excavation, or placing or causing to be placed any obstruction of any character of such nature as to endanger the safety of persons or property in any street, alley, unenclosed lot or public place within the city, are hereby required to place and keep continually burning at nighttime, in and around such excavation or obstruction, a sufficient number of red danger signal lights, not exceeding 50 feet apart, to put the public on full notice of such place or thing of danger. 
(Code 1974, § 23-3) 
Sec. 70-3. - Installation of driveways. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to lay, install or establish across any sidewalk or sidewalk line within the city any driveway for the passage of vehicles, without first having applied for and obtained from the city manager written permission for the installation of such driveway, and without laying, installing and establishing the driveway in strict compliance with directions given by the city manager concerning the method in which such driveway shall be constructed or installed. 
(Code 1974, § 23-4) 
Sec. 70-4. - Dangerous or unsatisfactory railroad crossings. 
If the city council shall have reason to believe any crossing by a railroad of any street in the city is in dangerous or unsatisfactory condition, it shall give notice to the agent of such railroad of a hearing on the matter, which shall be held not less than ten days after such notice. If, upon such hearing, the council shall find that such crossing is in fact dangerous or unsatisfactory, it shall order it repaired or replaced. Failure of the railroad to obey such order shall be an offense against this Code. 
(Code 1974, § 23-5) 
Sec. 70-5. - Railroads obstructing crossings. 
It shall be unlawful for a railroad to block or otherwise close or obstruct any of the street or public road crossings in the city for a longer time than five minutes; provided, however, between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. such crossings, if necessary, may be blocked for a period not exceeding ten minutes. 
(Code 1974, § 23-6) 
Sec. 70-6. - Location of gasoline pumps and filling stations. 
(a)  No gasoline filling stations shall be permitted to be installed on the sidewalks, but all such stations within the city shall be installed as turn-in stations; the pumps shall be installed well within the property line so that vehicles being served will not be an obstruction to traffic, either on the streets or sidewalks. 
(b)  No gasoline pump shall be placed closer than 15 feet to the property line, and in the event a gasoline pump is placed between the property line and the filling station building, the building shall not be placed closer than 25 feet to the property line. 
(Code 1974, § 23-7) 
Secs. 70-7—70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BASIC STREET SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 70-31. - Establishment of street, grade lines; compliance therewith. 
The city engineer shall establish grade lines from such points as the city council may decide upon and, from time to time, such street lines as persons and corporations contemplating the erection of buildings may demand. All buildings and structures of any character whatsoever in the city, whenever the buildings and structures are to be erected abutting on any sidewalk or within five feet of any sidewalk in the city, must be erected in conformity to such grade and street lines. 
(Code 1974, § 23-1) 
Sec. 70-32. - Designation of streets. 
All streets in the city will be designated as one of the following: 
(1)  Primary route; 
(2)  Secondary route; 
(3)  Main artery. 
(Code 1974, § 23-9(a)) 
Sec. 70-33. - Manner of designation. 
The designation of a street in the city will be determined by a committee composed of the city manager, the city engineer and the public works director and shall be approved by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 23-9(b)) 
Sec. 70-34. - Right-of-way widths. 
The right-of-way for all primary routes and secondary routes in the city shall be 60 feet and the right-of-way for all main arteries shall be 80 feet. 
(Code 1974, § 23-9(c)) 
Sec. 70-35. - Width of paving. 
(a)  The width of paving or asphalt placed on streets designated as secondary routes shall be 26 feet and the width of the curb and gutter shall be four feet. 
(b)  The width of paving or asphalt placed on streets designated as primary routes shall be 32 feet and the width of the curb and gutter shall be four feet. 
(c)  The width of the paving or asphalt placed on streets designated as main arteries shall be 44 feet and the width of the curb and gutter shall be four feet, but adjoining property owners shall be assessed for only 32 feet of paving plus the curb and gutter. 
(Code 1974, § 23-9(d)) 
Sec. 70-36. - Extension of present rights-of-way. 
All present rights-of-way of streets in the city will be extended as they now exist. 
(Code 1974, § 23-9(e)) 
Sec. 70-37. - Prerequisites to acceptance of street dedication. 
In any area of the city which has not been developed and the streets cut up to the present time, before any street dedicated to the city is accepted by the city, a plat must be submitted by the owner or developer to the city council showing the width of the proposed streets and the width of the proposed paving and proposed width of the curb and gutter. Before the dedication of the street is accepted by the city, all of the following must occur: 
(1)  The city council must approve the right-of-way width, the paving width, and, where applicable, the curb and gutter width. 
(2)  The developer will be responsible for 100 percent of the costs of all materials to establish and construct a street upon rights-of-way dedicated to the city to include paving, stormwater drainage, and, where applicable, curb and gutter. 
(3)  The city may, at its sole option, provide a portion of the labor and equipment costs for preparation of the new street for paving and curb and gutter and stormwater drainage installation. 
(4)  The developer will be responsible for 100 percent of the costs of all materials to install water and sewer utilities and service within the new street. 
(5)  The city may, at its sole option, provide a portion of the labor and equipment costs utilized to install water and sewer utilities within such street. 
(6)  The developer may provide for the paving, curb and gutter, stormwater drainage, and water and sewer utilities separate and apart from any participation by the city. However, the developer must provide an agreement acceptable to the city that all work will be done in accordance with city specifications and that such developer will warrant to the city all work for a period of two years from the date that the committee composed of the city manager, the city engineer, and the public works director approve and accept, subject to the aforesaid warranty, such work. At the expiration of two years from such acceptance date, the paved street and all subject utilities will become the maintenance responsibility of the city. The developer will correct, at his expense, any defects that arise or occur or become manifest within the two-year warranty period. 
(Code 1974, § 23-9(f)) 
Sec. 70-38. - Determination of width of streets and paving for future annexed land. 
For any area of land annexed to the city in the future, the width of the streets, the width of the paving and the width of the curb and gutter will be determined by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 23-9(g)) 
Sec. 70-39. - Street and right-of-way classification map. 
The committee mentioned in this article will prepare a street and right-of-way classification map, which map will depict all streets in the city showing the designations of streets and the widths of paving or asphalt and the widths of curb and gutter required. This map shall be kept up to date by the committee and a copy of such map shall be maintained at all times in the office of the clerk of the city and the office of the city manager. 
(Code 1974, § 23-9(h)) 
Secs. 70-40—70-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS AND STREET CUTS 

Sec. 70-61. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person or entity to:
