(1)  Cut or remove any portion of the surface treatment (whether asphalt, concrete, dirt or other covering or topping) of any public highway, street or alley or any portion of any sidewalk, curb or gutter which is within any public right-of-way located in the city; or 
(2)  Make any excavation within the right-of-way of any public highway, street or alley located in the city; 
without first having obtained a permit from the city therefor. 
(Code 1974, § 23-21) 
Sec. 70-62. - Applications for permits. 
Prior to the issuance of any permit required pursuant to section 70-61, the applicant for such permit shall file with the city a written application in such substance and form as shall from time to time be required therefor and containing at least the following information: 
(1)  The name, business address, social security number or federal tax identification number, business telephone number and home telephone number of the applicant; 
(2)  The name, business address, social security number or federal tax identification number, business telephone number and home telephone number of any person or entity who will be performing such work if different from the applicant; 
(3)  The name, business address, social security number or federal tax identification number, business telephone number and home telephone number of the person or entity for whom such work will be performed or installation made; 
(4)  The experience, relative to the types of work proposed to be performed, of the person or entity who will perform such proposed work; 
(5)  The exact location of the proposed excavation and/or cut; 
(6)  The dimensions of the proposed excavation and/or cut; 
(7)  The purpose of the proposed excavation and/or cut; 
(8)  The nature and extent of precautions which will be utilized so as to prevent danger to the public from the proposed excavation and/or cut; 
(9)  The nature and extent of precautions which will be utilized so as to prevent any such proposed excavation from becoming flooded; 
(10)  The nature and extent of any installation to be made following any such proposed excavation and the details of such proposed installation; 
(11)  The anticipated date of commencement of such excavation and/or cut; 
(12)  The anticipated duration of time necessary to complete such work; and 
(13)  The location of site of proposed work, including approximate distances and directions, with respect to nearby streets, alleys, intersections, utilities, and public places and grounds. 
(Code 1974, § 23-22) 
Sec. 70-63. - Filing of application. 
Applications required pursuant to section 70-62 shall be filed with the director of public works of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 23-23) 
Sec. 70-64. - Permit fee. 
All applications for permits required pursuant to section 70-61 shall be accompanied, at the time of the filing thereof, by payment by the applicant to the city of the permit fee therefor in such amount as shall be prescribed from time to time by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 23-24) 
Sec. 70-65. - Bond requirements. 
All applications for permits required pursuant to section 70-61 shall be accompanied, at the time of the filing thereof, by a written bond in the amount of $2,000.00 with the surety of a company authorized to transact a surety business in the state conditioned that the applicant for such permit and all persons and entities operating pursuant thereto will fully and faithfully comply with and observe all requirements, conditions and obligations with respect to such permit and will indemnify and hold harmless the city of and from any and all costs, loss, expenses, damages, obligations and liabilities which the city shall sustain or incur as a result of the failure of the applicant for such permit or any person or entity operating pursuant to such permit to fully and faithfully comply with and observe all requirements, conditions and obligations with respect to such permit; provided that in lieu of such surety bond the applicant may elect to post a cash bond with the city for such amount. 
(Code 1974, § 23-25) 
Sec. 70-66. - Posting of cost to cure. 
All applications for permits required pursuant to section 70-61 shall be accompanied, at the time of the filing thereof, by the payment to the city of a deposit in an amount equal to the cost, as reasonably estimated by the director of public works of the city, to the city for the replacing of the surface treatment of any highway, street or alley proposed to be cut or removed and/or for the replacing of any sidewalk, curb or gutter following completion of the work proposed relative thereto. 
(Code 1974, § 23-26) 
Sec. 70-67. - Action on application. 
Upon satisfaction of the requirements of sections 70-62, 70-64, 70-65 and 70-66, the director of public works of the city shall, upon his determination that under all circumstances surrounding issuance of the permit applied for would not be adverse to the interest of the city or the public, issue the permit for such period of duration as he shall deem appropriate for the accomplishment of such work subject to such restrictions, limitations and conditions as he shall determine to be appropriate under the circumstances. 
(Code 1974, § 23-27) 
Sec. 70-68. - Expiration of permits. 
All rights and authorizations to perform any activity pursuant to any permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article, and well as such permit itself, shall expire and terminate upon the earliest of the following: 
(1)  The date of expiration thereof established in such permit except to the extent the date of expiration may be extended because of providential cause; or 
(2)  Sixty days following the date of the issuance of such permit, if the work authorized pursuant to such permit has not commenced on or prior to such date. 
(Code 1974, § 23-28) 
Sec. 70-69. - Notification of utilities. 
No later than 24 hours prior to the commencement of any work authorized pursuant to a permit issued in accordance with this article, the applicant for such permit shall notify the building inspector of the city and all utility companies having wires, conduits, pipes and other facilities which are located with 25 feet of the outside dimensions of the site upon which such work will be performed of the date of commencement of such work as well as the location and nature thereof. 
(Code 1974, § 23-29) 
Sec. 70-70. - Restrictions on work. 
All work authorized by a permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall at all times be fully and faithfully performed in a competent and workmanlike manner and in accordance with: 
(1)  All professional, code, and safety standards applicable thereto; 
(2)  All conditions, limitations and restrictions contained in such permit; 
(3)  All rules, regulations, ordinances and laws applicable thereto; and 
(4)  All directions and requirements of the director of public works of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 23-30) 
Sec. 70-71. - Revocation of permit. 
Upon the failure of the applicant for a permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article or any person or entity performing work pursuant to such permit to comply with the provisions of section 70-69 or 70-70, then the director of public works of the city may revoke such permit whereupon all rights and authorizations to perform any work permitted thereby shall total cease and expire. 
(Code 1974, § 23-31) 
Sec. 70-72. - Backfill. 
Promptly upon completion of work for which an excavation permit is issued pursuant to this article, the holder of the permit therefor shall backfill, or at such holder's sole expense cause to be backfilled, the excavation so made with such materials as shall be required by such permit or by the director of public works of the city to a level of density and compactness as shall permit restoration of the surface treatment of the highway, street or alley to the same condition as existed prior to such excavation, all to the satisfaction of the director of public works of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 23-32) 
Sec. 70-73. - Resurfacing and restoration. 
Upon completion of the required backfill of an excavation or upon completion of work which occasioned the cutting or removal of any surface treatment of any highway, street or alley or any portion of any sidewalk, curb or gutter which is within any public right-of-way, the director of public works of the city shall cause such surface treatment, sidewalk, curb and/or gutter to be repaired or resurfaced as necessary to return the surface treatment, sidewalk, curb and/or gutter to the same condition as existed prior to work performed pursuant to such permit. 
(Code 1974, § 23-33) 
Sec. 70-74. - Reimbursement of cost to cure. 
(a)  The city shall refund to the holder of any permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article the difference between the deposit posted pursuant to section 70-66 and the cost to cure pursuant to section 70-73, less any and all costs, losses, damages, expenses, obligations and liabilities sustained or incurred by the city due to failure of the holder of such permit to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The holder of a permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall, within 30 days of notification of the amount thereof, pay to the city the amount of the difference between the amount of cost to cure pursuant to section 70-73 and the deposit posted pursuant to section 70-66 plus any and all costs, losses, damages, expenses, obligations and liabilities sustained or incurred by the city due to failure of the holder of such permit to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1974, § 23-34) 
Sec. 70-75. - Execution. 
Failure of the holder of any permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article within 30 days of notification thereof to pay all amounts due to the city as required pursuant to the provisions of section 70-74 shall authorize the issuance of execution therefor against the holder of such permit as in the case of execution for taxes due to the city and authorize the city to proceed with respect to the bond posted by the holder of such permit. 
(Code 1974, § 23-35) 
Chapter 74 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-6(2); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-6(9); any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not included in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-6(14); administration, ch. 2; businesses and business regulations, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— Local government budgets and audits, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-1 et seq.; accounting for public funds, O.C.G.A. § 45-8-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 74-1—74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATION TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2017-16, § I, adopted October 16, 2007, in effect repealed the former art. II., §§ 74-31—74-73, and enacted a new art. II as set out herein. The former art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 99-37, adopted October 4, 1999; and Ord. No. 2008-24, adopted November 3, 2008. 
State Law reference— Business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq. 

Sec. 74-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Administrative fee means a component of an occupational tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. 
Dominant line means the type of business within a multiple line business that the greatest amount of income is derived from. 
Engaged in business means doing or performing any act of selling any goods or services, or soliciting business, or offering any good or services for sale primarily in attempt to make a profit, including selling or performing services of the character of a wholesaler or retailer, or being involved in any of the functions performed as a manufacturer, or renting real or personal property; all of the foregoing performed either as an owner, operator or agent of any business, trade, profession, or occupation within the city. 
Gross receipts mean the total revenue of the business or practitioner for the period, including without limitation, to the following: 
(1)  Total income without deduction for the cost of goods or expenses incurred; 
(2)  Gain from trading in stocks, bonds, capital assets or instruments of indebtedness; 
(3)  Proceeds from commissions on the sale of property, goods or services; 
(4)  Proceeds from fees for services rendered; and 
(5)  Proceeds from rent, interest, royalty or dividend income. 
The term "gross receipts" shall not include the following: 
(1)  Sales, use or excise tax; 
(2)  Sales returns, allowances and discounts; 
(3)  Inter-organizational sales or transfers between or among the units of a parent-subsidiary controlled group of corporations as defined by 26 USC 1563(a)(1), or between or among the units of a brother-sister controlled group of corporations as defined by 26 USC 1563(a)(2); 
(4)  Payments made to a subcontractor or an independent agent; and 
(5)  Governmental and foundation grants, charitable contributions or the interest income derived from such funds received by an organization which employs salaried practitioners otherwise covered by this chapter, if such funds constitute 80 percent or more of the organization's receipts. 
Landlord means any person, firm, corporation or other business entity that rents or leases realty consisting of at least either three units or 4,000 square feet (regardless of the number of units). In determining residential dwelling units, the structure upon which the landlord claims homestead tax exemption shall be excluded from the computation. In determining commercial units, any structure occupied by the landlord or by an entity that includes the landlord shall be excluded from the computation. 
Location or office includes any structure or vehicle where a business, profession, or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction work site which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. The renter's or lessee's location which is the site of personal property which is rented or leased from another does not constitute a location or office for the personal property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor. The site of real property which is rented or leased to another does not constitute a location or office for the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor unless the real property's owner, lessor, or the agent of the owner or lessor, in addition to showing the property to prospective lessees or tenants and performing maintenance or repair of the property, otherwise conducts the business of renting or leasing the real property at such site or otherwise conducts any other business, profession, or occupation at such site. 
Nonprofit organization means an organization which is formed for a purpose not involving pecuniary remuneration, directly or indirectly, to its shareholders or members as such. Such organizations encompass those, which are truly altruistic as well as those whose aid is limited to its membership. 
Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession or business for revenue raising purposes. 
Person includes sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofit, or any other form of business organization, but specifically excludes charitable nonprofit organizations which utilize 50 percent or more of their proceeds for charitable purposes. 
Practitioner of profession or occupation is one who by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. The term "practitioners of professions and occupations" shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. 
Regulatory fees mean payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or as an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact fees as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(8) or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § 1, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-32. - Tax required. 
Each person engaged in any business, trade, profession or occupation in the city, whether with a location in the city, or in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in the state exerting substantial efforts within the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, shall pay an annual occupation tax for such business, trade, profession or occupation; which tax and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in the city. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in the city, such business tax registration shall be shown to the city clerk or his deputies or to any police officer upon his or their request. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § 1, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-33. - Purpose and scope of tax. 
The occupation tax levied in this article is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5—48-13-26. The penalties for delinquency for these businesses are civil in nature and do not include incarceration. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § 1, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-34. - Administrative and regulatory fee structure; tax structure. 
(a)  A non-prorated, nonrefundable administrative fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges in an amount as set from time to time by resolution of the city council and on file in the office of the city clerk shall be required on all business occupation tax accounts for the initial start-up, renewal or reopening of those accounts. 
(b)  A regulatory fee will be imposed as provided under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9 on those applicable businesses. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. 
(c)  The regulatory fee schedule for persons in occupations and professions set forth in subsection (b) of this section shall be such sum as may be established from time to time by resolution of the city council as is necessary to reasonably cover the city's expense in investigation and/or inspection as provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-35. - Levied; restrictions. 
(a)  An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices within the city or upon the applicable out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7 based upon the following criteria: gross receipts of the business or practitioner in combination with the profitability ratio for the type of business, profession or occupation as measured by nationwide averages derived from statistics, classifications or other information published by the United States Office of Management and Budget, the United States Internal Revenue Service or successor agencies of the United States. 
(b)  The gross brackets classification for each business, trade, profession or occupation shall be as set forth in the following schedule: 
Section 28 - Gross Brackets Classification Schedule 

 
(c)  Refunds. 
(1)  A business, trade, profession or occupation may apply for a partial refund of its previously paid occupation tax when the business ceases to conduct business within the city. A business with multiple locations may apply for a refund when it closes one or more of its locations or offices, and no business dealings are conducted in the city from the closed location(s) or office(s). The previously paid occupation tax shall be prorated from the date certified in the written request for a refund and calculated pursuant to subparagraph (3), below. 
(2)  A written request for a refund shall be submitted to the occupation city clerk within six months after the business, trade, profession, or occupation ceases to exist as a legal entity doing business in the city, and the request shall certify the date the business ceased to exist. If one or more locations or offices are still in operation and conducting business in the city, then the request for refund shall certify the date the location(s) or office(s) for which the occupation tax was paid ceased to conduct business in the city. 
(3)  The occupation tax levied and paid under this section shall be subject to a prorated refund based on the number of full months left in the year for which the occupation tax certificate was issued upon written request as provided herein. Transaction of business during any month or portion thereof, for the purpose of this section, shall be deemed to have continued business for the entire month. Such refund must be applied for within 60 days of the discontinuance of the business or corporation. 
(4)  Administrative and regulatory fees and any penalties paid on behalf of a business, trade, profession or occupation shall not be subject to a refund. 
(d)  The city shall not require the payment of more than one occupational tax for each location that a business or practitioner shall have nor shall the city require that a business pay occupational tax for more than 100 percent of the gross receipts. 
(e)  The city shall not require an occupation tax on those receipts that were taxed by occupation tax in other localities or states. 
(f)  The city shall require an occupation tax from those real estate brokers, agents or companies whose offices are located outside the city and sell property inside the limits of the city. 
(g)  For out-of-state businesses with no location in the state, occupation taxes include the gross receipts of the business as defined in O.C.G.A. § 14-13-7 which are reasonably attributed to sales or services in the state. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-36. - Paying tax of business with no location in state. 
Registration and the assessment of an occupation tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state if the business' largest dollar volume of business in the state is in this city and the business or practitioner: 
(1)  Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or 
(2)  Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-37. - Each line of business to be identified on business registration. 
The business registration of each business operated in the city shall identify the line or lines of business that the business conducts. No business shall conduct any line of business without first having that line of business registered with the city clerk. The dominant line of business shall be noted by the city clerk upon the business registration form which is to be displayed by the business owner. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-38. - Number of businesses considered operating in city. 
Where a person conducts business at more than one fixed location, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of an occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-39. - Licenses or occupational tax receipts not transferable; change of address notification required. 
(a)  Business licenses or occupational tax receipts shall not be transferable, and transfer of ownership shall be considered in the same light as the termination of such business and the establishment of a new business. Therefore, a new occupational license tax shall be required for the new owner of the business. 
(b)  Any person moving from one location to another shall notify the clerk of such move and the new address in writing on a form provided by the clerk no later than the day of moving. A new license or receipt for occupational tax will be issued at the new location if the new location conforms to the zoning regulations of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-40. - Professionals as classified in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1)—(18). 
(a)  Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1)—(18) shall elect as their entire occupation tax one of the following: 
(1)  The occupation tax based on gross receipts combined with profitability ratios as set forth in section 74-35; or 
(2)  A fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, such tax to be paid at the practitioner's office or location; provided, however, that a practitioner paying according to this paragraph shall not be required to provide information to the local government relating to the gross receipts of the business or practitioner. The per practitioner fee applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework. 
(b)  With respect to such election, the following general rules apply: 
(1)  This election is to be made on an annual basis and must be done by January 1 of each year; and 
(2)  The professions that may elect a flat tax of $400.00 per practitioner are as follows: lawyers; physicians licensed under O.C.G.A. title 43, ch. 34; osteopaths licensed under O.C.G.A. title 43, ch. 34; chiropractors; podiatrists; dentists; optometrists; psychologists; veterinarians; landscape architects; land surveyors; practitioners of physiotherapy; public accountants; embalmers; funeral directors; civil, mechanical, hydraulic, or electrical engineers; architects; marriage and family therapists, social workers, and professional counselors. Occupation tax, at election of each taxpayer, shall be a flat fee of $400.00 per practitioner who is licensed to provide any of the services listed in this subsection or the tax shall be computed on the basis of gross receipts in accordance with the provisions of section 74-35. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-41. - Practitioners exclusively practicing for the government. 
Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the United States, the state or a municipality or county of the state, shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § 1, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-42. - When tax due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax delinquent. 
(a)  Each occupation tax shall be for the calendar year unless otherwise specified. Said occupation tax shall be due and payable January 1 of each year and shall, if not paid by April 1 of each year, be subject to a ten percent penalty for delinquency and shall accrue interest at the rate of one and five-tenths percent per month until said tax, penalties and interest are paid in full. On any new profession, trade, business or occupation begun in the city in 1995 or succeeding years thereafter, the registration and tax shall be due and payable immediately upon beginning business, and shall be subject to a ten percent penalty for delinquency if not paid within 90 days of the commencement of such business, and interest shall accrue at the rate of one and five-tenths percent per month until said tax, penalties and interest are paid in full. Penalties provided herein shall be in addition to any other penalties, civil or criminal, which may be applicable. 
(b)  The tax registration provided for in this subsection shall be issued by the city clerk. Any person transacting or offering to transact in the city any business, trade, profession or occupation without first having obtained such registration shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 74-49. Such penalties shall be in addition to all other penalties, civil and criminal, provided in this article, may be collected by the remedies provided in this article and shall have the same lien and priority as the occupation tax to which the penalty is applied. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-43. - Allocation of gross receipts of business with multiple intrastate or interstate locations. 
(a)  For those businesses who have multiple locations inside and outside of the city where the gross receipts can be allocated to each location, the gross receipts used to determine the occupational tax assessed will be those gross receipts attributed to each city location. In the case where the dollar amount of gross receipts attributed locally cannot be determined in those businesses with multiple locations, the total gross receipts will be divided by the total number of locations in the city and elsewhere and allotted to those locations. Upon request, the business or practitioner with a location or office situated in more than one jurisdiction shall provide to the city the following: 
(1)  Financial information necessary to allocate the gross receipts of the business or practitioner; and 
(2)  Information relating to the allocation of the business' or practitioner's gross receipts by other local governments. 
(b)  Where the business has locations outside of the city and taxation is levied for a criteria other than gross receipts in the other local governments, the city shall not assess more than the allotted share of gross receipts for the local operation. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-44. - Exemption on grounds that business is operated for charitable purpose. 
No business on which a business registration or occupation tax is levied by this article shall be exempt from such registration or tax on the ground that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless 80 percent or more of the entire proceeds from such business are devoted to such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-45. - State veterans free license. 
Persons who qualify for a state veterans free license must secure such license from the state and present the license to the city clerk, who, upon receipt of the license, will honor the license and issue a city license without charge. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-46. - Evidence of state registration required if applicable; state registration to be displayed. 
(a)  Each person who is licensed by the secretary of state pursuant to O.C.G.A. title 43 shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the city registration may be issued. 
(b)  Each person who is licensed by the state shall post the state license in a conspicuous place in the licensee's place of business and shall keep the license there at all times while the license remains valid. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-47. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. 
Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a city business registration, show evidence of such qualification. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-48. - Liability of officers and agents; registration required; failure to obtain. 
Any person subject to the occupation tax levy pursuant to this chapter shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for such business as described in this chapter, and in default thereof the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a registration. Every person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall likewise obtain the registration provided for in this section before commencing the business; and any person transacting, or offering to transact in the city, any of the kinds of business, trade, profession or occupation without first having so obtained such registration, shall be subject to penalties provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-49. - Penalty of article violation. 
In addition to the penalties provided for in section 74-41, any person violating any provisions of this article shall, upon conviction before the municipal judge, be fined in an amount not exceeding $500.00. Each day the violation continues shall be a separate violation subjecting the offender to a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-50. - Businesses not covered by this article. 
The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the state or by act of local law. 
(1)  Those businesses regulated by the state public service commission. 
(2)  Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. title 46, ch. 3. 
(3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. 
(4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. 
(5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8. 
(6)  Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. 
(7)  Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. 
(8)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. 
(9)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(10)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-51. - Occupation tax inapplicable where prohibited by law or provided for pursuant to other existing law. 
An occupation tax shall not apply to the gross receipts of any part of a business where such levy is prohibited or exempted by state law or laws of the United States. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-52. - Occupation taxes levied on business to be transacted during calendar year; filing of returns showing gross receipts during preceding calendar year. 
(a)  The owner, proprietor, manager or executive officer of the business liable for the occupation tax levied for the current calendar year shall, at the end of the preceding year, and on or before April 1 of the current calendar year, file with the city clerk, on a form furnished by the clerk, a signed return setting forth the actual amount of the gross receipts of such business for the entire preceding calendar year. This return will be used to determine the final tax for the calendar year just completed and as an estimate of the gross receipts and occupation tax for the current year. 
(b)  All occupation taxes levied by this article are levied on amount of business to be transacted during the calendar year. However, for convenience of both the city and the taxpayer, and to avoid the necessity of making numerous returns, those businesses subject to the occupation tax levied pursuant to section 74-35, the return filed with the clerk in accordance with subsection (a) of this section shall be used as an estimate for making payments on the occupation tax for current calendar year. The actual and final amount of tax levied for business transacted in a current calendar year shall be paid in accordance with a final return to be made after the termination of the current year, in accordance with the procedure set forth in this article. 
(c)  To verify and document the gross receipts of such return, the applicant must submit or produce documentation evidencing gross receipts which may include federal tax return forms listing gross receipts for the most recently completed calendar year or such other proof of actual gross receipts satisfactory to the city. 
(d)  Where a business subject to the occupation tax for the calendar year has been conducted for only a part of the preceding year, the amount of gross receipts for such part shall be set forth in such return. Such return shall also show a figure putting the receipts for such part of a year on an annual basis, which figure shall bear the same ratio to the amount of gross receipts for such part year as the full year bears to such part. Such figure shall be used as the estimate of the gross receipts of the business for the current calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-53. - Procedure where taxes overpaid or underpaid. 
(a)  Upon the filing of the final return as provided in section 74-52, if the amount of the occupation tax due for the previous year, based on actual gross receipts, is more than the amount of occupational tax paid based on the estimate from the preceding year, the difference in such amount shall be due and payable by the taxpayer to the city on April 1 of the current year and delinquent if not paid on or before that date. 
(b)  Upon the filing of the final return as provided in section 74-52, if the amount of the occupation tax due for the previous, based on actual gross receipts, is less than the amount of occupational tax paid based on the estimate from the preceding year, the difference in such amount shall be refundable by city to the taxpayer; or, if the business continues to be conducted in the city during the current year, such difference in amount shall be credited by the city on the amount of occupation tax to be paid to the city by the business for the current year. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-54. - Payment of occupation tax by newly established businesses. 
In the case of a business subject to occupation tax for a calendar year, which was not conducted for any period of time in the city in the preceding year, the owner, proprietor, manager or executive officer of the business liable for occupation tax shall estimate the gross volume of revenue from commencing date to the end of the calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-55. - More than one place or line of business. 
Where a business is operated at more than one place or where the business includes more than one line, the gross receipts of each location will be entered on a separate occupation tax return and the tax will be calculated at the rate of the dominant line of business conducted by the businesses identified on a form to be furnished by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-56. - Returns confidential. 
Except in the case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect the occupation tax hereby levied, it shall be unlawful for any officer, employee, agent or clerk of the city or any other person to divulge or make known in any manner the amount of gross receipts or any particulars set forth or disclosed in any occupation tax return required under this article. All contents of such return shall be confidential and open only to the officials, employees, agents or clerks of the city using such returns for the purpose of this occupation tax levy and the collection of the tax. Independent auditors or bookkeepers employed by the city shall be classed as employees for the purposes of this section. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the publication by the city officials of statistics, so classified as to prevent the identification of particular reports or returns and items thereof, or the inspection of the records by duly qualified employees of the tax departments of the state or of the United States, and other local governments. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-57. - Insurance companies. 
Insurance companies are hereby declared to be not subject to the schedules of taxation imposed by sections 74-35, but shall be taxed as provided in article III of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-58. - Specific requirements for certain licenses. 
Before any license is issued under this article, the following terms or conditions must be complied with by the indicated business activity. 
(1)  Air conditioning and heating, installation and service . State license is required before a license is issued. 
(2)  Bonding company . Must be approved by police chief. 
(3)  Bus agent, express company and parcel delivery . This specific occupation tax is levied upon all business done within the city and to and from points in the state. Business done to and from points without the state are expressly excluded from this tax levy. 
(4)  Cafe, restaurant and cafeteria . Must have permits from health department and fire inspector before license is issued. 
(5)  Delicatessen, meat market and meat processor . Must have permit from health department before license is issued. 
(6)  Dancehall . Must be approved by fire chief and police chief. 
(7)  Detective agency . Must have a state license and must also be approved by police chief. 
(8)  Electrician . State license is required before a license is issued. 
(9)  Exterminators . Permit is required from state department of entomology before a license is issued. 
(10)  Gasfitters and plumbers . State license is required before license is issued. Must also provide $2,000.00 bond and obtain permit prior to engaging in any work within any city right-of-way. 
(11)  Junk dealer . Such person shall hold their shop subject to visitation and inspection by the police and on refusal of inspection, his shop shall immediately be closed by the city manager, and license forfeited, and in case any machinery or appliances of any railroad shop or gas company or waterworks fixtures shall be found in such junk dealer's shop without sufficient explanation, it shall be just and conclusive cause for the revocation of each dealer's license. Minors are to have written permits from parents or guardians before selling to dealers. If a junk dealer buys from a minor without a written permit from parents he will be subject to prosecution. 
(12)  Kennels (dog). Must be in area zoned for this type business. 
(13)  Massage therapist . Must show certification. 
(14)  Outpatient clinic . Must have proof of state certification. 
(15)  Pawnbrokers . Each person or firm engaged in the business of a pawnbroker or conducting a pawnbroker shop in the city shall make a report to the chief of police before 10:00 a.m. each day (except Sunday when transactions for Saturdays shall be made the following Monday) of every article or thing pawned to or purchased by him or them for the day and night previous; such report to specify the article or thing giving a full description thereof such as a number, mark and all other details as will make identification of such articles clear and positive, and such person shall hold their shops subject to visitation and inspection of the police, and upon refusal of any pawnbroker to submit to such visitation or inspection of his shop shall be immediately closed by the city manager. All licenses issued to pawnbrokers are subject to this subsection, and violations of this subsection shall be punished with the revocation of the license and license for pawnbrokers shall be transferred from the person to whom it was issued. 
(16)  Precious metal . Must be approved by police chief. 
(17)  Rides only . Provided the machinery and accessory implements shall be located in such place in the city as the city manager may approve. License is subject to be revoked by the city manager after a hearing before the city manager, party at interest having first been served notice of such hearing. 
(18)  Taxicabs, transportation; nonemergency . Provided before any license is granted each applicant must have insurance coverage, property damage and personal liability for a minimum of $15,000.00 in a company acceptable to the city clerk and deposit such policies with the city clerk covering every car used in such taxicab/nonemergency transportation business. Each taxicab is required to have its framed license displayed in view of passengers at all times, with the number of cab corresponding with the number on the license. 
(19)  Telephone company . Telephone company charges will be three percent of the recurring local service revenue of subscribers located within the city. 
(20)  Tree surgery . In addition to business license, must also have proof of liability insurance in the minimum amounts of $50,000.00 for bodily injury and $100,000.00 property damage indemnifying the city and any person injured or damaged resulting from the pursuit of such activities. 
(21)  Trenching and pipe laying . In addition to business license, must also post $2,000.00 bond and obtain permit prior to engaging in any work within any city right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-59. - Inspections of books and records. 
In any case the city clerk, through his officers, agents, employees or representatives, may inspect the books of the business for which the returns are made. The city clerk or his designee shall have the right to inspect the books or records for the business of which the return was made in the city, and upon demand of the city clerk, such books or records shall be submitted for inspection by a representative of the city within 30 days. Failure of submission of such books or records within 30 days shall be grounds for revocation of the tax registration currently existing to do business in the city. Adequate records shall be kept in the city for examination by the city clerk at his discretion. If, after examination of the books or records, it is determined that a deficiency occurs as a result of underreporting, a penalty of ten percent on amounts due beyond 90 days shall be assessed. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-60. - Tax registration to be revoked for failure to pay tax, file returns, permit inspection of books. 
Upon the failure of any business to pay such occupation tax or any part thereof before it becomes delinquent, or upon failure to make any of such returns within the time required in this article, or upon failure to make a true return, or upon failure to amend a return to set forth the truth, or upon failure to permit inspection of its books as provided in section 74-59, any business tax registration granted by the city under this article permitting the owner of such business to do business in the city for the current year shall be, ipso facto, revoked and shall subject the business to the penalties provided for herein. No new business tax registration shall be granted by the city for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax provided for in this article is at that time unpaid, or to an individual, firm or corporation who has failed to submit adequate records as requested by the city clerk in accordance with provisions found in section 74-59. In the case of those practitioners where the local government cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct its business, the imposition of civil penalties shall be permitted and pursued by the local government in the case of delinquent occupation tax. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-61. - Lien taken and execution for delinquent occupation tax. 
In addition to the other remedies as provided in this article for the collection of the occupation tax levied in this article, the city clerk, upon any tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the correct amount of such tax against the persons, partnership or corporation liable for such tax, which such execution shall bear interest at the rate of 12 percent per annum from the date when such tax becomes delinquent, and the lien shall cover the property (in the city) of the person, partnership or corporation liable for such tax, all as provided by the ordinances and charter of the city and state law. The lien of such occupation tax shall become fixed on and from the time when such tax thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the city clerk or his designee upon the property of the defendant located in the city, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of such execution, with interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be as is provided by ordinances and charter of the city and state law, and the defendant in such execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the charter of the city and state law in regard to tax executions. When a nulla bona entry has been entered by proper authority upon an execution issued by the city clerk against any person defaulting on the occupation tax, the person against whom the entry was made shall not be allowed or entitled to have or collect any fees or charges whatsoever for services rendered after the entry of the nulla bona. If, at any time after the entry of nulla bona has been made, the person against whom the execution issues pays the tax in full together with all interest and costs accrued on the tax, the person may collect any fees and charges due him as though he had never defaulted in the payment of the taxes. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-62. - Administration. 
The city clerk shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the levy, assessment and collection of taxes and penalties imposed in this article; provided however, that any person who is of the opinion that this tax has been incorrectly assessed or that his major line classification is incorrect, or that any other requirement or decision of the city clerk is in error, shall have the right to appeal as follows: 
(1)  The aggrieved taxpayer shall first submit the complaint or alleged error in writing to the city manager who shall review the complaint. 
(2)  Should the taxpayer, the city clerk and the city manager fail to resolve the issue, the city manager shall notify the city council and the city council will consider the appeal at its next regular meeting. 
(3)  If the city clerk and the city manager recommend that an audit of the books of a licensee or person is necessary, the city council, upon finding as a fact that it appears desirable to order such an audit, may do so, with the expense of the audit to be borne by the city if the position of the taxpayer is sustained in the audit. If not, the expense of the audit shall be due and payable pursuant to this section as a penalty in addition to taxes due from the licensee or person. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-63. - Rules and regulations. 
The city manager shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article or other laws of the city and state, or the Constitution of the United States for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and the collection of the license or occupational tax under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-64. - Amendment, repeal of provision. 
This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the council to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. Such amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the city of additional occupation taxes upon the same person, property or business. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-65. - Applications of provisions to prior ordinance. 
This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereinafter passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed fines or penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in such ordinance or ordinances, or failure to comply with any other provisions of this article, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee or assessment shall be fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-66. - Enforcement of article. 
It is hereby made the duty of the city clerk and city police department to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed; and to summon all violators of this article to appear before the municipal court. It is hereby made the further duty of the city clerk, chief of police, and their assistants, to inspect all registrations issued by the city, as often as in their judgement it may seem necessary to determine whether the registration held is the proper one for the business sought to be transacted thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-67. - Article to remain in full force and effect until changed by council. 
This article shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the council. All provisions relating to any form of tax levied in this article shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-68. - Requirement of public hearing before tax increase. 
After January 1, 1999, the city council shall conduct at least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-69. - Option to establish exemption or reduction in occupation tax. 
The city council may by subsequent ordinance or resolution provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax to one or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions as part of a plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-70. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. 
Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention of this article that the specific shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-71. - Severability. 
If any section, provision, or clause of any part of this article shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, or if the provisions of any part of this article as applied to any particular situation or set of circumstances shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional, such individuality shall not be construed to affect the portions of this article not so held to be invalid, or the application of this article to other circumstances not so held to be invalid. It is hereby declared as the intent that this article would have been adopted had such invalid portion not been included herein. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Sec. 74-72. - Repeal of conflicting provisions. 
All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this article, and not preserved hereby, are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 2017-16 , § I, 10-16-2017) 
Secs. 74-73—74-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INSURANCE BUSINESSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses and business regulations, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— General assembly authorized to provide for taxation of insurance companies based on gross direct premiums received from insurance policies within the unincorporated areas of counties, Ga. Const. Art. IX, § IV, ¶ I(c); local tax on other than life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. 

Sec. 74-101. - Personal insurance coverage—Personal coverage. 
Each insurance company and association collecting within the city insurance premiums for any life, health, disability, accident or industrial coverage as defined under O.C.G.A. §§ 33-25-1, 33-26-1, 33-27-1 or 33-29-1, shall pay an annual license fee of $75.00 for each location such company and association located within the city; provided that each such company and association so collecting any such premiums shall be deemed, for purposes hereof, to have at least one such location with the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-27, § 1, 10-5-1998; Ord. No. 99-37, § 29(1)(b), 10-4-1999) 
Sec. 74-102. - Same—Gross premiums tax. 
In addition to the annual license fee set forth in section 74-101, all such companies and associations collecting premiums on such insurance shall pay to the city an annual percentage tax equal to one percent of all gross premiums collected from within the city from such insurance coverages. All such insurance companies and associations shall submit a statement to the city, prior to March 1 of each calendar year, showing gross premiums so collected in the previous calendar year and pay the percentage tax set forth above. If such an insurance company or association discontinues collecting such premiums from within the city during any calendar year, such company or association shall forthwith submit a statement thereof and of gross premiums collected to the date thereof and pay the percentage tax on the basis of premiums collected since the beginning of the then current calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 98-27, § 1, 10-5-1998; Ord. No. 99-37, § 29(1)(b), 10-4-1999) 
Sec. 74-103. - Casualty coverage—License fees. 
Each insurance company and association collecting within the city insurance premiums for any fire, liability, collision, casualty, marine, surety, indemnity or bonds coverage defined by O.C.G.A. §§ 33-32-1 and 33-34-2 shall pay an annual license fee of $75.00 for each location of such company or association located within the city; provided that each such company and associationso collecting any such premiums shall be deemed, for purposes hereof, to have at least one such location within the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-27, § 1, 10-5-1998; Ord. No. 99-37, § 29(1)(a), 10-4-1999) 
Sec. 74-104. - Same—Gross premiums tax. 
In addition to the annual license fee stated in section 74-103, all such companies and associations collecting premiums on such insurance shall pay to the city an annual percentage fee equal to 2.5 percent of all gross premiums collected from within the city in excess of $10,000.00 for such insurance coverages. All such insurance companies and associations shall submit a statement to the city, prior to March 1, showing gross premiums so collected in the previous calendar year and pay the percentage tax set forth above. If such an insurance company or association discontinues collecting such premiums from within the city during any calendar year, such company or association shall forthwith submit a statement thereof and of gross premiums collected to the date thereof and pay the percentage tax on the basis of premiums collected since the beginning of the then current calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 98-27, § 1, 10-5-1998; Ord. No. 99-37, § 29(1)(a), 10-4-1999) 
Sec. 74-105. - Independent agencies, brokers, etc., not otherwise licensed. 
There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which an insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by this article in the amount of $50.00 for each such location within the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-27, § 3, 10-5-1998; Ord. No. 99-37, § 29(2), 10-4-1999) 
Secs. 74-106—74-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Local depository financial institutions business license tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 

Sec. 74-131. - Business license tax. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93, there is hereby levied an annual business license tax upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations and state building and loan associations a business license tax at the rate of one quarter of one percent of the gross receipts of such institutions. Gross receipts shall mean gross receipts as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institution pursuant to this article shall be $1,000.00 per year. 
(Ord. No. 83-21, § 1, 12-5-1983) 
Sec. 74-132. - Filing of return. 
Each depository financial institution within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city on March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. Such returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in such return. 
(Ord. No. 83-21, § 2(a), 12-5-1983) 
Sec. 74-133. - Due date. 
The due date of taxes levied by this article shall be April 1 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 83-21, § 2(b), 12-5-1983) 
Secs. 74-134—74-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses and business regulations, ch. 22. 
State Law reference— Local excise tax on rooms, lodgings and accomodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.; operators of hotels, inns and roadhouses, O.C.G.A. § 43-21-1 et seq. 

Sec. 74-161. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Due date means the 20th day after the close of the monthly period for which tax is to be computed. 
Guestroom means a room occupied, or intended, arranged, or designated for occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. 
Hotel means any structure or portion of a structure (including a hotel, motel, inn, lodge, tourist camp and tourist cabin) containing guestrooms and in which rooms, lodgings or accommodations are regularly furnished for value. As used in this article, the term "hotel" does not include any jail, hospital, orphanage, asylum, sanitarium or medical, mental, drug or alcohol treatment facility or any governmental building. 
Monthly period means the calendar months of any year. 
Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room or apartment in a hotel or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room, except when such room is being used as a meeting room. 
Occupant means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses or has the right to use or possess any room in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use or other agreement, or otherwise. 
Operator means any person operating a hotel in the city, including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, lessee, sublessee, lender in possession, licensee or any other person otherwise operating such hotel. 
Permanent resident means any occupant as of a given date who has or shall have occupied, or has or shall have the right of occupancy of any guestroom in a hotel for more than ten consecutive days next preceding such date. 
Person means an individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or cooperative nonprofit membership, estate, trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number, excepting the United States of America, the state, and any political subdivision of either thereof upon which the city is without power to impose the tax provided in this article. 
Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
Return means any return filed or required to be filed as provided in this article. 
(Code 1974, § 24-65) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-162. - Imposition and rate of tax. 
There shall be paid a tax of five percent of the rent for every occupancy of a guestroom in a hotel in the city. The tax imposed by this article shall be paid upon any occupancy on or after May 1, 2000, although such occupancy is had pursuant to a contract, lease or other arrangement made prior to such date. 
(Code 1974, § 24-66; Ord. No. 2000-008, 3-20-2000) 
Sec. 74-163. - Collection of tax by operator. 
Every operator maintaining a place of business in this city and renting guestrooms in the city not exempted under this article shall collect equal to the amount of tax imposed and levied under this article from the occupant. 
(Code 1974, § 24-67) 
Sec. 74-164. - Exemptions. 
The tax authorized by this article shall not apply to: 
(a)  Charges made for any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations provided to any persons who certify that they are staying in such room, lodging, or accommodation as a result of the destruction of their home or residence by fire or other casualty; 
(b)  The use of meeting rooms and other such facilities or any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations provided without charge; 
(c)  Any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations furnished for a period of one or more days for use by Georgia state or local governmental officials or employees when traveling on official business. Notwithstanding the availability of any other means of identifying the person as a state or local government official or employee, whenever a person pays for any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations with a state or local government credit or debit card, such rooms, lodgings, or accommodations shall be deemed to have been furnished for use by a Georgia state or local government official or employee traveling on official business for purposes of the exemption provided by this paragraph. For purpose of the exemption provided under this paragraph, a local government official or employee shall include officials or employees of counties, municipalities, consolidated governments, or county or independent school districts; or 
(d)  Charges made for continuous use of any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations after the first 30 days of continuous occupancy. 
(Code 1974, § 24-68; Ord. No. 2009-14, § I, 7-6-2009) 
Sec. 74-165. - Registration of operator. 
(a)  Every person engaging or about to engage in business as an operator of a hotel in the city shall immediately register with the finance director on such form as shall be provided by the official. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of the place of business, and such other information which would facilitate the collection of the tax as the finance director may from time to time require. The registration shall be signed by the owner in the case of a natural person; in case of ownership by an association or partnership, by a member or partner; and in the case of ownership by a corporation, by an officer. 
(b)  The finance director shall, after such registration, issue without charge a certificate of authority to each operator to collect the tax from occupants. 
(c)  A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator. 
(Code 1974, § 24-69) 
Sec. 74-166. - Determination, returns and payments. 
(a)  All amounts of taxes due under this article shall be due and payable to the city monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each respective monthly period. 
(b)  On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the finance director showing the gross rent, rent from permanent residents, taxable rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the finance director. 
(c)  Operators collecting the tax authorized by this article shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for, and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and paying the amount due, if such amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from the state sales and use tax under the Georgia Retailer's and Consumers' Sales and Use Tax Act (O.C.G.A. §§ 48-8-1—48-8-66). 
(Code 1974, § 24-70) 
Sec. 74-167. - Persons liable for tax. 
(a)  The taxes imposed pursuant to this article are imposed upon the operator and shall be collected by the operator from the occupant. The operator shall collect the tax imposed under this article from the occupant and shall pay the tax over to the city as provided in this article. 
(b)  Each operator shall add the amount of the tax imposed under this article to the room rental charge, which shall be a debt from the occupant to the operator until paid, and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as other debts. Any operator who shall neglect, fail or refuse to collect the tax imposed pursuant to this article upon all rent due for occupancy shall be personally liable for payment of the tax so imposed. 
(c)  No operator shall advertise or hold out to the public in any manner that such operator will absorb all or any portion of the tax imposed pursuant to this article or that such operator will relieve the occupant of the payment of all or any portion of the tax imposed pursuant to this article. 
(d)  Any operator liable for any tax imposed pursuant to this article who shall sell the hotel business of such operator or shall quit the hotel business shall make a final return and payment of all amounts due to the city pursuant to this article, all within 15 days after the date of selling or quitting the business. 
(Code 1974, § 24-71) 
Sec. 74-168. - Failure to pay tax. 
(a)  The tax imposed pursuant to this article shall for each month become delinquent on the 21st day of each succeeding month. The finance director shall, when any tax becomes delinquent under this article, pursue any remedy or right allowed by law for enforcement of the collection and payment of taxes imposed by the city as may be allowed under state law and the ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Any operator who fails to pay the tax imposed pursuant to this article to the city or fails to pay to the city any amount of such tax required to be collected pursuant to this article within the time required for payment thereof shall pay a penalty of ten percent of the tax, or the amount of the tax not so paid within such time period, in addition to the tax or amount of tax not so paid within such time period, plus interest on the unpaid tax or portion thereof at a rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount or portion thereof should have been returned until date of payment. 
(Code 1974, § 24-72) 
Sec. 74-169. - Deficiency determination. 
(a)  If the finance director is not satisfied with the return of the tax or the amount of the tax required by this article to be paid to the city by any person, he may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of information within his possession or that may come into his possession. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly periods. 
(b)  The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the due date of taxes. 
(c)  The finance director shall give to the operator written notice of his determination. The notice may be served personally or by mail. If made by mail, such service shall be made by certified mail and shall be addressed to the operator at the address of the operator as it appears in the records of the city. 
(d)  Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period shall last expire. 
(Code 1974, § 24-73) 
Sec. 74-170. - Determination if no return made. 
(a)  If any person fails to make a return, the finance director shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the person, or as the case may be, of the amount of the total rents of such persons within the city which are subject to the tax required by this article. The estimate shall be made for the period in respect to which the person failed to make the return and shall be based upon information which is or may come into the possession of the finance director. Written notice shall be given in the manner prescribed in subsection 74-169(c). 
(b)  The amount of the determination shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, from the 20th day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount or any portion thereof should have been returned until the date of payment. 
(Code 1974, § 24-74) 
Sec. 74-171. - Administration of article. 
(a)  The finance director shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax imposed under this article. 
(b)  Every operator shall keep such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the finance director may require from time to time. 
(c)  The finance director or any person authorized by the finance director may examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator renting guestrooms to a person and any operator liable for the tax in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator to ascertain and determine the amount of tax required to be paid. 
(d)  In administration of the provisions of this article, the finance director may require the filing of reports by any persons or class of persons having in such person's or persons' possession or custody information relating to rentals of guestrooms which are subject to the tax imposed under this article. The reports shall be filed with the finance director when required by him and shall set forth the rents charged for each occupancy, the dates of occupancy, and such other information as the finance director may from time to time require. 
(Code 1974, § 24-75) 
Sec. 74-172. - Collection of delinquent taxes. 
(a)  At any time within three years after any tax or any amount of tax required by this article to be collected becomes due and payable, and at any time within three years after the delinquency of any such tax or any amount of tax required to be collected, the finance director may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction in the name of the city to collect amounts delinquent together with interest, court fees, filing fees, attorney's fees and other legal fees incident thereto. 
(b)  If any operator liable for any amount under this article sells out his business or quits the business, his successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient sum from the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the finance director showing that the city has been paid in full or a certificate stating that no amount is due. 
(c)  If the purchaser of a business fails to withhold from the purchase price as required under this article such purchaser shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by such purchaser but only to the extent of the purchase price. 
(d)  Whenever the amount of any tax or interest has been paid more than once, or has been erroneously or illegally collected or received by the city under this article, it may be offset by the finance director. If the operator or person determines that he has overpaid or paid more than once, which fact has not been determined by the finance director, the operator will have three years from date of payment to file a claim in writing stating the specific ground upon which the claim is founded. The claim shall be audited. If the claim is approved by the finance director, the excess amount paid to the city may be credited on any amounts then due and payable from the person by whom it was paid, or his administrators, representatives, successors or assigns. 
(Code 1974, § 24-76) 
Sec. 74-173. - Retention of records. 
It shall be the duty of every operator required to make a report and pay any tax levied under this article to keep and preserve suitable records of rents taxable under this article, such other books of accounts and records as may be necessary to determine the amount of tax due hereunder, and any other information as may be required by the finance director. It shall be the duty of every operator to keep and preserve for a period of three years all invoices and other records of occupancy and rents for occupancy which are taxable under this article with all such books, invoices, and other records to be open to examination by the finance director or any person authorized by him at all reasonable hours. 
(Code 1974, § 24-77) 
Chapter 78 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Driving animals, § 14-14; court, ch. 30; noise control, § 38-31 et seq.; noise control of powered motor vehicles, § 38-40; motor vehicles a nuisance, § 38-191 et seq.; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 46; reckless driving destroying vegetation in parks, § 50-11; speed of vehicles in parks, § 50-13; public safety, ch. 58; littering, scattering refuse prohibited; transporting loose materials, § 66-6; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; vehicles for hire, ch. 90. 
State Law reference— Jurisdiction of municipal courts over misdemeanor traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-21(a); power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Adoption of uniform rules of the road. 
Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1—40-6-395, known as the uniform rules of the road, are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited in this chapter. 
(Code 1974, § 15-01) 
Sec. 78-2. - Parental responsibility. 
It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor under the age of 16 years to permit, whether knowingly or through ineffective control or supervision, such minor to violate any provision of this Code or state law regarding the operation of vehicles.
