(b)  Whenever the cross connection control coordinator determines that there has been a violation of this article, he shall notify the owner in writing of such violation, and within 30 days the owner will submit a plan for correcting the violation. 
(c)  The city manager may cite the owner to the municipal court of the city for a violation of any provision of this article. 
(d)  The city manager may in the name of the city file in county superior court a suit seeking the issuance of an injunction, damages, or other appropriate relief to enforce the provisions of this article or other applicable law or regulation. Suit may be brought to recover any and all damages suffered by the city as a result of any action or inaction of any customer of the water system or other person who causes or suffers damages to occur to the water system of the city due to a violation of this article. Suit may be filed by the city against any customer of the water system or owner for any expenses, losses, or damages of any kind or nature suffered by the city as the result of a violation of this article. 
(e)  The city manager may issue a show cause notice to any customer or owner directing him to appear before the city manager at a specified date and time to show cause why water service should not be discontinued for a violation of this article. The customer or owner may present his defense at such hearing. The notice of such hearing shall be mailed to the customer or owner or delivered personally to him at least ten days prior to the hearing date. 
(Code 1974, § 19-19) 
Secs. 82-94—82-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - WATER PROVISION EXTENSION POLICIES 

Sec. 82-111. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to provide uniform policies and procedures relative to the provision and extension of water service by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1998-19, § 26-300, 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 82-112. - Application required. 
Any person desiring water service shall make application for such service at the office of the utilities department on a form to be furnished by the department. The form must be executed by the property owner or his authorized agent or provide the size of tap requested and a proper street address. 
(Ord. No. 1998-19, § 26-301, 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 82-113. - Deposits. 
Applicants for water service who are commercial establishments shall be required, at the time of application for service, to make a deposit equal to the three-month bill of the average customer in that class. Tenants in a single-family residence or mobile home shall be required, at the time of application for service, to make a deposit as determined by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1998-19, § 26-302, 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 82-114. - Meter installation fees. 
At the time of application for water service, the applicant shall also pay a meter installation fee in accordance with the rates set by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1998-19, § 26-303, 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 82-115. - Impact fee. 
The city council may, at its discretion, assess an impact fee by resolution on new water service customers at the time of application for service at such future date. The impact fee, which will be equal to or less than the equity in the water system established by existing customers through the payment of water rates, will be based upon a system of equivalent residential units (ERU). 
(Ord. No. 1998-19, § 26-304, 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 82-116. - Basin specific fee. 
If the city undertakes at its expense a water system project to provide service for an unserved area, the city manager may require a basin specific fee to be assessed against each new customer who connects to the system to recoup a portion of the capital costs of the project. The fee shall be based upon the number of equivalent residential units (ERU) the project was designed to serve. 
(Ord. No. 1998-19, § 26-305, 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 82-117. - Irrigation meters. 
Any person desiring the installation of a water meter for irrigation purposes shall make application for such water meter in accordance with the provisions of section 82-112. At the time of application, the applicant will be required to pay the meter installation fee to be set by resolution as set forth in section 82-114. 
(Ord. No. 1998-19, § 26-306, 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 82-118. - Water main extension. 
(a)  All applications for water service that require the extension of a water main will be evaluated by the director of utilities department to determine the estimated cost of the proposed extension for submittal to the city manager for his approval. Based upon the availability of funds, the city manager is authorized to approve or disapprove any application for water service requiring a water main extension. A fee as set by resolution of the city council shall be required of the applicant at the time of application for water service requiring a water main extension. This fee is to defray the costs associated with the development of the estimated costs of the extension. The fee will be applied to the costs of the extension should it be undertaken; otherwise, the fee shall be forfeited. Cost estimates are not binding upon the city. 
(b)  Within the corporate limits, the city will extend the water main to the applicant's property line a distance of no more than 300 feet at no cost to the applicant. For extensions in excess of 300 feet, the applicant shall be required to pay the costs of the additional material required plus ten percent to defray the city's costs of purchasing, inventory and handling of the material. 
(c)  Outside the corporate limits of the city, applicants are responsible for 100 percent of the costs of the main extension including all planning, engineering, material, labor, equipment and pavement replacement costs. Construction of the water main extension shall be done by a licensed contractor in strict accordance with city standards for material and workmanship. The work will be inspected by utilities department personnel before being accepted into the city system. The city manager may approve an exception to this policy based upon the applicant's binding agreement to have his property annexed into the city at its convenience, in which case the provisions of subsection (b) of this section shall apply. 
(d)  All costs of easements, jacking and/or boring, fire hydrants or other related costs which may be required for the water main extension are the responsibility of the applicant. The city shall have no obligation or responsibility for the costs of any on-site facilities either inside or outside the corporate limits. 
(e)  All water main extensions shall include the installation of fire hydrants at a distance of not more than 600 feet apart. The cost of the hydrants and related appurtenances shall be paid in accordance with the provisions of this section and any applicable resolutions of the city council relating thereto. 
(f)  All water main extensions shall be of a minimum of eight inches. The city may, in its discretion, require the installation of water mains larger than eight inches, in which case the city will be responsible for the additional costs directly resulting from the oversizing. 
(g)  Prior to any application being approved by the city manager and the work authorized, the applicant shall pay all estimated costs required under the provisions of these regulations. Any difference between the actual and estimated costs of the extension, either upward or downward, shall be reconciled as necessary upon completion of the project. 
(h)  In the event that a water main extension makes water available to other property owners abutting such extension, such other property owners shall be required to pay to the city their proportionate share, if any, of the costs of the extension borne by the original applicant on a front foot basis before being permitted to connect to such extension. The charges collected will be refunded by the city to the original applicant, but in no case will the refunds exceed the amount paid by the original applicant. Any refunds due to the original applicant will be paid, without interest, on March 31 and September 30, as appropriate. 
(i)  All liability for payment of refunds by the city shall cease seven years from the date of payment by the applicant for water main extension. The assignment by the applicant of any money due under the provisions of this refund policy without the written consent of the city is prohibited. 
(j)  In the event that a water main is extended, either inside or outside the corporate limits, the costs of which is paid in part or in full by the city, applicants who wish to connect to the main shall be required to pay a connection charge in addition to the meter installation fee as referenced in section 82-114. The connection charge shall be applicant's proportionate share, on a footage basis, of the city's share of the cost of the extension. If the water main installed is larger than eight inches, the applicant shall be required to pay only its proportionate share of the cost of an eight-inch main. 
(k)  All water mains extended under the provisions of these regulations, whether inside or outside the city, shall become the sole property of the city upon the connection with the city water system and shall thenceforth be maintained by the city. 
(l)  Anything in these regulations to the contrary notwithstanding, the city in its sole discretion shall have the right to disapprove any application for water service when it determines that it is not in its best interest to do so based on monetary or manpower constraints or on other considerations such as the unavailability of water supply. Furthermore, the city reserves the right to extend its water system on a planned basis in the best interest of orderly community-wide growth. 
(Ord. No. 98-19, § 26-307, 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 82-119. - Turnoff/turn-on policy. 
All of the provisions set forth in this article shall apply to the user of the utility service and to the owner of the property being served. The term "customer" shall mean the name on the account to which the service is charged and the user of the service at the physical location. Termination of service shall follow these procedures: 
(1)  Customers with unpaid balances on their water bill will receive a delinquent notice 30 days after their regular monthly bill has been mailed. The delinquent notice will provide a due date that is seven days after the notice is issued, after which date service will be terminated. 
(2)  The delinquent notice will also advise that prior to service being terminated, a hearing will be afforded at which time the user and/or owner may present his protest or challenge to the bill. The notice will specify the date, time and place of the hearing and whether the hearing will be held before the city manager or his designated agent. The hearing will be held not less than four days after the notice is given. A record will be kept by the person holding the hearing and of the specific protest and/or challenge made by the user and/or owner. 
(3)  Service turned off for nonpayment of a water bill will be turned on only after payment of the delinquent bill plus a fee to be set by resolution of the city council to cover the cost of the additional trips to the service location by utilities department personnel. 
(Ord. No. 98-19, § 26-360, 6-1-1998) 
Secs. 82-120—82-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - WATER SHORTAGE MEASURES 

Sec. 82-136. - Purposes. 
The purpose of this division is to provide for emergency procedures to prevent threats to public health and safety arising from periods of water shortage and drought and to prevent acts that cause, or can be reasonably expected to cause, significant imminent harm to the public health, safety and welfare or to limited water resources. 
(Code 1974, § 26-100) 
Sec. 82-137. - Public notification. 
The public shall be notified of the implementation of emergency procedures in accordance with this article and those steps which are being implemented pursuant thereto by providing notice thereof to the local news media and by posting notice thereof upon the city's bulletin board in city hall and upon the bulletin board located at the county courthouse at least 24 hours prior to any implementation of emergency procedures in accordance with this division. 
(Code 1974, § 26-101) 
Sec. 82-138. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Business using high volumes of water means water customers of the city using more than 25,000 gallons of water per day. 
Essential services means health care, sanitation, cooking needs, wastewater disposal, fire protection, and other essential services specified from time to time by administrative order of the city manager. 
Low pressure means less than 20 pounds per square inch (psi). 
Outdoor water usage means lawn and garden watering, noncommercial car washing, water for private swimming pools, and other activities specified from time to time by administrative order of the city manager. 
Step I restrictions means no outside water usage between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. prevailing time on Monday through Friday and no outside water usage at any time on Saturday or Sunday. The city water department must approve all use of water from the city water distribution system to fill a tank-truck or to directly fill a swimming pool from a fire hydrant. The standards to be used by the water department in the exercise of this discretion shall be: 
(1)  To protect both storage volumes and system pressures from dropping below the levels specified in section 82-139; and 
(2)  To protect the water supply so that public health, safety and welfare shall not be imminently threatened. 
Step II restrictions means all outdoor use of water shall be banned. Businesses using high volumes of water may be placed on significant restrictions by the city manager. The standards to be utilized by the city manager in the exercise of his discretion shall be: 
(1)  The effect that a high-volume user has on causing the levels specified in section 82-139; 
(2)  Whether limiting a business's hours or days of operation will allow water levels to exceed the levels provided in section 82-139; and 
(3)  Any increased water supply generated by imposed restrictions, all in such manner as to best promote the public health, safety and welfare. 
Step III restrictions means water shall be rationed pursuant to administrative order issued by the city manager so as to provide for essential purposes only. Commercial and industrial users shall be restricted in accord with a plan therefor adopted by administrative order of the city manager. All outdoor use of water shall be banned. 
(Code 1974, § 26-102) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-139. - Implementing Step I restrictions. 
Step I restrictions shall be implemented if the city exceeds 90 percent of its permitted water withdrawal amount or maximum safe production level for one day or if low pressure or loss of service is experienced. Step I restrictions shall remain in effect until all factors are relieved and shall cease upon city council determination that an adequate supply to fulfill public needs exists. City council determination shall be made following recommendation of the city manager and the water superintendent and shall be subject to modification by the council at the council's next meeting. The public shall be notified of the termination of Step I restrictions through the notification thereof to local news media and by removing prior notices thereof from the city and county bulletin boards. 
(Code 1974, § 26-103) 
Sec. 82-140. - Implementing Step II restrictions. 
Step II restrictions shall be implemented if Step I restrictions are not effective in restoring water levels above levels described in section 82-139. Step II restrictions shall remain in effect until factors that invoked Step I restrictions are relieved for a period of two weeks following the last date on which one or more factors occurred. Upon termination of Step II restrictions, Step I restrictions shall be automatically reimplemented. 
(Code 1974, § 26-104) 
Sec. 82-141. - Implementing Step III restrictions. 
Step III restrictions shall be implemented if Step II restrictions fail to prevent loss of water service. Step III restrictions shall remain in effect until loss of water service ceases. Upon termination of Step III restrictions, Step II restrictions shall be automatically re-implemented. 
(Code 1974, § 26-105) 
Sec. 82-142. - Extreme cases. 
(a)  In extreme cases of loss of service the city manager may authorize the closing of valves in the water distribution system. When exercising this discretion the city manager shall: 
(1)  Make water available to private consumers from fire hydrants that are equipped to dispense water to the private containers of consumers; 
(2)  Fully consider the needs of medical facilities; and 
(3)  If possible avoid the interruption of fire protection. 
(b)  When determining extreme cases, the city manager shall consider: 
(1)  Loss of service; 
(2)  Available water supply; and 
(3)  The threat posed to public health, safety and welfare by continued water usage without imposition of the restrictions authorized pursuant hereto. 
(Code 1974, § 26-106) 
Sec. 82-143. - Surcharges. 
Surcharges as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk for the violation of Step I, Step II or Step III restrictions shall be imposed and water service shall be terminated. Water supply shall not be restored until payment of the surcharge and of a reconnection fee. 
(Code 1974, § 26-107) 
Sec. 82-144. - Enforcement procedures. 
The city manager shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this division by discontinuance of water service in the event any person or entity violates any provisions of this division or any restrictions imposed pursuant to this division after receiving oral or written notice from the city of violations of this division. 
(1)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, in any and all events that the city manager determines that a person or entity is violating or has violated any provisions of this division or any restrictions imposed pursuant to this division and that the violation or violations endanger the public health, safety, or welfare, the city manager shall have the power and authority to immediately terminate the water service of that person or entity. 
(2)  Any person aggrieved by having the water supply terminated by the city manager shall have the right to appeal the termination to the city council. Such appeal shall be taken within three days from the date of the termination by notifying the clerk of the city in writing specifying the grounds of appeal. The city clerk shall fix a date and time for the hearing of the appeal by the city council within two days after the receipt of the notice of appeal and after due notice to the parties at interest the city council shall conduct a hearing on the appeal within five days of the date the notice of appeal was received by the city clerk and proceed to decide the appeal within three days of the date of the hearing. 
(3)  In the filing of any appeal, the city manager shall have the power and authority to reinstate the water supply of the appellant until the city council renders a decision in order to avoid undue hardship in the event that the city manager is reasonably assured that violations for which the water supply was terminated will not continue. 
(Code 1974, § 26-108) 
Sec. 82-145. - Application. 
This division shall apply to all users of the city water system whether inside the city or outside the city. 
(Code 1974, § 26-109) 
Sec. 82-146. - Metering of water. 
(a)  All water that is pumped from aquifers by the city shall be metered by the city. Such metering shall be monitored by the water department of the city on a daily basis with records thereof to be maintained by the department. 
(b)  All water service connections to the city's water system shall be metered through an approved metering station with water consumption readings to be taken periodically by the appropriate department of the city. 
(c)  Water metering devices shall be checked for accurate calibration periodically as required and as recommended by manufacturers thereof. 
(Code 1974, § 26-110) 
Sec. 82-147. - Rules and regulations. 
The city manager shall be entitled to issue rules and regulations relative to the administration of this division which are not inconsistent with the provisions of this division subject to the right of the city council to revoke or modify any such rule or regulation within 60 days following the submission thereof. 
(Code 1974, § 26-111) 
Sec. 82-148. - Compliance with other requirements. 
Compliance with the provisions of this division shall not excuse or relieve any person or entity from complying with the requirements and provisions of all other laws, ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations applicable to water and water usage or to the conduct of any activity. Such additional laws, ordinances, rules and regulations include, but are not limited to, all applicable federal and state laws, rules and regulations and all other applicable ordinances and resolutions of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 26-112) 
Sec. 82-149. - Knowledge. 
Each person and entity who or which is a water customer of the city as well as all employees, agents and servants of such water customers shall be conclusively presumed, for purposes of this division, to have at all times complete and full knowledge of all provisions of this division. 
(Code 1974, § 26-113) 
Sec. 82-150. - Criminal conviction not required. 
Any proceeding or action which may be taken with respect to the suspension or termination of water pursuant to this division shall be and are administrative in nature with respect to the privileges of water customers of the city. No conviction, dismissal, acquittal, other plea or other disposition with respect to any criminal violation involving any alleged criminal conduct shall be necessary for any action pursuant to the provisions of this division or otherwise affect any action taken by the city or city officials relative thereto. 
(Code 1974, § 26-114) 
Sec. 82-151. - Violations and penalties. 
It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to knowingly and intentionally violate any of the provisions of this division or any restrictions implemented pursuant to this article with such violations being subject to punishment as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. 
(Code 1974, § 26-115) 
Secs. 82-152—82-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GAS SERVICE 

Sec. 82-181. - Owner responsible for connection. 
It shall be the responsibility of the property owner where a natural gas meter is located to provide for his own connection from the meter to his gas installation. 
(Code 1974, § 26-42) 
Sec. 82-182. - Request for change in line required. 
Every person who desires a natural gas service line of the city to be changed or moved shall file a written request for such change or movement with the natural gas department of the city at least five working days prior to the date such change or move is desired. 
(Code 1974, § 26-43) 
Sec. 82-183. - Deposit required when requesting line change. 
A deposit shall be made with the city at the time of the filing of the written request referred to in section 82-182, such deposit to be used by the city natural gas department for paying the cost of labor and materials in the moving of the natural gas service line. Upon the completion of the moving of the line, any portion of the deposit not expended for labor and materials in the moving of the line shall be refunded to the person who has deposited it. 
(Code 1974, § 26-44) 
Sec. 82-184. - Minimum charge for changing line. 
A charge as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk for labor and materials for the moving of a natural gas service line shall be paid. Such charge shall be, in all cases, deducted from the required deposit. 
(Code 1974, § 26-45) 
Sec. 82-185. - Owner to cooperate in line changes. 
When a natural gas service line is moved or the location of the natural gas service line is changed, the property owner shall grant to the city all rights, easements, permits and privileges necessary for the moving of the gas line to the new location. 
(Code 1974, § 26-46) 
Sec. 82-186. - Distribution of natural gas owned by the ultimate user. 
The natural gas department of the city is authorized to transport and distribute through the natural gas system of the city on an interruptible basis natural gas which is owned by a customer of such system who is the ultimate user thereof and which is received by the customer from the city's natural gas system at the point of use thereof by such customer upon payment of such fees and charges relative thereto as may be established from time to time by ordinance of the city, all subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Such transportation and distribution shall be authorized only for nonresidential customers having facilities permitting the use of customer owned natural gas on an interruptible basis and having daily average consumption of natural gas on an annualized basis of 500,000 cubic feet per day or greater; 
(2)  Approval and clearance by all appropriate regulatory entities and authorities; 
(3)  Such transportation and distribution shall be contingent upon and subject to transportation of customer's natural gas via Southern Natural Gas Company and South Georgia Natural Gas Company pipelines to the natural gas facilities of the city and the availability of customer's natural gas at the natural gas facilities of the city; 
(4)  No natural gas subject to such transportation and distribution shall be resold by the customer or transported to other premises of the customer without the prior written consent of the city manager; 
(5)  Distribution charges imposed by the city shall be in addition to all transportation costs and penalties incurred by the customer with Southern Natural Gas Company, South Georgia Natural Gas Company and others; 
(6)  Availability of transportation and distribution through the city natural gas system shall be subject to curtailment and interruption due to demand upon the city's natural gas system by noninterruptible customers thereof and to allocation of available distribution capacity between interruptible customers of the city's natural gas system; 
(7)  Payment by customers of all applicable sale taxes and all standby charges relative to such transportation and distribution; and 
(8)  Entry into a transportation and distribution agreement between the customer and the city which is specifically approved by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 26-48) 
Chapter 86 - VEGETATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; vegetation a nuisance, § 38-141 et seq.; parks and recreation, ch. 50; damaging vegetation generally, § 50-10; reckless driving destroying vegetation in parks, § 50-11; landscape requirements for certain vehicular use areas, § 54-81 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; zoning, app. A; subdivisions, app. B. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Crown means the main point of branching or foliage of a tree or shrub, or if none then the upper portion of a tree or shrub. 
Crown spread means the horizontal width of a tree or shrub measured across the tree or shrub at its greatest diameter. 
Danger tree means any tree or shrub: 
(1)  Which because of its condition constitutes a reasonable potential hazard to: 
a.  Improvements or utilities located within the right-of-way of any street; 
b.  Vehicular or pedestrian traffic within the right-of-way of any street; or 
(2)  Which harbors any insect, fungus, pest or disease which constitutes a potential hazard to other trees located within the city which is not eliminated by treatment thereof within 30 calendar days following written notification thereof to the owner of the property upon which such tree is located. 
Park tree means any tree or shrub trunk of which is located within any public area and which is other than a street tree. 
Public area means any real property owned by the city or which is utilized by the city for public purposes. 
Public tree means any tree or shrub the trunk of which is located within a public area. 
Shrub means a woody plant normally characterized by persistent woody stems, low stature and branching near its base. For purpose of this article the word shrub also includes all woody plants of all species which have developed (or which under normal conditions in the city will develop) trunks of a caliper diameter of less than two inches at a height of six inches above ground level. 
Small tree means a self-supporting woody plant of a species which under normal conditions in the city will develop a single trunk of a caliper diameter of at least two inches at a height of six inches above ground level and a maximum height at normal maturity in the city of 25 feet or less. 
Street means any and all public rights-of-way located within the city which are utilized for public vehicular or pedestrian right-of-way purposes including streets, alleys and other ways. 
Street tree means any tree or shrub the trunk of which is located within the right-of-way of a street. 
Topping means the act of cutting back the limbs or branches in the crown of a tree or shrub to stubs thereof which are larger than three inches in caliper diameter at the point of such cut. 
Tree means a self-supporting woody plant of a species which has developed (or which under normal conditions in the city will develop) a single trunk of a caliper diameter of two inches or more at a height of six inches above ground level. 
(Code 1974, § 23-63) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 86-2. - Location of shade trees. 
(a)  All shade trees in the city shall be planted no closer than ten feet from the property lines, so that vision at intersections will not be obstructed. 
(b)  Any person being notified of this section by the chief of police and failing to comply with the this section, shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1974, § 23-8) 
Sec. 86-3. - Location of street trees. 
No street tree shall be planted closer than 35 feet to any street corner as measured from the point of nearest intersecting curb or curbline provided that shrubs maintained at less than 18 inches in height may be planted and maintained within such distances. No street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet to any fire hydrant. 
(Code 1974, § 23-64) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 
Sec. 86-4. - Street trees and public utilities. 
No street tree other than a small tree shall be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead public utility wire or over or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, power line or other public utility. 
(Code 1974, § 23-65) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; utilities, ch. 82. 
Sec. 86-5. - Care of public trees. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article the city shall have the right to plant, prune, cut, maintain and remove, or to cause to be planted, pruned, cut, maintained and removed, any public tree to the extent necessary to ensure public safety, to provide for public utilities, to ensure convenient utilization of streets, or to preserve or enhance the symmetry or beauty of public properties. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article the city shall have the right to prune, cut or remove, or cause to be pruned, cut or removed, any public tree which is a danger tree or any portion of a public tree which: 
(1)  Is in an unsafe condition; 
(2)  Interferes with public utilities or other public improvements convenient utilization of streets; or 
(3)  Is affected with any injurious fungus, insect, pest, or disease. 
(Code 1974, § 23-66) 
Sec. 86-6. - Topping of public trees. 
Except to the extent otherwise permitted under this article, no person or entity shall engage in any act or conduct involving the topping of any public tree except to the extent necessary due to damage by storms or other such casualty or due to its location relative to utility wires where other pruning practices are impractical. 
(Code 1974, § 23-67) 
Sec. 86-7. - Maintenance by owners of private trees. 
(a)  The owner of each tree or shrub any portion of which shall overhang into or over any street shall prune, and to the extent necessary remove, such tree or shrub to the extent that the tree or shrub shall: 
(1)  Not obstruct the light from any street light or obstruct the view of any street intersection; and 
(2)  Be maintained so as to provide a clear space of eight vertical feet above the surface of both the paving of such street and any sidewalk located within the right-of-way of such street. 
(b)  The owner of each tree or shrub which is located upon property which is located within the city shall promptly remove all danger trees and all broken or decayed limbs which may constitute a menace to the safety of the public while utilizing any street. 
(Code 1974, § 23-68) 
Sec. 86-8. - Removal of stumps. 
All stumps of public trees shall, as soon as practicable, be removed below the surface of the ground by the persons or entity responsible for creation of such condition so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground and such persons or entities shall promptly thereafter render the premises to a clean, safe and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1974, § 23-69) 
Sec. 86-9. - Conditions constituting nuisances. 
Conditions and circumstances existing or arising from the failure of those responsible therefor to comply with the provisions of either section 86-7 or section 86-8 shall constitute a nuisance which shall both authorize the abatement of such nuisance by the city pursuant to the provisions of this Code with respect thereto and, in connection therewith, to the assessment of a lien against such person, such entity and the premises for the cost of the abatement of such nuisance. 
(Code 1974, § 23-72) 
Secs. 86-10—86-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TREE BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 86-31. - Creation. 
There is hereby created and established a tree board in and for the city. 
(Code 1974, § 23-50) 
Sec. 86-32. - Purpose. 
The purpose of the tree board shall be to perform the duties specified in this chapter and to perform such other duties as shall be provided from time to time by ordinance adopted by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 23-51) 
Sec. 86-33. - Membership. 
The tree board shall consist of five members appointed and removable by the council by majority vote thereof. Members of the tree board shall be residents of the county, but need not be residents of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 23-52) 
Sec. 86-34. - Term of office. 
The term of office of each member of the tree board shall be on a calendar year basis for a two-year period with members subject to removal either with or without cause by the council prior to the end of their term of office; provided that in the appointment of the first board two members shall be appointed for an initial one-year term and three members shall be appointed for an initial two-year term. 
(Code 1974, § 23-52) 
Sec. 86-35. - Compensation, expenses. 
Members of the tree board shall receive no compensation for their services except that they may be reimbursed for any out-of-pocket expenses incurred by them in direct connection with the performances of their services and duties subject to approval thereof by the city council by resolution thereof in accordance with such requirements as shall be imposed by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 23-53) 
Sec. 86-36. - Meetings. 
Meetings of the tree board shall be held from time to time as necessary for the board to perform its duties and responsibilities. All meetings of the tree board shall be open to the public and shall be held in accordance with the requirements of state law relative to meetings of local governmental entities. 
(Code 1974, § 23-54) 
Sec. 86-37. - Disqualification of members of board. 
(a)  Should any member of the tree board have any personal or financial interest or relationship with respect to any person, matter or issue pending before the board or otherwise be closely associated with any person, matter or issue pending before the board, then such member shall be disqualified to participate in connection with such matter or issue. 
(b)  Any member of the tree board shall be entitled to raise a question of a potential disqualification of any other member who has not disqualified himself whereupon, following such consideration as the board shall deem appropriate, the tree board shall determine by majority vote of those members who are not subject to potential disqualification in connection with such matter or issue whether each such member is or is not disqualified. 
(Code 1974, § 23-55) 
Sec. 86-38. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The tree board shall generally investigate and advise officials of the city regarding the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal and disposition of trees and shrubs located within public areas in the city. 
(b)  The tree board shall develop lists of trees, small trees, shrubs and vines recommended for planting in the city. 
(c)  The tree board shall, upon the request of the city manager, investigate and advise city officials, regarding specific matters relative to trees and shrubs located within the city. 
(d)  The tree board shall hear and determine such issues and matters as it shall be authorized to determine from time to time by ordinance of the city. 
(e)  The tree board shall have such additional duties, responsibilities and powers as shall be specifically provided from time to time by ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1974, § 23-56) 
Sec. 86-39. - Rules and regulations. 
The tree board shall adopt such rules, policies, procedures and regulations for the transactions of its business and for consideration and determination of issues and matters before the board as it deems necessary, subject to the prior approval thereof by the city council. 
(Code 1974, § 23-57) 
Sec. 86-40. - Chair and vice-chair. 
The tree board shall select from among its members a chair who shall preside at meetings and hearings of the board and a vice-chair who shall preside at meetings and hearings of the board in the absence of the chair or the disqualification of the chair. 
(Code 1974, § 23-58) 
Sec. 86-41. - Secretary designated. 
The secretary of the tree board shall be the city clerk or such other person as shall from time to time be so designated by the city manager to perform the functions of secretary of the tree board. 
(Code 1974, § 23-59) 
Sec. 86-42. - Duties of secretary. 
The secretary of the tree board shall provide administrative assistance to the board and shall perform such duties on behalf of the board as the city manager shall from time to time direct. 
(Code 1974, § 23-60) 
Sec. 86-43. - Authority of tree board. 
The tree board shall have no authority or power other than as specifically provided from time to time by ordinance of the city. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing the board shall have no authority, right or power to expend any funds, to direct the activities of any employee or official of the city or to contract for or on behalf of either itself or the city. 
(Code 1974, § 23-61) 
Sec. 86-44. - Legal assistance. 
The city attorney shall be the legal advisor and legal representative of the tree board and shall render such legal assistance to the board as shall be necessary. 
(Code 1974, § 23-62) 
Chapter 90 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses and business regulations, ch. 22; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 78. 
State Law reference— Reciprocal agreements as to operation of vehicles registered in other states inapplicable to motor vehicles for hire, O.C.G.A. § 40-2-95. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 90-1—90-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, adopted Oct. 1, 2012, deleted the former Art. II, §§ 90-31—90-41, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to taxicabs and derived from the Code of 1974, §§ 25-1—25-11. 

Sec. 90-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this chapter, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
City clerk shall mean the city clerk for the City of Tifton, Georgia. 
City manager shall mean the city manager for the City of Tifton, Georgia. 
Company means the holder of a license to operate a taxicab business under the provisions of this chapter, whether a person, firm, partnership or corporation. 
Driver means any person who drives or operates a taxicab on the streets of the city for a licensed taxicab company. 
Police chief or chief of police means the individual employed by the city as the chief of the police department of the city. 
Street means any street, alley, lane, avenue, court or public place in the city. 
Taxicab means a motor vehicle engaged in the business of carrying passengers for hire, or offering to carry persons for hire, except motor vehicles used as ambulances, sightseeing cars and buses, and except for limousines and buses operated on a fixed route. 
Taxicab business license means the written authority and privilege granted by the city for the operation of a taxicab business incorporating the company's ownership and use of at least one taxicab. 
Taxicab driver's permit or permit means the written authority granted by the city for an individual to drive or operate a taxicab within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-32. - Owner's compliance with chapter 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for the holder of a taxicab business license, its agents or employees, to allow any vehicles to be used in the conveyance of passengers or property for hire unless such vehicle has met the requirements set forth in this chapter, and continues to meet to the requirements as set forth in this chapter. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for the holder of a taxicab business license, its agents or employees, to allow any person to drive, use, or operate any vehicle as a vehicle for hire unless that person has met the requirements set forth in this chapter and has been issued a taxicab driver's permit to drive a taxicab within the city limits of Tifton. 
(3)  Any person holding a taxicab business license issued pursuant to this chapter or any employee or agent of such person who violates any provision of this chapter, or directs, consents to, permits, or acquiesces in such violation either directly or indirectly shall, by such conduct, subject the taxicab business license to suspension, revocation or probation upon conditions. For purposes of administering and enforcing this chapter, any act committed by an employee, agent or representative of a holder shall be deemed to be an act of such holder. A violation of any provisions contained within this chapter shall be punishable pursuant to section 1-11 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-33. - Indemnity for benefit of city. 
Any taxicab company operating under this chapter shall hold the city harmless against any and all liability, loss, costs, damages or expenses which may accrue to the city by reason of the negligence, default or misconduct of the company in connection with the rights granted to such company under this article. Nothing in this chapter shall be considered to make the city liable for damages because of any negligent act or omission or commission by any taxicab company, its servants, agents, drivers or other employees, during the operation by the company of a taxicab business or service, either in respect to injuries to persons or with respect to damage to property which may be sustained. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-34. - Identification and markings generally. 
Every taxicab shall have a sign plainly indicating on the door on each side of the vehicle, in letters not less than four inches high, the full name of the taxicab company operating the vehicle, including words such as "taxicab," "taxi," or "cab." Such sign shall be professionally applied and shall be either painted or permanently affixed to each side of the vehicle in clearly visible colors. There shall be no outside advertising of any kind on taxicabs. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-35. - Numbers generally. 
There shall be shown on each side of the vehicle and on the rear of each taxicab a number at least four inches high, such number to be separate and distinct from that on any other public vehicle or taxicab in the city. Such number shall be assigned to such taxicab and its owner by the city clerk. Such number shall be professionally applied and shall be either painted or permanently affixed on the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-36. - Registration of number and names of owner and operator. 
The number assigned a taxicab in accordance with this chapter, together with the names of the owner and operator of the taxicab, shall be registered with the city clerk in a book to be kept for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-37. - Safe mechanical condition of taxicabs required. 
Every taxicab operated on the streets of the city shall be maintained in a safe mechanical condition, with all safety and pollution control equipment remaining intact and operative, at all times when the taxicab is in service. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-38. - Cleanliness of taxicabs required. 
Each vehicle operating under this chapter shall be kept painted, and in a clean, sanitary condition, free of litter and debris, and at all times suitable for public transportation of passengers. The chief of police or his designee, upon observing violations of this section or any other provision of this chapter which deals with the physical condition of taxicabs, shall place a "deadline decal" on the windshield of the vehicle, such decal to list all observed violations. No driver or other unauthorized person shall remove or deface a deadline decal. No driver shall use a vehicle to transport passengers for hire while a deadline decal is in place. The deadline decal will be removed after correction of all listed violations. The deadline decal shall be legible and of sufficient size and color to be easily recognizable and shall be attached the driver's side window of the vehicle. The form for the deadline decal shall be approved by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-39. - State license tag for taxicabs required. 
Prior to the use and operation of any vehicle as a taxicab under the provisions of this chapter, the owner of such vehicle shall secure and display on the vehicle a current state license registration tag. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-40. - [Authority to remove vehicle used as taxicab in violation of this chapter]. 
The chief of police or his designee shall have the authority to remove from operation on the streets of the city any vehicle used as a taxicab which is in violation of this chapter and to prohibit operation of such taxicab until all deficiencies have been corrected. An order of the chief of police or his designee to remove a vehicle from the city streets may be appealed to the city council through the administrative hearing process. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-41. - Manifest. 
Each taxicab driver, operator or company shall maintain a daily manifest upon which shall be recorded all trips made by each vehicle each day, showing time and place of origin, destination of each trip, and amount of fare. All such completed manifests shall be returned to the taxicab company by the driver at least weekly or shall be maintained by the company at its offices at the conclusion of each driver's daily tour of duty. Each taxicab company shall retain and preserve all drivers' manifests for at least 12 months; and such manifests shall be made available to the city, to any officer of the police department, or to the chief of police at all reasonable times. All manifests shall be kept in a legible condition. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-42. - Required. 
No person shall operate a business involving the use of one or more taxicabs on the streets of the city unless a license for such business has first been granted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-43. - Application. 
Application for a license required by this chapter shall be made on the form provided by the city clerk and shall provide for such information as is required for other business license applicants. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-44. - Fee. 
Each person operating a taxicab business license shall pay an annual license fee to the city as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the city clerk. Such annual fee shall be prorated for the remainder of the initial year. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-45. - Duration. 
For purposes of this section, the license year shall begin on January 1 of each calendar year and end December 31 of the same year. Each license issued under this article shall be effective only for the calendar year stated in the license unless sooner suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-46. - Issuance. 
Upon the payment of the required license fee, the filing of the proper application and the issuance of a license, the city shall issue to the applicant named in the application a decal for each vehicle described in such application and with respect to which such fee has been paid, which decal shall describe the vehicle for which it is issued and state for what license year it is issued. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-47. - Display. 
It shall be unlawful to operate or drive any taxicab for hire in the city without having conspicuously displayed on the taxicab a valid current decal accurately describing the taxicab in which it is displayed. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-48. - Fixed place of business required. 
Each taxicab company, as a condition for holding a city business license, shall establish and maintain a fixed headquarters on private property for the operation of the company's business. Such headquarters shall conform to the requirements of the city zoning ordinances and other applicable ordinances of the city or county (if located in the unincorporated area of the county), and shall provide adequate off-street parking space for all taxicabs not in service. Such company headquarters shall not be moved except by the approved transfer of the company's business license to another location. 
No taxicab company operating a taxicab shall use the streets of the city as a place of business or be allowed to use any parking space in the city other than while actually taking on or letting off passengers. All taxicabs shall be parked on a parking lot off of streets within the business district and shall not use business property as a depot of operation unless all taxicabs can be parked behind the depot off of such street. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-49. - Coverage required. 
Any taxicab company desiring to do business within the city shall give and maintain a policy of indemnity insurance with an indemnity insurance company authorized to do business in the state for each vehicle in use as a taxicab, or a self-insurance certificate issued under state guidelines and regulated by the state insurance commission. The minimum coverage shall be $25,000.00 for bodily injury to any one person, $50,000.00 for injury to more than one person which is sustained in the same accident, and $10,000.00 for property damage resulting from one accident. Such indemnity insurance shall inure to the benefit of any person who is injured or who sustains damage to property caused by the negligence of a taxicab company, its servants or agents. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-50. - Blanket policy. 
Any company or person operating a taxicab in the city shall give a separate policy of indemnity insurance or certificate of self-insurance for each separate taxicab for hire, except where such company or person actually owns or holds legal title to more than one taxicab, in which event, such company or person may give one policy of indemnity insurance covering all the taxicabs actually owned. This latter provision, however, shall not apply to any group of persons separately owning taxicabs who may be jointly operating or doing business under a licensed taxicab company name. The taxicab company is responsible for ensuring that individual persons operating taxicabs under such license shall comply with all state laws and local ordinances governing insurance coverage. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-51. - Notice when voided. 
Before any policy of insurance or certificate of self-insurance required by this chapter is voided for any cause, nonpayment of premium or otherwise, notice shall be given, in writing, to the city clerk at least 30 days before it shall be effective. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-52. - Application. 
Any person desiring a Tifton taxicab driver's permit required by this chapter shall submit an application in writing, on a form to be furnished by the city. Such application shall be made under oath and shall state: 
(1)  The age of the applicant; 
(2)  Applicant's address; 
(3)  Length of time applicant has resided in the city; 
(4)  Applicant's knowledge of the streets and traffic laws of the city and how obtained; 
(5)  Whether applicant has any physical infirmities that may affect applicant's ability to operate a moving vehicle safely; and 
(6)  Whether applicant has been convicted of a violation of any of the laws of the state or of this Code or other ordinances of the city and, if so, when and of what offense, and the sentence of the court. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-53. - Qualifications of applicant. 
(1)  Application. Any person seeking to obtain a Tifton taxicab driver's permit must first complete an application provided by the city clerk and must pay the application fee to the city clerk upon submitting the application to the city clerk. The application must be completed in full and the following documents must be included: 
a.  Fingerprints. The city police department shall fingerprint each new applicant which expense must be paid by the applicant. 
b.  Passport photos. Each applicant shall submit with the application, two photographs that are 2½" wide by 2¾" in height, one of such photographs to be retained by the city clerk in the files at the city clerk's office and the other to be attached to the taxicab driver's permit if the same shall be granted to the applicant. The photos shall be taken within the immediately preceding three months. 
c.  Driver's history. Applicants are required to provide a motor vehicle driver's history as prescribed by the chief of police or designee. 
d.  Citizenship documentation required. Provide documentation, as requested by the city clerk, that applicant is a citizen of the United States or an alien admitted for permanent residence or otherwise granted employment authorization by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service. 
e.  Receipt for payment. A copy of the receipt indicating that the taxicab driver's permit application fee has been paid. 
f.  Recommendation from employer. A signed recommendation from the holder of the taxicab business license who is the employer of the driver is required prior to issuance of a taxicab driver's permit. 
(2)  Taxicab driver's permit requirements. Each applicant seeking to obtain a city taxicab driver's permit shall meet the following requirements: 
a.  Applicant must be at least 18 years of age. 
b.  Possess a valid Georgia driver's license, and the license must not be limited as defined in O.C.G.A. § 40-5-64. 
c.  The Applicant must be in good physical and mental health. 
d.  Applicant must meet all of the other requirements for taxicab drivers contained in this chapter. 
(3)  Required information on application. Each applicant seeking to obtain an Tifton taxicab driver's permit shall provide the city clerk the following information under oath on the application: 
a.  The full name, date of birth and age of the applicant. 
b.  Home address of the applicant for the previous ten years. 
c.  The applicant's home telephone number. 
d.  A statement and detailed explanation regarding any convictions of crimes specified in this chapter. 
e.  Further information reasonably related to the qualifications for a taxicab driver's permit as may be required. 
(4)  Investigation of applicant. The chief of police or designee shall conduct a criminal history investigation and background check of each applicant for a taxicab driver's permit in order to determine the moral character and fitness of the applicant. A report of these investigations and a copy of the driver's history of the applicant, if any, shall be attached to the application. A Tifton taxicab driver's permit shall not be issued if the applicant has been convicted of any of the following offenses: 
a.  Any criminal offense involving the operation of a motor vehicle resulting in the death of any person. Driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs within the five years immediately preceding the date of the application. 
b.  Been declared a habitual violator by the department of driver services or its successor. 
c.  Any felony in the commission of which a motor vehicle is used. 
d.  Leaving the scene of an accident involving an occupied or attended vehicle as specified by the laws of this state for a period of 15 years preceding the date of application. 
e.  Leaving the scene of an accident involving an unoccupied vehicle or property damage as specified by the laws of this state for a period of ten years preceding the date of application. 
f.  Perjury or false swearing or making a false statement in any statement under oath in connection with the application for a taxicab driver's permit. 
g.  Convictions, or forfeiture of bail, not vacated, upon three charges of violation of the motor vehicle laws of this state arising out of separate transactions within the 12-month period immediately preceding the application for a permit. 
h.  Involvement in more than two automobile accidents in which it could be reasonably determined that the applicant was at fault, within the 12-month period immediately preceding the application for a permit. 
i.  Except as otherwise specifically provided in subsection (11) below, four or more convictions of this chapter, relating to vehicles for hire, arising out of separate transactions within the current calendar year. 
j.  Two or more convictions of failure to obtain a taxicab driver's, failure to obtain liability insurance required under this chapter, and/or compliance with laws and ordinances relating to taxicabs, arising out of separate transactions within the current calendar year. 
k.  Any felony, criminal intent to commit or the commission of any crime involving theft, prostitution, promotion of prostitution, public lewdness, or a drug-related offense, unless five years have elapsed since the date of termination of any sentence, parole, or probation. 
l.  Any criminal attempt to commit or the commission of a sexual offense or a violent felony, unless 20 years have elapsed since the date of termination of any sentence, parole, or probation. 
m.  Conviction relating to alcohol or drugs within a taxicab, within the 12 months preceding the application for a permit. 
n.  If at the time of application the applicant is charged with any of the offenses listed in this section, consideration of the application will be suspended until entry of plea or verdict or dismissal. For the purposes of this section, a plea of nolo contendere to any of the offenses set out in this subsection shall constitute a conviction. 
(5)  Certification prior to issuance of the taxicab driver's permit. Applicants will certify that they have been furnished a copy of this chapter, City of Tifton, Georgia by the city clerk, and that they have read and understand these sections and agree to abide by the provisions of said chapters. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-54. - Required information on permit. 
Upon approval of an application for a taxicab driver's permit, the city clerk shall issue a permit to the applicant, which shall be signed by the city manager and shall contain the name, address, sex, race, and signature of the applicant. The taxicab driver's permit shall also state the name of the company employing the driver as stated in the application. If the driver changes employment, then the application and permit must be amended to show the change in employment. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-55. - Permit renewal required annually. 
Each permit granted under this chapter shall be valid for a period of one year from the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-56. - Denial of taxicab driver's permit. 
If the application for a taxicab driver's permit is denied, it shall be the responsibility of the city manager or designee within ten days from the date of the denial to provide written notification to the applicant of the reason(s) that the application was denied. Said notice shall be mailed to the applicant's home address as listed in the permit application. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-57. - Appeals. 
Any person who has been denied a Tifton taxicab driver's permit or taxicab business license shall have ten days from the date on the notification of denial to file a petition for appeal with the city council. The city council shall consider the petition and within 45 days of the filing of the petition decide whether to uphold or reverse the denial of the application. Any decision rendered by the city council shall be mailed to the applicant within ten days of the decision at the address listed on the application. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-58. - Permit to be displayed. 
Every driver granted a taxicab driver's permit under this chapter shall post the taxicab driver's permit in a conspicuous manner in such a place as to be in full view at all times to all passengers while such driver is operating a taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-59. - Alteration of permits prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to alter, deface, obliterate or destroy a taxicab driver's permit or cause or allow such behavior. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-60. - Not transferable. 
Any taxicab driver's permit issued under this division is not transferable from one company to another and is to be used solely by the person to whom it is issued. It is unlawful for any driver to operate a taxicab in the city without a valid taxicab driver's permit or for any owner of a company to permit a taxicab under its license to be operated by a driver who does not possess a valid taxicab driver's permit issued pursuant to the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-61. - Renewal. 
Permits may be renewed on a calendar year basis, upon application and payment of the annual fee, unless the permit for the preceding period has been revoked or is under suspension. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-62. - Suspension. 
(a)  The city manager shall have the authority to suspend a taxicab driver's permit for the following reasons: 
(1)  The driver is charged with operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating beverages or drugs, or reckless driving; 
(2)  Making any false statement in the application for the permit; or 
(3)  Operating a taxicab in violation of any provisions of this chapter or applicable state law. 
(b)  The suspension of a taxicab driver's permit for the above reasons, may be appealed as provided for in this chapter. 
(c)  Upon the suspension of a taxicab driver's permit, notice thereof shall be provided to the taxicab company employing the taxicab driver. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-63. - Driving after suspension or revocation prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle for hire or taxicab for the carriage of passengers during any period in which his permit to do so is suspended or revoked in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-64. - Administrative hearing. 
(1)  Upon information and belief there are reasonable grounds to believe that the holder of a taxicab driver's permit or taxicab business license has violated or is not in compliance with any of the provisions of this chapter, the city manager, shall have the authority to suspend a taxicab driver's permit or taxicab business license up to sixty days or to revoke a permit. 
(2)  In the event the city manager suspends or revokes a permit or license under this chapter, the city manager will be required to send notification of the suspension or revocation to the licensee or permittee by certified mail to the licensee to the address on the licensee's application. 
(3)  Any appeal of a suspension or recommendation for revocation by the city manager shall require an administrative hearing. Such hearing shall be informal and shall be heard by the city council. The decision of the city council shall be provided to the taxicab driver or licensee in writing to the to the address listed on the application within ten days of the hearing. The decision of the city council shall be final. 
(4)  If a taxicab driver is suspended three times within any three-year period, and if each appealed suspension is upheld, the fourth such suspension with such three-year period shall be for a period of one year. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-65. - Carrying additional passengers. 
No driver of a taxicab shall pick up or carry any passenger, other than the passenger first employing the taxicab, without the consent of the first passenger. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-66. - Rates must be available in vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful to operate or drive any taxicab in the city without having available for inspection by the passenger the schedule of rates under or by which such taxicab is being operated. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-67. - Charging for hand baggage prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee, operator or driver of any taxicab being operated in the city for hire, to charge any of its passengers any sum for hand baggage or hand luggage. The only charge to be made to such passengers for transportation shall be such passenger fares. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
Sec. 90-68. - Transporting alcoholic beverages. 
Any driver or owner of a taxicab found guilty of hauling, transporting or delivering alcoholic beverages in any quantity anywhere inside of the city limits shall be guilty of an offense and his city taxicab driver's license shall be revoked at the discretion of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2012-17, § I, 10-1-2012) 
APPENDIX A—LAND DEVELOPMENT CODE[1]
